div1.p: 1. *qoukudi/dhs ktl.—a formal method of opening, after the manner of the gnomic poets, not due, as Bloomfield imagined, to ‘the modesty of our author.’ Cf. Herod.init.; Intr. p. xv.

cune/graye—a characteristic word of Thuc., who is known to the ancient critics as o( suggrafeu/s, much as Homer is o( poihth/s. It denotes the bringing together in one work of many occurrences—composing in its etymological sense. (How some find a reference to the hunting up of materials is not clear.)
3. w(s e)pole/mhsan—namely, how, i.e. showing how they waged war. Of course different from o(\n e)pole/mhsan, which would be absurdly tautological. The aorist is called complexive.
4. a)rca/menos ( tou= cuggra/yai ) ktl.—we are to understand that as soon as the war broke out Thuc. began to put down what occurred, and kept a sort of diary of the war.
eu)qu\s kaqistame/nou—supply tou= pole/mou.

5. e)lpi/sas—expecting. On the relation of the participles here see Intr. p. xli. This first sentence is very characteristic of Thuc., in whose periods form is constantly subordinated to sense. O. Muller well says that Thuc. has two favourite forms of period, (a) the main predication, followed by clauses giving the circumstances and reasons, which may in turn be explained in similar clauses; and (b) the reasons, circumstances in participial and other clauses followed by the resulting fact or opinion, as in c. 2. 2.
a)ciologw/taton tw=n p.—the illogical form of comparison, as in c. 10. 3, cf. ‘fairest of her daughters Eve’: Tac. Ag. 34 ceterorum fugacissimi. It is frequent in Greek.

6 tekmairo/menos—inferring this, adding the grounds of the e)lpi/s These grounds are (1) o(/ti a)kma/zontes ..., (2) o(rw=n ... Thus the clause with o(/ti is co-ordinate with a partic. of cause; cf. Xen. Symp. 8. 11 tekmai/romai th=| kaloka)gaqi/a| kai\ o(/ti se o(rw=.
7. a)kma/zonte/s ... paraskeuh=|—at the height of their military power. That h)=|san, not h)=san, is the true reading there cannot be a doubt; for i)e/nai e)s in this pregnant use see L. & S.
8. to\ a)/llo *(ellhniko/n—including the Greeks outside Greece proper. Cf. to\ lhstiko/n, to\ barbariko/n, to\ ceniko/n, and many others.

10. kai\ dianoou/menon—sc. cuni/stasqai, the ellipse of an infin. with dianoei\sqai being common, as in 124. 3. The kai/ serves to bring dianoou/menon into connexion with cunista/menon; we should put ‘actually’ with to\ me\n eu)qu/s. The Sicilian Greeks are a good example.

ga/r—as ‘the movement’ meant by ki/nhsis must be (1) the war itself, and (2) the unrest that preceded it, ga/r cannot introduce the reason of the expectation that the war would be important, but must be epexegetic.
12. me/rei tini/—a considerable part, as, for example, Thrace and Macedon. Supply e)ge/neto, affected.

w(s de\ ei)pei=n—qualifying plei=ston. Note that w(s(e)/pos)ei)pei=n never apologises for a metaphor, but always limits a sweeping or universal statement. Hence (it extended, e)ge/neto), one might almost say, over the greatest part of mankind; i.e. it affected perhaps a greater part of mankind than had been affected by any previous commotion. Of course the possible exception is the Persian wars.

(Whatever be the exact construction of megi/sth dh\ ... a)nqrw/pwn—and the words are variously interpreted—Thuc. over-estimates the importance of the war. If we supply megi/sth dh\ e)ge/neto to me/rei tini/ and e)pi\ plei=ston, the exaggeration is extreme. e)pi\ plei=ston is taken by Classen and others to mean the greatest part of the (known) world; but this involves a very great exaggeration of a fact ascertainable; and it is unlikely that Thuc. would make such a sweeping statement. It looks also as if plei=ston, more than before, were meant to be parallel to megi/sth, greater than before. The text has no appearance of being corrupt or interpolated.)
13. ta\ pro\ au)tw=n—the events that preceded this disturbance (ki/nhsis). The neut. au)ta/ is frequently used by Thuc. with reference to the details of the subject he is dealing with.

(This phrase cannot refer to events that immediately preceded the war; for (a) dia\ xro/nou plh=qos would then be absurd, (b) Thuc. himself gives an account of the fifty years preceding the war as a period well known, (c) the Persian wars could not be ineluded in ou) mega/la nomi/zw gene/sqai kata\ tou\s pole/mous (cf. c. 18. 2). Thuc. must be thinking of the period of the Trojan war and of that between the Trojan war and the Persian war, i.e. to the end of the Tyrants. But the words are very inexact; cf. Intr. p. xx).
14. ta\ e)/ti palai/tera—events preceding the Trojan war.
15. a)du/nata—Thuc. frequently uses the neut. plur. of the verbal or of an adj. for the sing. where the subject is an infin. or a sentence. The use is mainly poetical.

tekmhri/wn—these ‘evidences’ are detailed in cc. 2-17: (1) migrations were frequent; (2) there was no common name; (3) weakness by sea; (4) the expeditions by land were on a small scale and were confined to border-fighting; (5) the tyrants hampered Greece proper, and Persia hampered Ionia.
1. w(=n belongs to pisteu=sai, and is probably attracted from a(/. Chambry quotes Soph. OT 646 pi/steuson, *oi)di/pous, ta/de, for the accus. with pisteu/w.
e)pi\ makro/taton skopou=nti—by earrying my inquiry to the farthest hunt (of the past). e)pi\ makro/taton of time also in Hdt. 1.171, in a similar connexion.
5. oi)koume/nh— this and the following participles are imperfect.
6. ou)=sai—sc. fai/nontai.
ta\ pro/tera—the adverbial accus., in plur, is common in Thuc., but is seldom found in other prose anthors.
8. biazo/menoi—the pres. and imperf. of this verb in a passive sense are far less common in other prose authors than in Thuc.
u(po/ tinwn ai)ei\ pleio/nwn—what is noticeable here is that ai)ei/ (‘from time to time’) occurs with tinwn, and not with tw=n, which—as the older critics note—is the usual form of expression.

9. th=s ga\r e)mpori/as ktl—see note on p. 1 l. 6. The causes to which the readiness to migrate are ascribed are (1) absence of commerce and intercommunication: th=s ga\r ...
qala/sshs: (2) low state of agriculture and absence of capital sunk in the land: nemo/menoi/ te ... futeu/ontes: (3) absence of demand for anything beyond the necessaries of life, which could be procured anywhere: th=s te ... e)pikratei=n.

e)pimeignu/ntes—the mid. is used in the same sense, e.g. in c. 146. At a period when the tribes of Greece regarded one another as enemies, it was impossible that e)pimici/a should exist, e)pimici/a being based upon treaties. In later times e)pimici/a terminated as soon as a state of war existed.
10. dia/—the sea as the medium of intercourse.

11. nemo/menoi—the word is used of enjoyment of profits derived, which may be combined with occupation. The following participles—e)/xontes, futeu/ontes—are circumstances explanatory of the degree of ‘enjoyment’ attained. (ne/mesqai w(s to\ polu\ to\ lamba/nein pro/sodon para\ *qoukudi/dh|, Photius.)
ta\ au(tw=n—what they had acquired by adverse possession.
12. o(/son—i.e. tosou=ton, o(/son, where o(/son = w(/ste, and is assimilated to the adverbial accus. tosou=ton.
a)pozh=n—this word occurs nowhere else in Attic, but is used by late writers (Lucian, Aelian, etc.), some at least of whom think it means to live poorly, inferring the sense implied in this passage.
periousi/an ktl.—had they accumulated stores for the purpose of barter, and had they planted trees, it would have been less easy to migrate.
13. a)/dhlon o)/n—accus. abs.

14. e)pelqw
 kai\ a)teixi/stwn a(/ma o)/.—(1) alternative explanations, seldom desirable, are here clearly called for; (2) taking a)teixi/stwn o)/ntwn first: the sense is, ‘as they were without walls.’ The simplest way is to suppose this masc. and dependent on a)fairh/setai. This involves making kai\ ... a/ma almost equivalent to a)/llws te kai/: kai/, we are told, does not = ‘and,’ but kai\ ... a)/ma = ‘particularly,’ as in 102. 3 and elsewhere. But (3) this makes it impossible to explain why tis ... a(/llos, which go together, are separated, because e)pelqw
 ... o)/ntwn is not then one expression. (4) This objection is diminished if kai\ ... o)/ntwn is taken as a parenthetical gen. abs., either (a) masc., with au)tw=n supplied, or (b) neut., with subj. supplied from context, like plwimwte/rwn o)/ntwn c. 7. (5) The objection disappears if kai/ = ‘and,’ e)pelqw
 kai\ a). a(/ma o)/ntwn giving the two circumstances leading to loss—a)fairh/setai. Though one circumstance
is modal—e)pelqw/n—the other causal, it is like Thuc. to connect them by kai/.
15. a)nagkai/ou—of what will just suffice, as in necessarius cibus. a)nagkai=os is frequently fem, in Plato. bi/aios and be/baios always have two terminations in Thuc.
16. pantaxou=—anywhere. The sense any frequently belongs to pa=s and words front it.
17. di' au)to/—accordingly; Thuc, often uses au)to/(-a/) in reference to a previous statement
mege/qei—of the number of inhabitants, as in c. 10.
18. paraskeuh=|—naval and military resources, as distinct from kataskeuh/, the external adornment of a city.
19. h( a)ri/sth—cf. th=s gh=s ou) pollh\n e)/temon 6.7. The attraction is most common with polu/s, but is fairly frequent with other adjectives.
20. nu=n ... kaloume/nh belongs to both nouns. In early times the districts had no general name.

22. *)arkadi/as—the exemption was due to the isolated character of Arcadia, the consequence of its mountams. a)/rktos, Bear-land; cf. a)/rkeios. The Arcadrans were unaffected by the Dorian migration They prided themselves on being autochthones (cf. Xen. Hell. 7.1. 23), and on their primeval antiquity (cf. L & S. under prose/lhnos).
kra/tista—best, the regular meaning of kra/tistos when applied to land.

23. a)reth/n—fertility. When Greece was in the village stage, (1) the inhabitants of some districts grew (comparatively) wealthy, and as a consequence there were disputes between the ‘haves’ and ‘have-nots’; (2) these fertile districts excited the cupidity of other clans.
25. ma=llon—more than communities whose land was not so fertile.
26. gou=n—at any rate the immunity of Attica was due to its barrenness; it is therefore likely that the troubles of other districts were due to their fertility.
tou= e)pi\ plei=ston, ‘the remotest time.’ e)pi\ plei=ston, adverbial (‘extending farthest back’), has the art. like to\ pri/n, etc.

to\ lepto/gewn—(1) the constant use of neut. adj. or partic. for a subst. is a feature of Thuc.'s style; (2) the soil of
Attica is in general stony and dry. The Attic Plain is watered by the Ilissus and Cephisus, but in summer the former is almost dry and the latter “meiou=tai tele/ws”: the land yields a return only to diligent cultivation. Of course in these early times the land was not setentifically dealt with; and it is noteworthy, as bearing on Thuc.'s point, that it looks more barren than it is.
28. para/deigma—the meaning of this term in Greek rhetoric is not merely ‘example,’ but ‘an example used to support an argument.’
to/de—referring to the sentence that follows, e)k ga/r ktl.
tou= lo/gou—explained by dia/, etc.

29. dia\ ta\s metoiki/as ktl.—that it was owing to the habit of settling elsewhere (to which I have referred) that Greece in other respects (besides population and security) had not advanced so fast (as Attica). metoiki/as is used exactly as in Aesch. Eum. 1019, where the Furies refer to their metoiki/a to and in Athens. 1. That e)k ga/r ktl. explains to/de is proved by the usage of Thuc. 2. dia\ ... au)chqh=nai is beset with difficulties. With the MS. reading ta\s metoiki/as e)s ta\ a)/lla three explanatious have been proposed: (a) ‘Attica did not grow in other respects so fast as in population.’ But this does not fall in with the general line of the argument. (b) ‘Attica through the presence of me/toikoi advanced much more (mh\ o)moi/ws) in other respects.’ But neither is this the argument, nor is there any proof that mh\ o(moi/ws can in such a connexion as this mean much more. (c) With regard to the rendering given above, it is denied that Greece can be the subject of au)chqh=nai. But, if we examine c. 2 as a whole, this does not appear impossible. The chapter deals with the early condition of Greece in general—h( nu=n *(ella/s kalouue/nh—the smallness of the communities (ou)/te mege/qei po/lewn i)/sxuon) and their weakness. To these conditions the very fertility of the soil contributed. Attica, which was barren, was an exception in both respects. It did not lose inhabitants by sta/sis: it did not excite the cupidity of strangers. On the other hand, strangers settled in Attica because it offered security; and thus the population of Attica was still further increased, and it was able to colonise. These last facts lend further support to my general argument (o( lo/gos), viz. that the weakness of the early Greeks in all respects is largely accounted for by the shifting nature of the population. h( *(ella/s is in the writer's mind throughout. e)s ta\ a)/lla is explained by many ‘with reference to its other parts’; but it more naturally means in other respects than those points to
which I have specifically referied. A striking example of this (ex contrario) is the colonising energy of Attica, the consequence of freedom from migration. Some take e\s ta\ a)/lla with metoiki/as—migrations to other parts; but ta/ is then wrong. Ullrich's emendation, according to which ta\ a)/lla, other parts of Greece, is subject of au)chqh=nai—see crit. 11.—is generally accepted; but it is not absolutely necessary.
2. pole/mw|—referring to u(po\ a)llofu/lwn e)pebouleu/onto.
3. oi( dunatw/tatoi—limiting apposition to oi( e)kpi/ptontes. This kind of apposition is common in Thuc.—The most conspicuous instance is that of the Alcmaeonidae from Pylus.

w(s be/baion o)/n—taken as (1) accus. abs., with a)naxwrei=n par' *)aqhnai/ous implied; (2) by Classen as governed by para/, in a loose apposition to *)aqhnai/ous. The second, though loose in grammar, gives a better sense.

4. poli=tai gigno/menoi—the imperf. partic, points to the many instances in which citizenship was bestowed. Of course this system of conferring civic rights belongs to a time when only the Eupatrids had any political power. They admitted new families freely. In later days, on the contrary, when Athens had attained power and the demos ruled, the Ecclesia was very jealous of the citizenship. Yet this welcome of political exiles remained an houourable tradition, as we see from the plays of Euripides
eu)qu\s a)po\ palaiou= with e)poi/hsan, but eu)qu/s belongs to a)po\ p., being equivalent to a)rca/menoi eu)qu/s: cf. c. 146 and 142. 7.
7. e)ce/pemyan—sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi. The colonising activity of Attica is supposed to have begun in the eleventh cent. B.C.
9. dhloi=—second proof of weakness, viz. lack of communication.
tw=n palaiw=n—neut., like ta\ pro\ au)tw=n kai\ ta\ e)/ti palai/tera in c. 2. Here ta\ palaia/ is explained to mean ta\ pro\ tw=n Trwikw=n The lit. trans, is insignificance in our early history.
11. pro/teron—this merely repeats the sense of pro/, as in ou) pro/teron ... pri/n ktl.

12. dokei= de/ moi—(1) at first parenthetical, afterwards (2) dokei= h( e)pi/klhsis ou)de\ ei)=nai, (3) dokei= a)/lla (nom.) ...
pare/xesqai, (4) dokei= *)/ellhnas kalei=sqai, (5) ? parenthetical, before e)du/nato. When a verb can take more than one construction, Thuc. sometimes combines alternative constructions in the same sentence without repeating the verb.

13. ta\ pro\ *(/ellhnos—adv. accus., as ta\ pro/tera c. 2, ta\ e)n th=| ei)rh/nh| 54.3. Hellen was son of Deucalion and Pyrrha; and Hellenes from Phthiotis accompanied Achilles to Troy. How the name came to be be extended to all the Greeks is unknown.

14. kai\ pa/nu—emphasised by being separated from ei)=nai. Cf. Xen. Anab. 1.5.8 kai\ ma/la kata\ pranou=s ghlo/fou, Dem. 5. 15 kai\ pa/nu fhsi/ tis au)tou\s a)naisqh/tous ei)=nai, and so with ou) (mh/) pa/nu not unfrequently. We should rather expect ou) pa/nu moi dokei= ou)d' ei)=nai.
ei)=nai—this and the infins, that follow are imperfect.

15. kata\ e)/qnh—distributive. This forms the subject to pare/xesqai = ‘various tribes,’ a)/lla te kai\ to\ P., among others the Pelasgian tribe, being in apposition to k. e)/qnh. Adverbial phrases are frequent in Thuc. as equivalent of a case of a subst.: as in 6.39 tau=ta kai\ kata\ me/rh kai\ cu/mpanta.

16. to\ *pelasgiko/n—a tribe of aborigines, whom Homer speaks of as dwelling in Asia Minor and Crete as well as in Greece. For the facts and theories about them see Abbott. Hist. Greece i. p. 27 fol. “When the Pelasgi became established [in literature] as an ancient tribe, those nations which laid claim to great antiquity, as the Athenians and Arcadians, became Pelasgians” (This is enough to know.)
e)pi\ plei=ston—this belongs to to\ *pelasgiko/n, meaning that the name of the P. was more widely extended than that of any other tribe.
17. pare/xesqai—sc. to the country.
tw=n pai/dwn—Aeolus, Dorus, and Xuthus.
18. i)sxusa/ntwn—ingressive aor., ‘having become mighty.’
19. e)pagome/nwn—sc. tinw=n.
e)p' w)feli/a|—to aid them. w)feli/a often = boh/qeia; cf. 1.73.2 e)p' w)feli/a|.
20. kaq' e(ka/stous—subject of kalei=sqai: the several tribes more and more (h)/dh ma=llon) began to be called Hellenes in consequence of their intercourse (with the Hellenes).
21. pollou= xro/nou—time within which (partitive), less commonly found in positive sentences.

22. e)du/nato—sc. to\ kalei=sqai *(/ellhnas. Shil. quotes Eur. Phoen. 12-13 kalou=si d' *)ioka/sthn me, tou=to ga\r path\r
e)/qeto. The e)du/nato is probably spurious, because, though the constrn. of dokei= shifts (see on 1. 12), the two clauses kaq' e(ka/stous me\n ... ou) me/ntoi should have the same form, just as ta\ me\n . kata\ e)/qnh de/ have. Even if the constrn. were again changed here, we should probably have e)ceni/khse.
25. w)no/masen—sc. *(/ellhnas.
ou)d' a)/llous—i.e. Hellas in Homer is Phthiotis, B 684. It has been pointed out that in a 344, d 726, 816, o 80 *(ella/s with *)/argos denotes Greece in general. The lines are perhaps spurious.
27. ta\ e)/ph—the poems.
28. a)nakalei=—distinguishes them as. a)nakalw= is call by a distinctive, official name.
ou) mh\n ou)de/—nor even; ou) mh\n a)lla/ = ‘not but what.’

1. barba/rous ei)/rhke—mentioned barbarians, because not yet had the Hellenes either been distinguished under one name in opposition (to them). There is a difficulty as to the construction of a)nti/palon. (1) Eustathius, followed by Stahl and Steup, made it agree with o)/noma, despite the order; and the adj. is occasionally separated by a prep. from its subst.; (2) Classen thought it an adverb like tou)nanti/on: the absence of the article is one reason against this; (3) Böhme made it internal accus. to a)pokekri/sqai, to have undergone an opposing separation, and Krüger favours this; (4) Mr. Forbes says it is in apposition to *(/ellhnas, which means the word Greeks. But should we not even so require a)ntipa/lous or *(/ellhnes?

The edd. note that Thuc. neglects the epithet barbaro/fwnoi, of the Carians, in Hom. Il. 2.867. But this simply means speaking an unknown tongue, and the statement of Thuc. is substantially correct. The Greeks could not be conscious that they were a separate people before they were conscious that they were one people.
3. d' ou)=n—resuming after the digression of which 3.3 consists.

oi( ... w(s e(/kastoi ... klhqe/ntes—the main subject is oi( *(/ellhnes klhqe/ntes, those who came to be called H. This is divided into (a) w(s e(/kastoi kata\ po/leis te o(/soi a)llh/lwn cuni/esan,
referring to kaq' e(ka/stous me\n h)/dh ... *(/ellhnas 3.2; (b) kai\ cu/mpantes u(/steron, referring to ou) me/ntoi ... a(/pasin e)knikh=sai. In (a) te = both is misplaced, the irregularity being explained by the fact that kata\ ... cunie/san is added to w(s e(/kastoi as an afterthought. Possibly, however, te = and, but it is hard to see any distinction between w(s e(/kastoi and kata\ p. The sentence is overloaded, since u(/steron, i e. long after the Trojan War (cf. 3.3), is combined with a statement of what happened pro\ tw=n *trwikw=n. Observe also that this apparent recapitulation (oi( d' ou)=n ktl.) does not agree entirely with the statements made in 3.2, where nothing is said about a common language. Thuc., as others have noticed, does not seem to have a clear view of the matter.
8. The MS. cunh=lqon will not do: e)ce/rxomai, e)/ceimi with accus, are not rare in Attic prose in a military sense; but e)/rxomai, ei)=mi are not used so.
9. *Mi/nws ga/r—from this point to c. 8 Thuc. deals with the gradual growth of maritime enterprise, and the ‘barbarian character of the early Greeks.’ For Minos see Abbott, Hist. Greece i. p. 122.
palai/tatos—was the first to. This does not belong to tw=n *kukla/dwn ... e)ge/neto, and perhaps not to th=s nu=n ... e)kra/thse.
10. th=s ... qala/sshs—this may depend on e)pi\ plei=ston, or on e)kra/thse.
12. h)=rce—became ruler.
13. prw=tos—later the Athenians colonised the islands, and after that an Athenian would be honoured as oi)kisth/s. See c. 12. 4.

15. e)gkatasth/sas—this partic. is of course not antecedent in time to the main verb e)ge/neto. It is aor. merely because it is the explanation how e)ge/neto oi)kisth/s, the partic. being equivalent to kai/ + aor. ind. (This use of the aor. partic. in Thuc. disposes of the passages discussed by Mr. Forbes, Thuc. i. p. 142.)
w(s ei)ko/s—as was natural (in one who ruled the sea).
16. kaqh/|rei—used of destroying, putting an end to a power, as in c. 16. 1.
17. tou= ... i)e/nai—purpose, generally with mh/. Tac. imitates this in Ann. 2.59 Aegyptum proficiscitur cognoscendae antiquitatis, etc.
21. e)p)—to, not against.
23. ou) tw=n a)dunatwta/twn = tw=n dunatwta/twn.

ke/rdous e(/neka—a frequent phrase. Notice the place of e(/neka, which is usual when it applies to two nouns, as e.g. Antiphon 6, 7 diabolh=s e(/neka kai\ a)pa/ths, Lys. 32. 10 kai\ th=s a)delfh=s e(/neka kai\ sfw=n au)tw=n. But the rule is not absolute.
24. toi=s a)sqene/si trofh=s—cf. Dem. 1.22 ta\ th=s trofh=s toi=s ce/nois. a)sqenei=s = ‘weak.’
25. po/lesin a)teixi/stois—i.e. village communities. We cannot help thinking of the great aphorism in 7.77. 7 a)/ndres ga\r polis kai\ ou) tei/xh.
27. bi/ou—livelihood. e)poiou=nto = ‘would get,’ a sense more familiar in the corresponding passive forms, o( bi/os e)gi/gneto au)toi=s.
e)poiou=nto—see L. & S. A. II. 2.
e)/xontos—synonymous with fe/rontos. 2.37.3 no/mwn o(/soi ai)sxu/nhn fe/rousi, 2.41.3 tw=| polemi/w| a)gana/kthsin e)/xei.
2. dhlou=si—i.e. show the truth of the preceding statements: there is even in the present day evidence for what I have said.
tw=n h)peirwtw=n tines—i.e. those dwelling in the coast towns of the mainland.
3. kalw=s—cleverly, as often in kalw=s le/gein.
tou=to dra=n—a regular expression for referring to a previous verb.
4. oi( palaioi/—sc. dhlou=si.

ta\s pu/steis ... e)rwtw=ntes—lit. everywhere agreeing in putting the stock question to strangers who come by sea, ‘are you pirates?’ thus showing that the persons addressed were not accustomed to disown the occupation, and that those who made it their bussiness to know did not censure it. Of ‘the old poets’ Homer is one (Od. 3.71 and 9.252); and there is the Hymn to Apollo l. 452; but of course Thucydides knew other passages. The wording of the sentence has been questioned; but Thuc. seems to have had in mind h( pu/stis tw=n katapleo/ntwn e)sti\n ei) lh|stai/ ei)sin. The poets are said to ask the question: for the characters are the mouthpiece of the poet.
6. ou)/te ... te frequently correspond, as in Lat. neque ... et

punqa/nontai ... e)pimele\s ei)/h—the forms of the recta and obliqua are combined, as frequently in Xen. = w(=n punqano/meqa ... oi(=s a)\n e)pimele\s h)=|. It expresses the thought of the poets. (Others seem to consider punqa/nontai as hist. pres. and ei)/h as pure iterative opt.)

8. kai\ kat' h)/peiron—i.e. they not only carried on piracy at sea, but plundered one another on land as well. kat' h)/peiron = kata\ gh=n. That Thuc. is thinking here of the towns near the coast is shown by c. 7.5 ai( de\ palaiai\(po/leis)dia\ th\n lh|stei/an a)po\ qala/sshs w)|ki/sqhsan.
10. tw=| palaiw=| tro/pw|—i.e. kata\ kw/mas oi)kou/mena kai\ a(rpazo/mena.
peri/—in the parts about. The names of the people are used by Thuc. indifferently with the place-names.
12. te—and so.

13. sidhroforei=sqai—below we have the act.: the mid. means to provide one's self with, see that one has. Such compounds of forw= (cf. kanhforw=, xrusoforw=) are not ordinarily used in mid.; but cf. Aristot. Pol. 2.1268b e)sidhroforou=nto/ te ga\r oi( *(/ellhnes, kai\ ta\s gunai=kas e)wnou=nto par' a)llh/lwn.
16. oi)kh/seis—settlements, the po/leis of c. 5. 1.
17. (dia\ ta\s) ... e)fo/dous—their hazardous intercourse.
cunh/qh ktl = cunh/qws e)dih|tw=nto.

19. tau=ta ... e)/ti ou(/tw nemo/mena—the fact that in these parts of Greece men still live in this way. This predicative use of the partic. is less common in Gk. than in Lat. (see M. T. 829 b). It is most often found with prepositions, and especially in phrases indicating time, with meta/, e)pi/, a(ma/. With certain well-defined exceptions, it does not occur unless the noun and verb yield sense without the partic.; i.e. the partic, was felt to be separate from the noun.

20. e)s pa/ntas o(moi/wn—lit. extending in similar form to all, like e)s o)li/gous oi)kei=n in 2.37. 1. The substitution of the noun diaithma/twn for the verb inf. tou= ... diaita=sqai with snitable constrn. Is characteristic of the old style.

21. e)n toi=s prw=toi—the undoubted exx of this idiom in Thuc are, besides this place (where Prof. Tucker wrongly says the evidence favours prw/tois), 3.82. 1 (sta/sis)e)n toi=s prw/th e)ge/neto: 7.24. 3 me/giston kai\ e)n toi=s prw=ton: ib. 71. 3 e)n toi=s xalepw/tata: 8.90. 1 e)n toi=s ma/lista. In 7.19. 4
the MSS. give e)n toi=s prw/tois (not prw=toi): ib. 27, e)n toi=s prw/tois (not prw=ton or prw/th): in viii. 89 e(n toi=s prw/tois (not prw=toi). Pre-eminence is not necessarily implied in any example, and Herbst is perhaps right in saying that prominence only is meant. If so, it may be that the nom. is due only to attraction to the subject; the principle being naturally extended to the adverb.
22. a)neime/nh| th=| diai/th|—dat, of manner.
24. au)toi=s—ethic dat., very common in Thuc, where the gen. might be used.
25. eu)daimo/nwn—in the popular meaning

dia\ to\ a(brodi/aiton—with forou=ntes. For the long linen (Ionian) xitwn worn by Ionians, Carians, Lydians see Gardner and Jevons, Gk. Ant. p. 49. Cf. Aesch. Persae 41 a(brodiai/twn d' e(/petai *ludw=n o)/xlos. Aften the Persian wars the short (Dorian) xitw/n of wool was substituted for it.
ou) polu\s xro/nos e)peidh/—no long time ago. a)f' ou)=, e)c ou(=, e)pei/, w(s, o(/te are all found in such phrases.

27. xrusw=n tetti/gwn seem to be pins with figures of grasshoppers at the end. Several might be used, apparently, for one krw/bulos, like hairpins. Helbig, however, thinks that metal spiral ornaments through which the ‘tail’ of the hair was passed are meant, and Studniczka supports this view; but it does not seem probable. The krw/bulos—which doubtless took different forms—is perhaps to be recognised on ancient monuments, since Xen. Anab. 5. 4. 13 speaks of leather helmets adorned with a krw/bulos and resembling a tiara (the various forms of which are well known). ei)/rw, twist, favours ‘coil’; but, if the pins had a bend in them, we can understand e)/nersis. (The v.l. e)n e)/rsei is prob. a false division like e)n tomh=| for e)ntomh=, c. 93. 5.) Cf. Aristoph. Eq. 1325, Nub. 984.

28. a)f' ou(=—from this circumstance It is likely that Thuc. is mistaken in saying that the Athenians carried the fashion to Asia Minor, and that it spread rather from the Ionians (Carrans, Lydians) to the Athenians. Cf. Herod. 5.88.
1. e)pi\ polu/—temporal.

metri/a|—this may mean that the Dorians too for a time had worn the ‘Ionian’ dress; but more probably Thuc. in metri/a| and e)s to\n nu=n tro/pon thought rather of the Athenians, and meant merely that the Spartans originated the ‘Dorian’ xitw/n.
4. i)sodi/aitoi with pro\s tou\s pollou/s, ta\ mei/zw, which is unusual for ta\ plei/w, is thought to refer to the fact that land was the sole form of wealth in early Sparta.

6. e)s to\ fanero\n a)podu/ntes —es to\ f. is a standing phrase for ‘openly,’ ‘in public,’ with verbs of motion, or suggestive of motion. The simplest form of phrase is such as e)s to\ f. e)negkei=n (Hyperid. I. v. 3), but Thuc., as so often, strains the use of the prep.
li/pa—with oil, frequent in Homer. It is generally explained as instrumental case, but K. W Kruger calls it internal accus.
meta\ tou=—in company with, i.e. ‘when they ...,’ as 3.59. 3 bi/ou ki/ndunos e)llu\s met' au)tou= (sc. tou= teleuta=n lo/gou).
7. h)lei/yanto—reflexive mid. like lou/omai, o(pli/zomai, and other words of the toilet.
8. diazw/mata—Il. 23, 683 zw=ma de/ oi( prw=ton paraka/bbalen.
10. pe/pautai—sc. to\ diazwmata e)/xontas a)gwnizesqai.

The order is e)/ti de\ kai\ nu=n e)n toi=s b e)/stin oi(=s (= e)ni/ois), kai\ ma/lista(e)n)toi=s *)asianoi=s. In the nom. plur, always ei)si\n oi)/, ai(/; in oblique cases always e)/stiu w(=n etc. in Thuc, unless words intervene, as in vii. 25 h)=san tw=n staurw=n ou(/s.
12. a)=qla ti/qetai kai/ = a)/qlwn tiqeme/nwn.
13. polla\ ... o(moio/tropa—internal accus. to diaitw/menon.
16. o(/sai me/n ktl.—“This clause (down to e(/kastoi i)sxu/os) is really subordinate to ai( de\ palaiai/ ktl. Whereas the most recent cities, etc,” Forbes.

17. plwimwte/rwn o)/ntwn—when navigation was easier, impers, gen. abs. corresponding to plwimw/tera e)ge/neto 8. 2. It is a question whether periousi/as ... e)/xousai goes closely with plwimwte/rwn o)/ntwn, so that kai/ joins new/tata to e)/xousai, or belongs to e)kti/zonto: c. 8 katasta/ntos tou= *mi/nw nautikou= plwimw/tera e)ge/neto (i.e. as early as Minos) favours the former; but c. 8.3 seems to show that Thuc. uses new/tata here vaguely of cities founded since Minos purged the seas.
20. a)pela/mbanon—occupied, cutting them off from the mainland with walls. The change of subject from the placenames to their inhabitants is common, e.g. 6.48; 74. 1; 75. 2; 88. 8; 94. 1.
21. e(/kastoi—in this place because it goes closely with pro\s tou\s prosoi/kous. On the order of e(/neka see 5. 1.
22. e)pi\ polu/—temporal.
23. On a)nti/sxousan (=dia\ to\ th\n l. a)nti/sxein) see 6. 2 l. 19.
24. kai\ e)n—the art. not repeated, as often in Thuc. (6. 1), even when the two members are contrasted.
25. e)/feron—sc. oi( lh|steu/ontes. They plundered not only one another but those who, though not sea-farers, lived on the coasts (=paraqala/ssioi h)=san).
1. oi( nhsiw=tai—the island barbarians were pirates ou)x h(=sson h)\ oi( *(/ellhnes.
3. w)/|khsan—previous to the time of Minos.
*dh/lou—in 426 B.C.; 3.104. The ‘proof’ applies only to the Carians, whence it may be inferred that the presence of Phoenicians in the islands was questioned by none.
6. u(pe\r h(misu/—subject, = plei/ous tw=n h(mi/sewn (though of course it might be taken as adverbial).
7. th=| skeuh=| tw=n o(/plwn—lit. their equipment (consisting) of arms, not ‘the style of their arms.’
9. Here Thuc. resumes from c. 4.
plwimw/tera e)le/neto—the neut. plur. as in 7. 1.
10. e)k tw=n nh/swn —e)k for e)n by (the regular method of) attraction to the verb.
11. o(/teper—namely, when, referring back to c. 4.
12. oi( para\ qa/lassan—cf. oi( par' e)/palcin 2.13. 5, para/ with dat. not being used of inanimates except when persons are clearly implied.
15. tei/xh perieba/llonto—referring to cities already in existence, but hitherto without walls: hence not as in c. 7.
w(s plousiw/teroi e(autw=n g.—the omission of au)toi/ in this idiom is rare: ‘as was natural, since they were now growing wealthier than they had been hitherto.’
16. ga/r refers to bebaio/teron w)/|koun. The double te presents the same process under two different aspects.
18. doulei/an—dependence. as often: so with douleu/ein. The weaker states became tributaries of the stronger.

periousi/as e)/xontes—usually rendered ‘because they had wealth at their command’ and used it to extend their power;
but more probably, ‘having funds in hand’ and being anxious to increase them. The more the funds increased, the more eager would they be to inerease them still further.
20 e)n tou)tw| ... o)/ntes—when they had now advanced to this condition, i.e. navigated the seas and were grown richer.
21 u(/steron xro/nw|—in course of time
22. *)a. te/ moi doxei=—and so it seems to me that it was because, etc.

23. ou) tosou=ton (o(/son prou/xwn) with a)/gwn, not so much because he was leader of ..., they being bound by their oaths to Tyndareus Tyndareus, Helen's supposed father, made her suitors swear to protect the rights of that one whom she should choose
26. Thuc. supports his view by reference to the origin of the kingship in Atreus' house.

27. *peloponnhsi/wn—masc., with oi(, those of the Pel. who have received the truest account by tradition. For the order of the gen. edd. compare c. 48. 4; 126. 11. It is supposed that Thuc. means the Argives, whose legends the Lesbian historian Hellanicus related. A fragment of H gives the story here referred to.
3. th\n e)pwnumi/an ... sxei=n—lit. secured the naming of the country after himself, though a stranger.
e)/phlun—there is no authority for the form e)phlu/ths in Attic. The passage in Xen. Oec cited in L. & S. is corrupt.
4. mei/zw—neut. plur.; cunenexqh=nai, ‘fell to the lot of,’ as often in Herod.; after Thuc. not found in Attic.
5. *eu)rusqe/ws me/n ktl.—the relationship of the persons mentioned is as follows:—ZZZ FAMILY TREE Pelops Perseus Sthenelus m. Nicippe Chrysippus Atreus Eurystheus Agamemnon

e)n th=| *)attikh=|—according to the story, Eurystheus was killed in the Megarid (Euripides represents him as taken prisoner) when at war with Demophon, king of Athens, from
whom he had demanded the surrender of the Heraclidae. The Megarid was then part of Attica.
7. kai\ e)pitre/yantos *eu). — there is parataxis here for *)atrei= de\ mhtro\s a)delfw=| o)/nti e)pitre/yantos.
10. *xrusi/ppou—Atreus and Thyestes conspired and murdered Ch. their half brother.
12. kai\ ... paralabei=n—co-ordinate with e)/ti mei/zw cunenexqh=nai ... *)atrei=.
13. kai\ a(/ma—the kai/ joins dokou=nta to boulome/nwn.
dunato/n—i.e. in point of wealth.
17. a(/—the wealth and power of the two families.

18. kai\ nautikw=|—the MSS give kai\ nautikw=| te, and two explanations are suggested: (1) te = too, Shilleto; and (2) te = and, while kai/ emphasises nautikw=|. thuc. 6.44 kai\ pro/s te tou\s *(phgi/nous, 8.68. 2 kai\ au)to/s te, 8.76. 5 kai\ e(autou/s te give rise to a similar question. The use of te is supported by examples in Herod. and tragedy; but the MS. variants and certain examples of corruption in the case of te are so numerous that it is very doubtful if the passages can be relied on. On the whole kai\ ... de/ = and moreover is more probable.
19. i)sxu/sas—ingressive.
20. ou) ... to\ ple/on h)/=h(=sson h)/.
xa/riti ... fo/bw| — for the contrast cf. Dem. 20.16 mei/zwn o( tou= me/llontos fo/bos th=s parou/shs xa/ritos, but there it is the fear and good-will felt; here it is the feelings inspired.

21. fai/netai ga/r—the passages referred to are Il. 2.576 tw=n e(kato\n new=n h)=rxe krei/wn *)agame/mnwn, and 2.612-613 au)to\s ga/r sfin dw=ken a)/nac a/ndrw=n *)agame/mnwn
nh=as, and so on.
23. w(s ... tou=to—Shilleto refers to Plat. Theaet. 193 D o(\ e)n toi=s pro/sqen ou(/tws e)/legon for a similar redundancy.
tw|—in any one's opinion. To tekmhriw=sai supply tou=to: it is only with ref. to the details that Thuc. suggests a doubt.

24. e)n tou= skh/ptrou th=| parado/sei—in the passage where the sceptre of Agamemnon is said to have been transmitted through his family; Il. 2.101-108. For this method of referring to passages in times before the division into books, etc. was made cf. c. 10. 4; Mark 12.26 e)pi\ th=s ba/tou; Ep. Rom. 11.2.

26. ou)k a)\n ... e)kra/tei—he would not have been ruler (as
he was). Classen's version, ‘he would not be (in the Iliad) ruler,’ is less likely.
27. ou)x a)\n ei)=en— MT 238.
2. kai\ tau/th| th=| stratei/a|—i.e. this expedition itself was not on a very large scale. All the more insignificant must have been those undertakings that preceded it.

4. o(/ti me/n—lit. that M. was a small place, or if any of the towns of those days seems now insignificant—(this) could not be considered a valid argument for refusing to believe that, etc. (1) The clauses introduced by o(/ti and ei) form the object to xrw/menos. (2) The me/n is not regularly answered, but is resumed in ou)k ou)=n a)pistei=n xrh/ (10.3) after a long parenthesis. (3) h)=n may mean was before its destruction, which is said by later writers to have occurred in 468 B.C. (there is no sufficient ground for doubting the statement). This is supported by nu=n dokei= which refers to towns still in existence. Or it may be ‘was in heroic times,’ and this is supported by to/te. But, whichever be meant, the argument is not affected. The simple explanation of the insignificance of Mycenae—now of prime importance to the archaeologist—is that the only part that could be called ‘city’ was the acropolis, and that was occupied by the castle of the chief. The rest of the settlement consisted of the villages of the clans; and there is no sign that in historic times the villages ever gave way to a city. Thuc. represents the fact correctly.
9. lo/gos kate/xei—fama obtinet; tradition affirms.

*lakedaimoni/wn ga/r—there were no signs of magnificence about Sparta until after the triumphs of Lysander. Even then, its appearance, remote from the world and unfortified, must have been comparatively insignificant. It does not seem clear that Thuc. wrote this passage before 404 B.C.
11. kataskeuh=s —k. includes everything that makes a place habitable and usable. Here ‘buildings.’
13. pro/s—in comparison with.

14. tw=n pe/nte ta\s du/o m.—two-fifths. (‘Two of the five divisions’ is, as Mr. Forbes remarks, wrong.) Of course Messenia is included in Laconia. Notice the way in which fractions are expressed. The gen. is omitted when the denominator is one higher than the numerator—as ta\ tri/a me/rh = 3/4.

15. th=s cumpa/shs—roughly speaking. In 2.9 Thuc.
expressly notes that Argos was not under the leadership of Sparta. But the omission here is of no importance, because we do not want an exact statement, but a general account of the power of Sparta.
16. tw=n e)/cw c.—their allies beyond P., who are many.

17. po/lews—for th=s po/lews, since the city was not compactly built. For the omission of art. Steup compares 4.18.3 and 8.95. 2. (Mr. Forbes's rendering ‘when a city is not built continuously’ is disproved by the fact that h( du/namis *lakedaimoni/wn—and not the power of any city—must be supplied to fai/noit' a)/n. Herbst's view that po/lews is predicative—since it has not been brought together into a compact city—is inconsistent with *lakedaimoni/wn h( po/lis above.)
18. kataskeuai=s—the plur. in concrete sense, as in 2.65. 2.
21. diplasi/an ... h)/—these compounds are constructed as comparatives. pollapla/sioi tw=n e)nanti/wn 4. 94; pollapla/sioi h)\ h)=lqon 127; diplasia dou=nai h)\ a)/llw| tini/ Lysias 19.52.
22. ei)ka/zesqai depends on oi)=mai.

a)po\ th=s f. o)/yews—not ‘from the notable or striking appearance’ (Forbes), but ‘from the mere (external) appearance.’ fanero/s is, as usual, what is seen, and o)/yis is the appearance in contrast with the reality, as in 6.31 th=| o)/yei a)neqa/rsoun (where my rendering ‘by the sight’ is also wrong).
26. megi/sthn me\n gene/sqai — ‘proved, it is true.’
de/—and yet. For tw=n pro\ au)th=s cf. 1. 1.
leipome/nhn with gen. as 6.72 ou)deno\s leipo/menos.

1. h(/n—rel. to stratei/an. According to the regular principle in Greek, the following clause, to which the nom. is supplied from h(/n, is without the rel. In the second clause the rel. is often replaced by the required case of au)to/s or ou(=tos—2.4. 5, o(\ h)=n tou= tei/xous kai\ ai( qu/rai a)newgme/nai e)/tuxon au)tou=. 7.29. 5 o(/per me/giston h)=n kai\ a)/rti e)/tuxon oi( pai=des e)selhluqo/tes. It is the repetition of the rel. that is unusual, as in 6.4. 3 to\ xwri/on ou(= nu=n h( po/lis e)sti\ kai\ o(\ prw=ton e)teixi/sqh. If, however, the first clause is neg. and the second pos., the rel. must be repeated, as in 2.43. 2 ou)k e)n w(=| kei=ntai ma=llon, a)ll' e)n w(=| h( do/ca kataleipetai. The same omission or substitution is frequent in Lat., as Liv. xxiii.8 cum quo steterat nec cum patria majestas sententia deputerat. In Engl. cf. Whom though to know be life, and joy to make mention of His name. Hooker.Eccles. Pol.
we treated her with great respect, which she recerved as customary, and was neither elated by it, nor confused. Johnson.Tour in Heb. To whom she seemed to listen, but did not hear them. Macaulay.Warren Hastings
e)pi\ to\ mei=zon kosmh=sai—exaggerate by using his fancy.
3. e)ndeeste/ra—comparatively insignificant.

pepoi/hke ga/r—out of a fleet of 1200 ships the poet has described those of the B. as carrying 120 men,e)n de\ e(ka/sth|
kou=roi *boiwtw=n e(kato\n kai\ ei)/kosi bai=non Il 2. 510-511 and those of Ph. as carrying 50,e)re/tai d' e)n e\ka/sth| penth/kont
e)mbe/basan, to/cwn eu)= ei)do/tes i)=fi ma/xesqai Hom. Il. 2.719-720 specifying the largest and the smallest a)ndrw=n is gen. of measure, as in tei=xos e(pta\ stadi/wn, almost confined to expressions of magnitude. The absence of a second art. with e)laxi/stas is interesting: Shilleto rightly compares nika=| d' o( prw=tos kai\ teleutai=os dramw/n Aesch. Ag. 314, where the reference is to a team, of which every member wins; just as here the two things combined are items of one fleet. As to the numbers, in Thuc.'s time the average complement of a trireme was 200. Therefore a fleet of 1200 would require 240,000 men: but the rationalistic calculation of Thuc gives about 103,000 for the Trojan War. Of course 103,000 is a far larger number than was sent out by any one state in the time of Thuc. The number of men who sailed for Sicily in 415 B C. may be roughly set down as 36,000. But 10.5 shows that Thuc. thinks of the combined forces of all Greek states, and the forces in the field during the Peloponnesian War would exceed his calculation for the Trojan War. (It seems, nevertheless, that Thuc. has not made out a very satisfactory case: tw=n nu=n in 10.3 should have been qualified.)
7. a)/llwn depends on mege/qous.
8. au)tere/tai— the fighting men served also as rowers. This was quite unusual in Thuc.'s day. See Il. 719 quoted above.
9. e)n—as e)n ... parado/sei c. 9. 4, and e)n new=n katalo/gw| above.
11. peri/news—the only passengers would be the kings and those immediately under them.
13. me/llontas ... e)/xontas—though these agree with peri/news, they apply in sense equally to all the Greeks. We should expect gen. abs.
14. meta\ skeuw=n—the want of space is what Thuc. alludes to. The room not taken up by the rowers would be filled with materials.

15. kata/farkta—i.e. the boats had no gangways projecting along them. These gangways (pa/rodoi) were used only in ships with a deep draught, and Thuc means that, as there were none in ‘Homeric’ ships, those ships can have had only a small draught, and therefore there was not much room in them. At intervals along the pa/rodoi were upright posts, and the open spaces between could be closed with curtains (pararru/mata) in battle or rough weather, and thus served in a trireme to protect the bodies of the thranitae (top set of rowers). The word is generally explained ‘decked’, but so far as one can judge, the only connexion between kata/strwma, the deck from end to end, and kata/farktos is that only ships that were kata/farktoi had katastrw/mata. The Homeric ships, it is true, had no katastrw/mata, but this is not the point here.
16. lh|stikw/teron—more like pirate craft than warships.
17. pro/s—as compared with. skopou=nti is dat. of the person judging, a frequent use of a partic.; cf. c. 21. 2
19. w(s—considering that.
21. ai)/tion—this predicate, so often in neut. sing. whatever be gender and number of the subject, is practically a noun.
23. te—answered by e)peidh\ de/, as e.g. in 6.83. 1; 7. 81; and c. 25. 3.
24. o(/son—only so large as.
au)to/qen with bioteu/sein, support itself in the (enemy's) country.
25. a)fiko/menoi—on their arrival, i.e. immediately after they landed. (This passage, from this word to the end of 11.2, is much disputed.)

26. ma/xh| e)kra/thsan—the conjecture e)krath/qhsan reduces the words toi=s ai)ei\ ... o)/ntes below to absurdity; and kratou=ntes would have to be changed to krath/santes. The Greeks were able to raise a rampart because they had won a victory.

to\ ga/r—for otherwise. This rampart is not that referred to in Il. vii. 336 and 433 as built in the tenth year by the counsel of Nestor, but one built immediately after the arrival of the Greeks, though this does not necessitate inserting eu)qu/s after a)/n with Dittrich. Similarly the gewrgi/a th=s *xersonh/sou below is not heard of in the Il. Thuc. doubtless got these details from a poem that related the earlier events of the war. Cf. the Schol. here: e)/ruma le/gei nu=n ou)x o(/per e)n th=| h/ le/gei *(/omhros gene/sqai, a)lla\ pro/teron mikro/teron dia\ ta\s tw=n barba/rwn e)pidroma/s. (Strabo quotes the opinion of Aristotle
that the tei=xos of Il. 7, which was so promptly destroyed by Poseidon, was in reality never built. It seems impossible that Thuc. can have had that tei=xos in mind)

27. fai/nontai de/ — this is de/ in apodosis, and it is here apparently suggested by the contrast set up by the parenthesis: though they fortified a camp, they did not employ their whole force. This de/ generally follows a parenthesis; but not in 2.65. 1 e)peidh\ o( po/lemos kate/sth, o( de\ fai/netai kai\ e)n tou/tw| prognou\s th\n du/namin
28. e)ntau=qa—before Troy; and consequently the Trojans held out.
2. au)tw=n—of their own accord.
ta\ de/ka e)/th—those ten years.
3. bi/a|—in the field. They were not penned up in the city.
u(poleipome/nois—imperf., who at any given time were left behind.

7. r(a|di/ws a)\n ma/xh| ... *troi/an ei(=lon — does this passage refer to ‘the two natural stages of the expedition’— battle followed by siege, or two alternative means of taking Troy,—either by pitched battle outside the gates, or by siege? Those who adopt the first, either (a) bracket the first ei(=lon with Kruger as spurious, and explain the d' after poliorki/a| as (a violent) apodotic de/, or, with Kruger bracket it; or else (b) make the first ei(=lon mean, not ‘capture (Troy),’ but, with Herbst, ‘defeat (the Trojans).’ Those who adopt the second with Bauer, make ma/xh| kratou=ntes = ‘by superiority in the field,’ and not ‘being as they were superior in the field’; and poliorki/a| proskaqezo/menoi = ‘by a regular siege,’ instead of ‘by persisting in a siege.’ But the difficulties involved in this are insuperable; for—apart from the extraordinary way in which the supposed alternative methods are expressed, and joined by de/ instead of h)/—the sense obtained, though at first sight attractive, makes periousi/an e)/xontes trofh=s and cunexw=s to\n po/lemon die/feron pointless in so far as the first method— superiority in the field + assault—is concerned; it necessitates forcing the meaning by an immediate assault (kata\ kra/tos) into ma/xh| kratou=ntes, and thus making this wholly distinct from ma/xh| e)kra/thsan in 11.1; and it strains no less the meaning of poliorki/a| proskaqezo/menoi. We therefore prefer the
first plan, but slightly modified; if the first ei(=lon is genuine, it is probably a mere anticipation of the second. Trans. If they had ... carried on the war persistently, they would easily have continued superior in the field and have taken the city, seeing that ... : if, then, they had persisted in a siege, they would have taken Troy.
proskaqezo/menoi governs poliorki/a|.
11. a)lla/—in contrast with periousi/an ei) h)=lqon e)/xontes trofh=s.
tou/twn—i.e. tw=n *trwikw=n.
geno/mena—though it proved.

15. katesxhko/tos—attributive. When an attributive partic. is itself further defined—dia\ tou\s poihta\s katesxhko/tos—it is frequently placed outside the art. This idiom is by no means confined to Thuc.
16 metani/stato — Greece (i.e. the Greeks) was still occupied with migration and settlement, so that the country did not quiet down (ingressive) and so increase.

*(ella/s here is used as in c. 6, for the Greek nation—h( *(e. e)sidhrofo/rei—and this explains (a) the use of metani/stato, (b) the accus. h(suxa/sasan, for which, as it refers to the subject of the main verb, h(suxa/sasa would be expected. *(ella/s takes a slightly different meaning after the w(/ste. A similar change of meaning may be detected in 7.34. 6 naumaxh/santes de\ a)nti/pala kai\ w(s au)tou\s e(kate/rous a)ciou=n nika=n, where the w(s-clause is general in sense, the way in which both sides lay claim to victory.
17. w(/ste mh\ h(. au)chqh=nai—the mh/ belongs to both partic. and infin., and w(/ste ... au)chqh=nai expresses a)xrhmati/a.
20. e)neo/xmwse = enewte/rise In sense this is pluperf. The verb occurs in Herod, but only here in Attic. Thuc. thought of the fate of Agamemnon, Teucer, and other heroes.

kai\ sta/seis—two things are not clear, (1) whether the disturbances alluded to are intended to be connected with the return from Troy, or merely to be an explanation of w(/ste mh\ h(suxa/sasan au).; (2) how *boiwtoi/ te ga/r is connected with what precedes. The passage is commonly referred to as though ga/r introduced an illustration of the sta/seis, but Steup (who thinks ga/r spurious) rightly points out that we hear nothing of sta/sis in the matter of the migrations referred to. If ga/r is retained, we must assume that the migrations are introduced as an illustration of the general unrest that continued; i e. the ga/r refers rather to 12.1 than to the immediately preceding sentence.
21. w(s e)pi\ polu/—for the most part, ‘in most cases.’
a)f' w(=n—as the result of which, referring to sta/seis.

22. ta\s po/leis—prob. the article is distributive=cities in each instance (Others, ‘the well-known cities’: but this is rightly objected to by several edd as a strange assumption of knowledge and as clashing awkwardly with e)n tai=s po/lesin)

23. oi( nu=n—meaning not that the Boeotians had changed their name, but the Boeotians ‘as we know them now,’ i.e. as inhabiting all Boeotia, instead of dwelling partly in Thessaly and partly in Boeotia.
e(chkostw=| e)/tei—the instances seem to be chosen in order to show that disturbances continued for a long period after the war.
meta\ *)ili/ou a(/lwsin—the art. replaced by a gen., as in dia\ xro/nou plh=qos c. 1. 2.
26. a)podasmo/s—i.e. a part that had voluntarily separated from the main body, not a)na/stantes, like the rest. The word only here in Attic; but cf. *fwke/es a)poda/smioi Hdt. 1.146.1.
27. a)f' w(=n—the plur. kata\ su/nesin. The ref. is to Il. 2.494, where the Boeotians, however, possess the chief cities of Boeotia.
2. e)/sxon—cf. sxei=n, c. 9. 2.
3 h(suxa/sasa bebai/ws—gaining unbroken rest and no longer subject to violent changes. Notice the ingressive aor. and imperf. combined.
5. *)/iwnas—the Ionian cities of Asia Minor. nhsiwtw=n—the Cyclades; cf. c. 4. Isocr. Panath. 43.

6. *)itali/as—i.e. the modern Calabria, the peninsula reaching to the Lius on W. and to Metapontum on E. The chief Peloponnesian founders of Sicilian and Italian cities were the Corinthians who founded Syracuse, and through Syracuse, Camarina [Acrae and Casmenae], the Megarians who founded the Hyblaean Megara, and through Megara, Selinus: the Achaeans who founded Sybaris and Croton, some Lacedaemonians who founded Tarentum. Forbes. But (1) Megara is not part of the Peloponnese (2.9), see next note; (2) it is not clear that Tarentum is reckoned in Italy.

8. e)/stin a(\ xwri/a—it is supposed that the colonies of Corinth in the W., Corcyra, Leucas, Ambracia, etc. are referred
to. If so (1) to\ plei=ston above is an exaggeration; (2) *(ella/s is here used for all the country ultimately inhabited by Greeks—as in Thuc.'s time: but *(ella/s was not so used above; (3) the vagueness of the reference to these colonies is strange. Steup gets over all these difficulties by taking e)/stin a(\ xwri/a as nom., so that the Megarian (see last note), Locrian and Chalcidian colonies would be included. This is tempting, and for the use of xwri/a we might compare ta\ tre/fonta h(ma=s xwri/a th=s *)itali/as, o(rw=nta e)n w(=| e)smen 7.14. But it must be confessed that (1) e)/stin a(/ looks like an antithesis to to\ plei=ston: (2) pa/nta de\ tau=ta appears to refer to e)/stin a(\ xwri/a as well as to the colonies mentioned before. Perhaps Thuc. writes somewhat vaguely here.
11. e)/ti ... h)\ pro/teron—referring to c. 8. 3.
12. ta\ polla/—in most cases.

13. tw=n proso/dwn m. gignome/nwn—this goes closely with kaqi/stanto, tyrannies were established where the revenues (of the government) increased. But dunatwte/ras ... poioume/nhs is a general statement with regard to Greece, and qualifies the whole sentence down to a)ntei/xonto. Thuc. means that a tyranny was generally established in a city enjoying a large revenue, which one man, whether a member of the governing class or not, succeeded in getting into his hands as the result of political agitation.
14. pro/teron de/—not necessarily immediately before, for in most cases oligarchy preceded tyranny, but in earlier days where one man ruled, his power was limited.

e)pi\ r(htoi=s ge/rasi—with (under the condition of) fixed prerogatives, viz. as priest, judge and leader (Arist. Pol. 3.14, 12). The purpose of this parenthesis is to point out that the rule of a single man, though it was known before the age of the tyrants, had been of a wholly different character. The age of the tyrants synchronises with an advance in Greece; yet the deeds even of the tyrants were relatively insignificant. As to tyranny, Aristotle agrees with Thuc.: e)pei\ de\ xei)rous geno/menoi e)xrhmati/zonto a)po\ tw=n koinw=n, e)nteu=qe/n poqen eu)/logon gene/sqai ta\s o)ligarxi/as ... e)k de\ tou/twn prw=ton ei)s turanni/das mete/balon.
17. e)ggu/tata—superlative of e)ggu/s. Cf. prope and propius.
18. metaxeiri/sai—Thuc., like Herod., uses the act. of this word, whereas other authors use mid.
19. kai\ ... nauphghqh=nai —kai/ = and in fact, the building of a trireme marking a climax in naval affairs (ta\ peri\ ta\s nau=s).

th=s *(ella/dos goes with prw=ton: cf. 2.18 a)fi/keto th=s *)attikh=s e)s *oi)no/hn prw=ton. Hdt. 1.163 prw/th| de\ *fwkai/h| *)iwnihs epexei/rhse.—The tetrh/rhs made its appearance in the second half of the fourth cent., and was the normal type of ship in the hellenistic period. It is not likely that it had four banks of oars.
22. nau=s—whether these were triremes or not does not appear.
23. tou=de tou= pole/mou—the dates given are circ. 704 and 664 B.C. (or, if the Archidamian War is meant, see Introd. p. xxvi, circ. 721 and 681 B.C.).
24. o(/te—since.
*sami/ois h)=lqe—the dat, after (simple) verbs of motion is common in tragedy, but does not occur in Attic prose outside Thuc.; cp. c. 27. 1; 61. 1; 107. 7.
25. gi/gnetai—turns out to be.

26. kai\ tau/th|—lit. this too reckons 260 years. The kai/ brings the battle into relation with the event above. (Thuc. seems to be maintaining the priority of Corinth against some other claimant.) The tau/th| is possessive dat, as Herod. 2.33 *(hrakle/i( o(/sa fasi\ ei(=nai e)/tea e)s *)/amasin.
1. th\n po/lin—their city.
2. ai)ei\ dh/ pote—as dh/ pote means in the past (frequent in tragedy), so ai)ei\ dh/ pote = always in the past, i.e. ‘from the earliest times.’

3. tw=n *(ellh/nwn ... e)pimisgo/ntwn—two points are made: (1) the early commerce of the Greeks was carried on mainly by land, (2) the Isthmus was on the high-road between oi( e)nto/s and oi( e)/cw *p. The sentence would be much clearer with a partic. like poreuome/nwn, as proposed by Steup, after *(ellh/nwn, so that te would mean and.
7. a)fneio/n—we have only one instance, Il. 2.570.
9. ma=llon e)/plw|zon—cf. c. 8. 2.

ta\s nau=s—the ships referred to in 13.2. These enabled Greece to extinguish piracy, and thus to further her commerce; and the outcome of that, it is implied, was the formation of a considerable fleet.

11. a)mfo/tera with pare/xontes, in both ways, i.e. as the
context shows, by sea and land. a)mfo/tera and kat' a)mfo/tera do not of themselves mean on both elements, but show the same accus. as tou=ton to\n tro/pon, and kata\ pollou\s tro/pous. It is the context that gives the special meaning.
e)/sxon—ingressive.
12. *)/iwsin — those of Asia Minor, among whom the Phocaeans and Samos are specially mentioned.
16. *ku/rw| polemou=ntes—they were ultimately reduced by Harpagus. Cf. c. 16.
17. e)pi\ *kambu/sou—C. reigned 529-521 B.C Polycrates ruled 532-521 B.C. According to Herod. 3.33, Samos was poli/wn pase/wn prw/th *(ellhni/dwn kai\ barba/rwn in the time of Polycrates.

19. *(phnei/an e(lw/n—Herod. 3.33 assigns far more imposing achievements to Polycrates: cf. ib. 122 th=s de\ a)nqrwpi/nhs (i.e. not ‘heroic,’ like Minos) legome/nhs geneh=s *polukra/ths prw=tos, e)lpi/das polla\s e)/xwn *)iwni/hs te kai\ nh/swn a)/rcein. This gift was made to the Delian Apollo as the Ionian deity.

21. *massali/an oi)ki/zontes—at the time when they founded Massilia. Hdt. 1.166 gives an account of a victory of the Etruscans and Carthaginians about 546 B.C., the time of which Thuc. is here speaking. But Eusebius and others placed the foundation of Marseilles 600 B.C.: there is plainly a diserepancy in the dates given for its foundation. (Classen in the 3rd ed. took e)ni/kwn to mean gained victories, and referred them to 600 B.C.; but Thuc. is plainly referring to circ. 546 B.C. See Steup's appendix.)
22. tau=ta ga/r—these, in fact, were the strongest navies, i.e. the strongest possessed by Iomans (cf. 14.6).
23. fai/netai with xrw/mena and e)chrtume/na: ‘though these fleets were built ... we find’ etc.

25. penthkonto/rois—Gardner and Jevons, p. 652. It is plain from Herod. 1. 163 that penteconters counted as nh=es makrai/, and stand in contrast to nh=es stroggu/lai, merchant-ships (cf. Thuc. 2.97. 1). Therefore the ploi=a makra/ are doubtless long ships of larger and smaller size than penteconters. To their resemblance in size to merchant - ships the word ploi=a seems to point.
26. e)kei=na—those existing in the time of the Trojan War.
27. tou= *darei/ou qana/tou—485 B.C. e)basi/leuse, ‘reigned,’ rather than ‘became king.’
29. peri/ te *sikeli/an —for the vague use of peri/ cf. Isocr. v. 111 ei=xe megi/sthn du/namin tw=n peri\ th\n *)asi/an. This is the age of the great Sicilian tyrants—Thero, Gelo, Hiero.
30 e)s plh=qos e)ge/nonto—reached a considerable number; probably the lit. sense is ‘came to.’
3. ei)/ tines a)/lloi—sc. e)ke/kthnto nautika/.
4. braxe/a—sc. nautika/, small fleets. This sense of braxu/s is fiequent in Thuc.
5. ta\ polla/—the greater part of these consisted of.

o)ye/ te a)f' ou(=—sc h(=n, it was late when. For a)f ou(= we should expect o(/te. but instead of saying ‘already when they started to build, it was so late that they could not get a strong fleet before the invasion of Xeixes,’ he says ‘from the time that they started’ etc. The building of the ships took place in 483-82 B C., the archonship of Nicodemus, and the invasion in 480 B.C. Herod. 7.33 does not say that Them, looked forward to a Persian invasion when he advised the building of the ships. It is thought that Herod, wanted to belittle Them
9. e)nauma/xhsan—at Salamis
dia\ pa/shs—throughent, an adverbial expression like a)po\ th=s i)/shs c. 15; a)po\(th=s)prw/ths, etc. (This is better than supplying new/s)
10. katastrw/mata—the Homeric ship was covered only fore and aft, the part in which the men rowed being open. (Cf. on c. 10. 4.)
12. ta\ palaia/—i.e. the early fleets mentioned in c. 13. ta\ u(/steron geno/mena—i.e. those mentioned in c. 14.3.
14. ou)k e)laxi/sthn—considerable, in spite of smallness of the fleets.
au)toi=s —toi=s nautikoi=s.
xrhma/twn proso/dw|—see c. 13.5. The possession of a fleet enabled them still further to increase their trade.
16. ta\s nh/sous k.—began to or ‘endeavoured to reduce the islands.’ The enterprise of Athens and Corinth is alluded to, as in (e)kei=noi)o(/soi mh/.

18. o(/qen tis — ‘as the result of which any considerable force was brought together,’ or ‘from which any considerable power was gained.’ This seems to be the meaning, corresponding
to i)sxi\n de\ ktl. above. But paragi/gnomai in Thuc. of troops regularly means be assembled in the field, and with dat. ‘come to the support of’ To be added to is prosgi/gnomai. Hence many edd. render ‘in consequence of which any considerable force was collected.’ o(/qen is then strange.
cune/sth—frequently used in this connexion from Herod. downwards.
22. ou) ga\r cuneisth/kesan—they were not joined to the strongest states as subjects, nor yet did they of their own accord unite on an equal footing for a campaign.
25. kat' a)llh/lous—inter se.
w(s e(/kastoi—cf. c. 3.4. Strictly e)pole/moun is supplied with w(s, but the phrase practieally becomes a distributive nnmeral

27. *xalkide/wn kai\ *)eretriw=n — the date of this war, fought for the possession of the Lelantian plain, is unknown. Herod says that Samos helped Chalcis and Miletus helped Eretria, and of course both sides must have attracted many other allies. The ultimate cause of the war was commercial rivalry. (Busolt i. p. 313.)
1. kai\ to\ a)/llo *(e—the rest of the Greeks also took sides as allies of the one or the other.
2. e)pege/neto—often of unfavourable occurrences, especially of anything sudden and unexpected, such as natural phenomena.
3. a)/lloqi—in different parts.
mh/—according to the constr, with verbs of hindrance (M.T. 749, 807), though kwlu/w generally has the simple infin.

4. kai/—and in particular.—*)/iwsi is governed both by proxwrhsa/ntwn and by e\pestra/teuse There is an anacoluthon at e)pestru/teuse, for strictly e\pege/neto should govern *)/iwsi with an abstract noun parallel to kwlu/mata for its subject.

6. basilei/a—MSS. authority is altogether in favour of this against e)cousi/a, and e)cousi/a does not seem to occur before Aristotle in this sense. Stahl thinks basilei/a is a gloss on e)cousi/a. But it is possible that e)cousi/a itself is a gloss. The matter is complicated by the fact that both basilei/a and e)cousi/a have a double sense (e)cousi/a, power to do a thing, a ‘power’; cf. basilei/a to\ a)ci/wma kai\ to\ e)/qnos basileuo/menon, Suidas). Of course here the sense is concrete.
*kroi=son—the destruction of the Lydian monarchy was 546 B.C., Herod 1.87 etc.
o(/sa—a part. of ei)mi/ is constantly omitted after o(/sos.

e)nto\s *(/aluos potamou= —e)nto/s from the Greek point of view. When potamo/s is added the art. is regularly inserted before the name of a river in Attic. But Herod. does not use the art., and Thuc. omits it in six passages. The only other known exx. are Isocr. 7, 80 (also e)nto\s *(/aluos p.) and Xen. Anab. 4.7.18.

9. kai\ ta\s nh/sous—according to Herod. 1. 169, when the Ioman cities of the mainland submitted to Harpagus, the islands also gave in; but no doubt the submission of the islands was incomplete. Otherwise the rise of Polycrates would be unaccountable. Thuc. alludes to their reduction after Lade, 494 B.C.
10. tu/rannoi—see c. 13.1. The course of the argument was there broken by the reference to the fleets, which were first dealt with.
11. to\ e)f' e(autw=n—their own interests.
12. to\ sw=ma—with regard to their personal good and the increase of their own estate. sw=ma includes safety and enjoyment.

14. di' a)sfalei/as ... ma/lista=o(/son e)du/nanto a)sfale/stata. Had the utmost regard for security in the administration of their cities, i.e. ‘pursued a cautious policy’ by avoiding great enterprises. di a)sfalei/as is an adverbial phrase, like those with which e)/xein is usually found, as di' e)pimelei/as, di' h(suxi/as, dia\ fulakh=s.
15. a)p' au)tw=n—on their part.
16. ei) mh\ ei)/ ti —ei) mh\ ei), nisi si, only here in Thuc. (see erit. note). ei) mh/ becomes an adverb. M.T. 476, 4.

17. oi( ga/r—for the use of ga/r cf. c. 14. 1. ‘The Sicilian tyrants in fact attained to the greatest power,’ i.e. greater power than any other of the tyrants (and they fought against their neighbours). The sense of plei=ston here is that of c. 1.2 e)pi\ plei=ston a)nqrw/pwn. There is no need for excision.
18. ou(/tw pantaxo/qen—summing up the whole from c. 13.
19. katei/xeto—was held in check, ‘constrained.’ Cf. c. 16; but the second clause, kata\ po/leis te shows that katei/xeto is felt here not as a verb of prevention, but of compulsion.
22. *)aqhnai/wn—the overthrow of Hippias, 510 B.C.
23. oi( e)k th=s—the prep. by attraction to katelu/qhsan.
e)pi\ polu\ ktl.—lit. which over a large area had been under tyrants even before Athens. The earliest instance was at Sicyon, where Orthagoras became tyrant circ. 670 B.C.

24. oi( plei=stoi ... *sikeli/a|—limiting apposition to oi( tu/rannoi, kai\ ... *sikeli/a| explaining plei=stoi, most of them, the last in fact except those in Sicily. In Syracuse the tyrants lasted till 466 B.C., when Thrasybulus was expelled.

25. u(po\ *aakedaimoni/wn—the Spartans were called misotu/rannoi. Cf. Aristotle, Pol. v. 10 *aak. plei/stas kate/lusan turanni/das. But their traditional policy of tyrant-breaking was dropped in the fourth cent., when au)tonomi/a became their watehword. Thus in 371 B.C. an orator is represented by Xen. as taunting the Spartans with preferring tyranny to free institutions. Alcibiades in his speech at Sparta (6.89—winter of 415-4 B.C.) makes a point out of this tradition.
27. th\n kti/sin—strictly speaking the Dorians did not found Sparta: it existed before the invasion; but there is no difficulty in speaking of the second founders thus.

1. w(=n i)/smen=e)kei/nwn ou(\s i)/smen. The sta/sis lasted longer at Sparta than elsewhere: cf. Herod. i 65, the Spartans before Lycurgus kakonomw/tatoi h)=san sxedo\n pa/ntwn *(ellh/nwn kata/ te sfe/as au)tou\s kai\ cei/noisi a)pro/smiktoi. In spite of this, they were the earliest to obtain good laws—mete/balon e)s eu)nomi/hn (Herod. l.c.)=hu)nomh/qh.
4. tetrako/sia—this gives a later date than 884 B.C. which other authorities assign to Lycurgus.
7. duna/menoi=dunatoi\ o)/ntes, see L. & S.
8. meta\ de/—the main sentence is resumed after the parenthesis. Cf. the use of de/(d' ou)=n) in c. 11. 1; ou)=n in 7.42. 3; de/ is frequent. So autem, sed, igitur.

th\n kata/lusin e)k th=s *(ella/dos—the art. is not repeated with a verbal substantive. The words necessary to complete its sense generally follow, but sometimes precede it, as in 2.18. 3 kata\ th\n a)/llhn porei/an h( sxolaio/ths. In the latter case, the prepositional phrase is connected with the verb of the sentence (cf. 2.7. 2; 38. 1) as well as with the verbal substantive.
10. kai\ h( e)n *maraqw=ni ma/xh—i.e. now begins the modern period, ta\ *mhdika/.
12. tw=| m. sto/lw|—the great armada.
14. e)pikremasqe/ntos—impending, as ii. 53. 4; 3.40. 7.
16. tw=n cumpolemhsa/ntwn—this and h(gh/santo are ingressive; ‘assumed the leadership of those who entered on the war as allies.’ prou/xontes—causal.

19. kai\ a)naskeuasa/menoi ... e)sba/ntes ... e)ge/nonto=a(nalabo/ntes ta\ skeu/h e)se/bhsan kai\ e)ge/nonto. Observe the historical importance of nautikoi\ e)ge/nonto, which is emphasised hy its connexion with h(gh/santo tw=n *(ellh/nwn.

20. a)pwsa/menoi ... diekri/qhsan—the subject modified in the course of the sentence from ‘the confederates’ to the confederates exclusive of Athens and Sparta, and those Asiatic cities and islands that revolted from Persia after Salamis.

24. tau=ta—Athens and Sparta. diefa/nh—it had become clear that, denoting the singling out of these two from among the rest. The aor. in sense of plup. appears in (1) sentences introduced by ‘when,’ ‘since,’ ‘until’ regularly; (2) in rel. and other subord. sentences often, (3) in principal sentences oceasionally.
26. o(maixmi/a—used hy Herod. and late writers; the adj. o(/maixmos in iii. 58. 4.
27. dienexqe/ntes—open war in 457 B.C., dispute in 461 B.C. See c. 102. e)pole/mhsan—till the thirty years' truce 445 B.C. See c. 107.
4. h)/dh e)xw/roun—now regularly joined these states—i e. entered the alliance of Athens or Sparta. Contrast the earlier state of affairs, c. 15. 2 ou) ga\r cuneisth/kesan ktl,

5. ta\ me\n spendo/menoi—this should mean now making truces; but we certainly expect ‘being now at peace.’ In the previous sentences Thuc. has described the state of affairs (a) from the battle of Salamis to 457 B.C., (b) from 457 onwards. Now during period (a) Athens and Sparta were at peace; but from 466 disputes began between Athens and her allies. During period (b) Athens and Sparta might be said to be ‘making truces’ (450, 445 B C.) or making war. The w(/ste therefore seems to refer to what happened from 466 onwards; but a)po\ tw=n *mhdikw=n—the war with Xerxes to the battle of Plataea (or Mycale) does not agree with this. There is a want of precision in the passage.

7. eu)= pareskeua/santo ta\ pole/mia—ef. Arist. Ath. Pol. 23 of the Athenians, sune/bh ta\ ei\s to\n po/lemon a)skh=sai. ta\ pole/mia in the sense of ta\ polemika/ is found in Herod. and Hippocrates; Xen. Anab. 1.6.1; Arist. Ath. Pol. c. 3 and 23.
11. h(gou=nto—sc au)tw=n.

kat' o)ligarxi/an ktl.—i.e. qerapeu/ontes de\ o(/pws politeu/sousi kat'-o)ligarxi/an(kata/ of mannei), e)pithdei/ws sfi/sin au)toi=s mo/non (‘in their, the Lacedaemonian, interests alone’). Cf. Arist. Pol. 4.11 tw=n e(n h)gemoni/a| genome/nwn th=s *(ella/dos ... oi( me\n dhmokrati/as kaqi/stasan, oi( d' o)ligarxi/as, ou) pro\s to\ tw=n po/lewn sumfe/ron skopou=ntes a)lla\ pro\s to\ sfe/teron au)tw=n.
13. nau=s te tw=n po/lewn—having gradually taken over (assumed possession of) the ships of the various cities. Cf. c. 99. 3.

16. kai\ e)ge/neto au)toi=s—two widely different views are taken of this passage according as au)toi=s means (a) ‘the Athenians’ only or (b) ‘the Athenians and Lacedaemonians.’ Omitting minor differences, we get (a) ‘and so her own resources for carrying on this war reached a greater strength than (what she had) when she stood at the height of her prosperity side by side with the undamaged forces of her confederates’; i.e. Athens had appropriated the forces of her confederates, as it were, and thus was stronger than when she was at the head of a body of independent allies. (b) The forces of Athens and Sparta separately were stronger than they had been (both together) during the period of the o(maixmi/a (Classen) or ‘stronger than the strongest power each separately had wielded with its still undamaged summaxi/a’ (Herbst). (a) accords with what Thuc afterwards says of the growth of Athenian power (cf. c. 118) By ta\ kra/tista he means the time before the reduction of Naxos (466 B.C.). cummaxi/a a)kraifnh/s is in contrast with the appropriation of ships and imposition of tribute. (b) with Classen's rendering is too strong; with Herbst, we certainly hardly feel the statement, as far as it refers to Sparta, consistent with the reference to her policy made above.

20. ta\ palaia/—this, as Herbst and Steup point out, refers only to the time before the expulsion of the tyrants—see note on c. 1.2 ta\ ga\r pro\ au)tw=n ktl. The events of the Persian wars were fully known, and in c. 18. 1 Thuc. comes to them as to modern events. Therefore we must suppose cc. 18 and 19 to form a long parenthesis—see the analysis of the prooi/mion, Intr III. note.
toiau=ta—i.e. comparatively insignificant, ou) mega/la.

xalepa\ o)/nta—though it is difficult to trust every piece of evidence as put forward in the traditions about them. This is the personal construction for xalepo\n o)\n panti\ e(ch=s t. p. The clause is amplified in what follows, and does not refer to what has preceded. pa=n e(ch=s=‘every one without exception.’
22. a)koa/s—accounts.

24. sfi/sin—the indirect reflexive, which, as regularly used in subord. sentences, refers to subject of principal sentence. But later writers generally use e(autou/s etc. as both indirect and direct reflex.
o(moi/ws—as events that did not occur in their own place.
25. gou=n—cf. c. 2.5. Here ‘for example’ (? and there too).

*(/ipparxon—there is a more detailed account of the matter in 6.54-59. Hdt. 5.55; Hdt. 6.123; Arist. Ath. Pol. c. 18. There are no discrepancies between this account and the statement of Herod. and Arist. (for the statement in the latter that Thessalus was half-brother of Hipparchus is not necessarily a contradiction of this); but there are several differences between the Aristotelian account and the longer account given in book vi.
1. u(potoph/sante/s ti—feeling some suspicion. (Some connect ti/ with memhnu=sqai.) u(potoph=sai used by Thuc. only in aor. inf. or partic.
2. e)kei/nh| th=| h(me/ra| kai\ p. with memhnu=sqai, on that great day at the very moment, before they were to take action.

3. e)k ... memhnu=sqai—the other places in Thuc. in which e:k practically=u(po/ are 2.49. 1; iii. 69. 1; v. 104; 6.36. 2. The use is Ionic, not found in Aristoph., and there are only doubtful traces of it in the orators.
5. pri\n cullhfqh=nai ... kinduneu=sai—wishing to do something before they were arrested (and) then to take their chance. pri\n c. goes with dra/sante/s ti, and kai/=‘on that condition.’

7. peri\ to\ *aewko/reion —e)n me/sw| tw=| *kerameikw=| (Harpocration), but inside the city. Meanwhile Hippias (according to 6.57) was marshalling the procession outside the gates. The Ath. Pol. however says that Hippias was awaiting the procession on the acropolis. The route of the procession was from the (outer) Ceramicus to the temple of Athcna Polias. As for the
Leocorion, the story was that the three daughters of King Leos were sacrificed to Pallas to avert famine from Athens. The chapel is connected with the worship of Apollo as god of purification.
9. polla\ de\ kai\ a)/lla—as regards; or (what comes to the same) oi)/ontai may be rendered ‘conceive.’
10. ou) xro/nw| a)mnhstou/mena—le grec renforce souvent une idée positive en la reprenant sous forme négative (Chambry). Cf. p. 112 1. 16.

11. w(/sper ktl.—Hdt. 6.57, if the kings are not present at a meeting of the Council, (keleu/ousi)tou\s ma/lista/ sfi tw=n gero/ntwn prosh/kontas e)/xein ta\ tw=n basile/wn ge/rea, du/o yh/fous tiqeme/nous, tri/thn de\ th\n e(wutw=n. It may be that Thuc. is referring to that passage, and took it to imply that each king had two votes (though it is doubtful whether Herod. meant that). In ix. 53 Herod. mentions the lo/xos *pitana/ths as present at Plataea. It can hardly be doubted that Thuc. consciously includes Herod. among oi( a)/lloi *(/ellhnes. See Jebb, The Speeches of Thuc., in Hellenica, p. 273.

12. mia=| yh/fw|—we expect the accus., as in Aesch. Eum. 738 yh=fon d' *)ore/sth| th/nd' e)gw\ prosqh/somai, but the sense is ‘give their opinion (sc. gnw/mhn) with one vote.’ (Eum. l.c. does not support the opinion of Classen and Steup that the use of the dat. is to be explained by the fact that the kings voted last.) The errors noted illustrate the difficulty of getting information about Spartan proceedings.

17. e)k ... tekmhri/wn with nomi/cwn. The object is (e)kei=na)a(\ dih=lqon, the pred. toiau=ta ma/lista(ei)=nai). The partic. nomi/zwn, pisteu/wn, h(ghsa/menos are co-ordinate; but they express not condition, but means: lit. However, it is by considering the proofs I have given and in the light of them thinking that ... that one will escape error, and not by preferring to follow the embellishments and exaggerations of poets or the attractive but untrustworthy compositions of prose writers ... but by coming to the conclusion. Edd. generally represent the participles as conditional, but mh/te ... mh/te would then be required. See M.T. 835

20. e)pi\ to/—so as to please the ear of the public rather than to arrive at the truth. The double compar. as regularly where two qualities in the same person or thing are contrasted: i)w\ strathgoi\ ple/ones h)\ belti/ones.
23. o)/nta—agreeing with the implied object of cune/qesan ta\ polla/ is in limiting apposition to this object, and au)tw=n depends on ta\ polla/.
24. a)pi/stws—so as to be incredible. This pregnant use of an adverb may often be noticed in the phrases with e)/xein, diakei=sqai, diatiqe/nai
e)pi\ to\ muqw=des e)knenikhko/ta—generally rendered ‘have won their way into the region of the fabulous’: but Croiset explains ‘in which the fabulous character has ended by prevailing.’
26. w(s palaia\ ei)=nai—for the restrictive infin. see M.T. 781; ‘sufficiently considering their antiquity.’ The ‘plainest indications’ are the tekmh/ria of 21.1.

27. kai\ o( po/lemos—Thuc. having ascertained, as clearly as is possible, the small importance of earlier undertakings, now returns to the Pel. War, which, to all who judge it in the light of the facts, will be found to have proved more important than they (ta\ palaia/).
28. e)n w)=|—while
3. dhlw/sei—with partic., as in 2.50 e)dh/lwse ... a)/llo ti o)/n. Cf. 5.9 dei/cw ou) paraine/sai oi(=o/s te w)/n. Cf. Jebb on Soph. Ant. 20.
5. kai\ o(/sa me/n—after his reference to the importance of the war, Thuc. goes on to explain the manner in which he has dealt with it. o(/sa=‘as regards all that.

lo/gw|—Steup is probably right in explaining this, not as merely pleonastic, but as a reference to the set speeches, as distinct from ‘words’ generally: hence=‘in debate.’ Note, however, the implied contrast between ta\ e)/rga tw=n lexqe/ntwn and ta\ e)/rga tw=n praxqe/ntwn, deeds of speech and of act.
6. e)n au)tw=|—i.e. e)n tw=| polemei=n.
7. xalepo/n—for the implied sense ‘impossible’ Steup compares c 20. 1; 7.87. 4
9. w(=n—rel. to tw=n lexqe/ntwn.
a)/lloqe/n poqen—from the various places where they happened to be

10. w(s d' a)\n e)do/koun ktl.—I have represented the various speakers as uttering the sentiments that seemed to me appropriate to the particular occasion, while I have kept as closely as possible to the general sense of what was really said: lit. as I believed that they would have best expressed what it
was necessary to say. a)/n and ma/lista belong to ei)pei=n ˙ e)xome/nw| ktl. to ei)/rhtai, to which e)moi/ is supplied. The order is thus awkward, but it is made easier by the preceding e)moi/. (The sense does not allow us to connect e)xome/nw| with e)do/koun)

11. ta\ de/onta—i.e. the best arguments that could be found to support the cu/mpasa gnw/mh of the speaker. (Jebb, Hellenica p. 275, thinks that Thuc. is tacitly contrasting this method with that of Herod., and, as it can scarcely be doubted that he does so in the passage that follows, this is probably true.)
14. ta\ d' e)/rga tw=n praxqe/ntwn—verbally this is opposed to th\n a)kri/beian tw=n lexqe/ntwn rather than to o(/sa lo/gw| ei)=pon.
16. h)ci/wsa—thought it my business.
ou)d' w(s e)moi\ e)do/kei—in accordance with my own whims.

17. oi(=s te au)to\s parh=n—i.e. (h)ci/wsa gra/fein e)kei=na)oi(=s: I described facts which I myself witnessed and (I described facts) after inquiring about each detail from others, thus e)pecelqw/n is parallel to oi(=s au)to\s parh=n, which, as Mr. Forbes says, is equivalent to au)to\s parageno/menos. (Another way is to make e)pecelqw/n govern oi)=s au)to\s parh=n, but this has the great disadvantage of making oi(=s au)to\s parh=n and para\ tw=n a)/llwn parallel phrases. See crit. note.)

18. o(/son dunato\n a)kribei/a|—for (tosou=ton)o(/son (accus. dunato\n(h)=n)a). Notice that a)kribei/a| here is subjective in sense, meaning the aecuracy of Thuc, not the accuracy of the facts, as in 22.1.
