21. e(kate/rwn—towards either side, objective gen. to eu)noi/as, as in 7.57. 10 *)aqhnai/wn eu/noi/a|. (Croiset connects e(kate/rwn tis, ex utrisque partibus quisque.)
w(s ... eu)noi/as h)\ mnh/mhs e)/xoi—for the gen., that of the sphere in which, depending on w(s, pw=s, pou=, poi=, and occasionally other advs. of manner, cf c. 36. 2. e)/xoi is iterative.

23 to\ mh\ muqw=des—the fact that he hears no legend in my history. mh/( is here subjective, referring to what the reader will feel (The edd., as frequently in Thuc., give various explanations of this mh/.)
au)tw=n—with to\ mh\ m.; cf. c. 1. 2.
24. a)terpe/steron—less attractive.

25. tw=n genome/nwn—this means the past so far as Thuc. records it, the period with which he deals; for Thuc. could
not suppose that his work would be useful as a record of all past history.
to\ safe/s—the truth, ‘the exact nature.’
26 tw=n mello/ntwn ktl.—of what is likely to be repeated at some future time with more or less exactness.
1. kri/nein—subject tou/tous. au)ta/ —my history, as au)tw=n above.
2. te—concluding, ‘and so.’
a)gw/nisma—the word means performance, ‘feat,’ ‘show piece,’ or ‘prize’; here of a prize composition.
e)s to\ paraxrh=ma a)kou/ein—for immediate hearing.

4. tw=n de\ pro/teron—it is by this time shown that ta\ palaia/ (cc. 2-17) were unimportant as compared with the Pel. War. But there remains the war against Xerxes (to\ *mhdiko/n, see c. 18. 2, the me/gas sto/los); and to that Thuc. now passes.

5. duoi=n naumaxi/ain kai\ pezomaxi/ain—which battles were these? The Schol says Artemisium and Salamis; Thermopylae and Plataea. But it is difficult to see how Mycale could be left out, and owing to the indecisive character of Artemisium, it is likely that Thuc. did not mean to include it, and reckoned Mycale as a naumaxi/a.
7. tou/tou de\ tou= p.—it is not possible to say with certainty whether Thuc. alludes to the Ten Years' War, or the whole of the Pel. War.
me/ga—predicative.
8. cunhne/xqh—cf. c. 9. 2. This use also, with an infin., is frequent in Herod.

11. u(po\ barba/rwn—if the Ten Years' War is meant, the only case mentioned by Thuc. is Colophon (3.34); but if the Twenty-seven Years' War be meant, Mycalessus (29) may be included, though h)rhmwqhsan is somewhat exaggerated.
u(po\ sfw=n au)tw=n—as Plataea (3.68), Mytilene (3.50), Thyrea (4.57).
12. oi)kh/toras mete/balon—as Aegina (2.27), Potidaea (2.70), Anactorium (4.49), Scione (5.32), Delos (5.1), Melos (5.116).

13. fugai/—sc. e)ge/nonto. Instances of exile as the direct consequence of the war are the Plataeans (2.5), driven out by the Thebans, the Lesbians, who fled before the Athenians (4.52); exile as the result of sta/sis occurred at Corcyra (3.69), Megara (4.74).
15. ta/ te pro/teron ktl.—moreover what was formerly repeated on hearsay, but seldom confirmed by fact, now became credible, because men saw it all.
17. seismw=n te pe/ri ... h(li/ou te e)klei/yeis—the construction changes slightly. We might have had seismoi/ or peri\ e)klei/yewn.
19. oi( au)toi/—moreover, emphasising i)sxuro/tatoi. Cf. the use of idem.

20. pukno/terai—of course Thuc. does not record all the strange things that befell meta\ tou=de tou= pole/mou: e.g. he records no instances of au)xmo/s or limo/s (for limoi/ evidently does not refer to hunger caused by siege). He records two eclipses of the sun, one in 431 B.C. (2.28), the other in 424 B.C. (4.52), but if the Ten Years' War be meant, three eclipses could have been observed in Greece; or it the Twenty-seven Years' War is alluded to, six. Of course it is not certain that all of the eclipses were actually observed; Thuc., as Mr. Forbes says, only gives the popular opinion.
para\ ta/—as compared with; cf. 4.6 xeimw\n mei/zwn para\ th\n kaqesthkui=an w(/ran.

23. kai\ h( ... h( no/sos—the art. is similarly repeated to throw emphasis on the second part of the phrase—the disease that ... I mean the pestilence—in c. 126. 4, and in several other instances. With no/sos most edd. supply e)ge/neto: but Steup rightly says ou)k a)/pistos kate/sth, for when Thuc. describes the plague in 2.47, he expressly says that ‘it was said that it had broken out in several other places previously’ to 430 B.C.
me/ros ti—object of fqei/rasa, sc. th=s *(ella/dos, a great number of the Greeks.

26. h)/rcanto de/—the narrative of the war begins at the opening of Bk. ii., the remainder of this book being occupied with the ai)ti/ai kai\ diaforai/. The main emphasis is on lu/santes ktl.; the date of the recovery of Euboea is 445 B.C. (c. 115).
29. ta\s ai)ti/as ... kai\ ta\s diafora/s—these are again denoted by h( a)lhqesta/th pro/fasis and ai( ... ai)ti/ai in 23.6.

3. th
 me
 ga ktl—apparently th
 ... lo/gw| is attributive predicate to tou\s *)aqhnai/ous ... a)nagka/sai, as Classen explains, lit. As for the truest motive ... I think that the A... . forced etc. The assumption of a ‘confnsion of construction’ (Kiuger) seems unnecessary. Chambry explains th
 a). pro/fasin tou\s *)aqhnai/ous h(gou=mai ... kai\(h(gou=mai) ... a)nagka/sai, so that h(gou=mai has two objects differently expressed, but gignome/nous and pare/xontas can scarcely be separated.

4. pro/fasin—of the actual motive, as in 6.6, and now and then in other authors. When so used it seems to denote the motive as it appears to the mind of the writer as distinct from the motive as put forward by the doer.

5. mega/lous gignome/nous—in c. 118 Thuc. says that the Athenians during the period between the foundation of the Delian Confederacy and the war (the Pentecontaetia) e)pi\ me/ga e)xw/rhsan duna/mews. We might, therefore, look for mei/zous a)ei/ in place of mega/lous, but, as this is the first mention of Atheman power, the pos. is quite natural. This growing greatness of A. is described in cc. 88-118; ai: ... l. ai)ti/ai occupy cc. 24-87.
11. *)e. e)sti po/lis—there is a city named E.
e)sple/onti—dat. of the ‘person judging,’ frequent in Thuc. The direct accus. instead of e)s after e)splei=n is poetical, and occurs nowhere else in prose.
12. *)io/nion—the Adriatic.
16. *kori/nqios—when a city that was a colony founded a colony in turn, it was usual to choose a founder from the original mother-city.
tw=n a)f' *(h. depends on *fali/os, of the family of the Heraclidae.

21. du/namis—see crit. note. The gloss po/lis is, of course, due to polua/nqrwpos. An obvious change would be du/namis m. kai\ <po/lis> polua/nqrwpos, but du/namis polua/nqrwpos is surely a possible phrase, as du/namis denotes military power: cf. 33. 2 au(/th(h( du/namis)pa/restin au)tepa/ggeltos.
23. a)po\ pole/mou ... e)fqa/rhsan—in consequence of a war with ... they became crippled.
24. th=s duna/mews depends on th=s pollh=s, i.e. the idiom h( pollh\ th=s d. is used.
25. ta\ de\ teleutai=a ... pole/mou—in the period immediately preceding this war.
1. e)pelqo/ntes—this conjecture seems required, since with a)pelqo/ntes (‘the departed exiles’) we miss a circumstantial partic. to e)lh/|zonto.

7. periora=n fqeirome/nous—in c. 35. 4 periorw= with infin. With infin. periorw= occurs only in Herod. and Thuc., and =e)w=: with partic. (pres. or aor. with different shade of meaning)=‘look on’ with indifference.
15. e)n a)po/rw| ei)/xonto —e)/xesqai e)n pollh=| a)pori/a| occurs in Antiphon v. 16, Lys. xiii. 11; ei)=nai e)n a)po/rw| Thuc. 3.22. The ordinary phrase is e)n(pollh=|)a)pori/a| ei)=nai.
16. qe/sqai to\ paro/n—how to arrange the matter.
18. ei) paradoi=en—oblique for the delib. subjunct.

19. timwri/an tina\ poiei=sqai—cf. c. 5. 1, ‘obtain help’; but the words would naturally mean to bring help (the idiom with poiei=sqai). In 6.60, however, a)/deian poiei=sqai means to obtain immunity.
20. au)toi=s—the Corinthians, depending on paradou=nai.
24. sfw=n—here, and frequently in Herod. and Thuc., as direct reflexive, referring to the subject of the same clause.

27. kata/ te to\ di/kaion—this does not mean as was right, but that to\ di/kaion was the motive put forward by the Corinthians; i.e. to\ di/kaion has its rhetorical use, and the plea may be illustrated by the saying suggnw/mh a)delfw=| bohqei=n.
2. a(/ma de\ kai/—for the de/ following te cf. c. 11. 1.

4. ou)/te ga/r—the verb is e)/pempon (c. 26. 1), but, owing to the length of the sentence, the construction is changed (anacoluthon), and instead of oi: *kerkurai=oi being the subject of the verb, a new subject, oi( *kori/nqioi, is introduced. The outline of the sentence is as follows: 1. (a) ou)/te ... nomizo/mena, (b) ou)/te ... a)poiki/ai: 2. perifronou=ntes de/, (a) kai\ (‘both’) ... plousiwta/tois, (b) kai\ ... dunatw/teroi, (c) nautikw=| de\ ... e)pairo/menoi, etc.
4. e)n panhgu/resi tai=s koinai=s—festivals common to Corinth and Corcyra.
5. ge/ra—the schol. rather vaguely says ta\s tima\s kai\ proedri/as. The corresponding passage in Diodorus says that the Corcyraeans neglected to send animals for sacrifice.

6. *korinqi/w| a)ndri\ ... i(erw=n—Hdt. 6.81 (Cleomenes of Sparta at Argos) Xen. Hell. 3.4 (Agesilaus of Sparta at Aulis) allude to the fact that a ce/nos could not offer sacrifice in a strange city without permission. Dittenberger shows that prokata/rxesqai is equivalent to proqu/ein (cf. Syl. Ins. Gr. 323 and 358): certain ceremonies took place before a victim was killed for sacrifice (Gardner and Jevons, p. 250), and these ceremonies had to be performed by a citizen of the place. The Corcyraeans would not perform them for Corinthians, and thus prevented the latter from sacrificing in Corcyra. Thuc. uses prokata/rxesqai here for the usual kata/rxesqai.

8. kai\ xrhma/twn ktl.—partly because the power that money gave them put them on a level with the richest of the Greeks. By ‘the richest of the Greeks’ the Corinthians themselves are meant. There is some exaggeration, no doubt, for the Athenians were actually among the richest; but the wealth of Corinth had become a tradition (see c. 13). o(moi/a o)/ntes is not possible (see crit. note), and dunatoi/ cannot be supplied with Herbst from dunatw/teroi. <e)n> duna/mei ... o(moi/a| or duna/mei ... o(moi=oi would give the required sense with a proper construction, but no correction is certain.
12. prou/xein —e)pai/romai is found only here with infin.= ‘boast.’

e)/stin o(/te—with kai\ kata\ ktl., sometimes even on the ground that the Phaeacians, who were famous for seamanship, had dwelt in Corcyra before them. The Greeks identified Corcyra with the Scheria of the Odyssey. For the naval reputation of the Phaeacians see Od. vii. 34-39, where they are called nausiklutoi/.
14. h(=| kai/—this circumstance (that they were proud of the reputation of the Phaeacians) led them to. kai/=‘and in fact.’
15. ou)k a)du/natoi, meiosis for dunatw/tatoi.
18. e)/pempon—sent, the imperf. being frequently used with pe/mpw and other verbs—keleu/w, de/omai etc.—where we look for aor. Perhaps it is because it takes time to deliver the message.
20. kai\ *)amprakiwtw=n—with frourou/s.
22. *)apollwni/an—now the ruins of Pollina, S. of Durazzo.

2. kai\ u(/steron—in eontrast with eu)qu/s. The e(/teros sto/los seems to anticipate a)lla\ strateu/ousin ktl. in 26.4; but the edd. explain with Poppo, that this new force consisted of fifteen ships (hence forty below, cf. c. 29. 4). But strateu/ousin e)p' au)tou/s should not allude to a hostile move made by the twenty-five ships already on the spot (the rendering ‘assume the offensive’ being madmissible): they should refer only to the new force sent from home.
3. kat' e)ph/reian—in a threatening manner, with e)ke/leuon.

6. a)podeiknu/ntes—cf. c. 25. 2, ‘calling their attention to graves (of their common ancestors buried at Corcyra) and ties of blood, to which they appealed.’ h(/n applies equally to both nouns, but is attracted to the nearer.
9. au)tw=n—neut., with ou)de/n, the demands.
10. a)lla\ strateu/ousin—parataxis, the sense being, ‘but, instead of the E. listening to their demands, the C.’
14. proei=pon combines public ‘summons’ with ‘notice’; Herod. 2.33; vii. 149. Infins. of different kinds are combined also with le/gw and gignw/skw.
18. au)toi=s—see on c. 13. 3.
22. e)pi\ th=| ... i)e/nai—epexegesis of a)poiki/an, and governed by e)kh/russon. For the dat. fem. in adverbial phrase cf. c. 15. 2. The new colonies were to have equal rights with the old.

24. e)qe/lei ... bou/letai—if e)qe/loi is right, the two moods are combined in O.O.; e)qe/loi represents e)qe/lei of recta, and there is no change of meaning. It should be noticed that the Laurentian gives e)qe/lei: for the change of indic. after ei) to optat. is rare, but occurs occasionally, as in Lys. vii. 34 prosh=lqon le/gwn o(/ti ... e(/toimo/s ei)mi, ei)/ tina bou/loito (=bou/lei), paradou=nai. In Thuc. 8.89. 3 ei) mh\ h)/koien represents ei) mh\ h(/kousi.
26. *korinqi/as—the Cor. drachma was about two-thirds of the value of the Attic.
me/nein—oblique for mene/tw.
4. *kefallh/nwn — partitive; there were four po/leis in Cephallenia, of which Pale was one.
9. kena/s—sc. a)ndrw=n.

15. pare/labon — ‘had taken with them,’ to support the request There is no difficulty in supposing that Sparta and Sicyon were ready to lend their voice to a request that Corinth should withdraw the new settlers. These oi)kh/tores must have appropriated the property of the exiled Corcyraean oligarchs; and the proceeding of Corinth was in this respect high-handed. The sending of the pre/sbeis did not commit Sparta to anything.
18. a)ntipoiou=ntai—sc. *)epida/mnou.

di/kas dou=nai—submit the case to arbitration. d. dido/nai kai\ de/xesqai is a technical phrase for legal arbitration between states as opposed to war: cf. vii. 18 o(/pla mh\ e)pife/rein h)\n di/kas e)qe/lwsi dido/nai.
19. ai(=s a)\n ktl = par' ai(=s a)\n di/kas dou=nai a). c.
21. kratei=n—sc. h)/qelon.
h)/qelon de/—an alternative suggestion to submit the decision to Apollo.
22. po/lemon de\ ktl.—but they charged them not to cause a war. Notice the difference between po/lemon poiw= and p. poiou=mai.
23. ei) de\ mh/— M.T. 478. kai\ au)toi/—they in turn. The elaborate wording of the allusion to Athens is intended to mark the earnestness and reluctance of the Corcyraeans.
24. e)kei/nwn biazome/nwn—if the Corinthians forced them.

25. e(te/rous tw=n nu=n—gen. of comparison; Xen. Mem. 4.4. 25 a)/lla tw=n dikai/wn. So Lat. alius occasionally has abl. tw=n nu=n o)/ntwn means the Peloponnesians whose confederacy Corcyra threatens to leave. ma=llon goes with fi/lous poiei=sqai, sooner than agree to the demand of Corinth.
26. w)feli/as e(/neka—in self-defence.

1. pro/teron d' ktl. — equivalent to ou) kalw=s e)/xein pro/teron au)tou/s (the Corinthians and Corcyraeans) dika/zesqai, poliorkoume/nwn tw=n *)epidamni/wn, but the logic of the sentence is sacrificed to a verbal antithesis.
4. tau=ta—i.e. withdraw the ships and the Illyrians.

e(toi=moi de\ ei)=nai—Krüger supplies dikazesqai, and w(/ste then =‘on the understanding that’; but this is not very satisfactory after poih/sein tau=ta has intervened. Bohme and others
make me/nein depend on e(toi=moi ei(=nai, with w(/ste pleonastic; and for this i(kano\s w(/ste is cited from Plat. Protag 338 c. In either case the sense is the same; they were prepared to agree that besiegers and besieged should stay as they were and make a truce until the arbitration was concluded. poih/sasqai is co-ordinate with me/nein. (Mr. Forbes supplies poiei=n tau=ta to e(toi=moi ei)=nai: but poiei=n tau=ta cannot=dika/zesqai, for in that case the second proposal of the Coreyraeans, h)\n kai\ e)kei=noi ktl., is a less conciliatory suggestion than their original proposal, 28.2.)
9. prope/myantes ... pro/teron—pleonasm, as in c. 23. 5.
11. e(bdomh/konta kai\ pe/nte—the numbers given in c. 27. 2 amount to 68, but to these are to be added the nh=es kenai/ from Elis.
disxili/ois—the number is puzzling, as in c. 27. 2 the Cor. are said to be pieparing to send 3000.
12. e)pi/—for, not ‘against.’ e)nanti/a, internal accus, as adv.; cf. c. 6. 6.
19. to\ i(ero\n *)apo/llwnos—the celebrated temple of *)apo/llwn *)/aktios, best known to us from its connexion with the battle of Actium.
21. prou/pemyan—before taking hostile action.

23. zeu/cantes—probably this means that they inserted new cross-beams, called zugw/mata or zuga/, connecting one side of the ship with the other. (The zugw/mata. however, may be ribs, stami=nes.) This has nothing to do with undergirding, which, as Mr. Forbes says, would be zw/santes.
24. e)piskeua/santes—overhauled to see if repairs were needed.
27. tessara/konta—see c. 25. 4.
2. para\ polu/—always with a word implying comparison; cf. para\ polu\ h(sshqe/ntes 2.89. 3.
6. parasth/sasqai—sc. th\n *)epi/damnon.
w(/ste=e)f) w(=|te|. e)ph/ludas —the oi)kh/tores of c. 26. 1.
10. *leuki/mmh|—Leukimo, SE. of Corcyra, near which the battle was doubtless fought.
11. a)/llous—those taken in the sea-fight.
18. th=s gh=s—partitive.

20. tou= te xro/nou to\n plei=ston—with me/xri ou(=, most of the time they were controlling the sea and plundering the allies, ‘until.’ (Classen and Herbst understand by o\ xro/nos the remainder of the campaigning season, but, without any qualification of xro/nos, this is surely impossible.) Of course the time intended must depend on the meaning of perio/nti tw=| qe/rei, for which see next note. Thuc. means that the Corcyraeans did not keep their fleet at sea all the time between the departure of the Corinthian fleet and its reappearance.

24. periio/nti tw=| qe/rei —perio/nti, being the reading of all MSS, may be accepted. If periei=nai is intended, the explanation offered (Ullrich and others) is in ‘the remaining part of the summer.’ Herbst supports this rendering with e)n tw=| au)tw=| qe/rei teleutw=nti etc. (see the passages quoted by Mr. Forbes). But tw=| qe/rei teleutw=nti means in the summer when it was ending; and perio/nti tw=| qe/rei=‘in the summer when it was (all) remaining over,’ the predicative partic., as Kruger says, modifying the whole sphere covered by the sense of the noun (cf. Bloomfield's note): this cannot yield the sense ‘in the remaining part of the summer.’ perio/nti must therefore be referred to periie/nai, Aeolic elision. Examples of this elision of the i of peri/ are Aesch Ag. 1145 pere/balon, Eum. 634 pereskh/nwsen, and periw/n is frequently given in MSS. for periiw/n. In Xen. Hell. 3.2. 25 the best MS. has perio/nti tw=| e)niautw=|. This means during the summer when it was coming round to autumn, drawing to a close. Steup and others, following the Schol. e)nistame/nw|, understand ‘when the summer came round’ to mean, when the next summer came; but this does not square so well with the concluding words of the chapter, which seem to refer to the winter of the year in which the battle was fought. If ‘drawing to a close’ is the meaning, then the dates would be:
Battle of Leucimme (c. 29. 4), ... Spring 435.
Return of Corinthian fleet (c. 30. 3), Autumn 435.
Corinthian preparations (c. 31. 1). Summer 435-33.

If, however, the sense is ‘when the next summer came,’ the first two dates should be altered to summer 435, and spring 434. (Remember that ‘summer’ in Thuc. includes spring and autumn.) In either case the calculations are based on the date of the battle of Sybota, for which see c. 51.
25. sfw=n—see c. 25. 2.
5. to\ qe/ros tou=to—i.e. for what was left of the campaigning season of 435. (If perio/nti applies to the next summer, then the whole summer of 434 would be meant.)
9. o)rgh=| fe/rontes—excited by the war, o)rgh/ being ‘passion, excitement, impulse,’ as well as anger. It is the ‘war fever’ that Thuc. means.
11. ta\ kra/tista—cf. c. 19, end.

12. e)/k te au)th=s ktl .—e)re/tas is object of a)gei/rontes, to which misqw=| pei/qontes is subordinate. Steup, however, supplies nau=s to a)gei/rontes, and makes m. pei/qontes co-ordinate with a)gei/rontes. He joins th=s a)/llhs *)e. e)re/tas together (‘rowers belonging to other parts of Greece’). With the ordinary construction, supply e)k before th=s.
16. e)/nspondoi=cu/mmaxoi. e)segra/yanto—causal mid.
19. gene/sqai—dependent on peira=sqai. Under the terms of the treaty the a)/grafoi po/leis might seek the alliance of either Athens or Sparta; but of course the request might be refused.
20. w)feli/an=boh/qeian.
22. presbeuso/menoi—to negotiate with them. The mid. seems to express reciprocity, and the word is rather loosely used.
24. prosgeno/menon—trans. ‘the addition of their fleet to ...,’ the chief emphasis being on the partic.
25. qe/sqai—as in c 25. 1.
26. e)s a)ntilogi/an h)=lqon—cf. ei)s lo/gous e)lqei=n tini.

28. eu)ergesi/as ... proufeilome/nhs— ‘without having a elaim through some great serviee rendered or through a previously existing alliance.’ The meaning is simply ‘we cannot urge that we are seeking to renew an old cummaxi/a or that we have a claim on you for services rendered.’ ‘We are not eu)erge/tai of Athens’: for this see on c. 137. 4 kai/ moi eu)ergesi/a o)fei/letai and c. 128. 4.
2. tou\s pe/las—others.
4. prw=ton—answered by e)/peita de/.
5. cu/mfora—internal accus.=cu/mforon de/hsin.
7. be/baion—(cf. c. 2) pred., ‘unfailing.’
ei) ... katasth/sousi—if they do not propose to ... .
9. meta/—while or ‘besides,’ a characteristic substitute for meta\ tou= th\n cummaxi/an ai)tei=n.

12. tetu/xhke de\ ktl —lit. it has turned out that the same conduct not only involves us in inconsistency in our dealing with you, as regards the request we make, but is also disadvantageous (to us) in respect of our own position at the present time; i.e. beeause we have hitherto abstained from entering your alliance it is inconsistent to be seeking it now, and for the same reason we are now in danger. To a)/logon and a)cu/mforon supply o)/n, which is often omitted with tugxa/nw, fai/nomai, diatelw=, and occasionally with other verbs; cf. c. 34 end.

16. e(kou/sioi — ‘having deliberately avoided all alliances’ (not ‘having entered into no alliance, if we could help it’). The strained position of e(kou/sioi, and other words, throws special emphasis on the different parts of the clause. This statement is referred to by the Corinthian at c. 37. 2 cimmaxi/an ou)deno/s pw de/casqai.
18. *korinqi/wn—with po/lemon ; cf. qew=n po/lemos, qew=n o(/rkos, oath by the gods.
di' au)to/—on that account, a favourite use of au)to/ and au)ta/ with Thuc.

19. perie/sthken ... fainome/nh—what formerly seemed discretion in us ... has now on the eontrary proved clearly to be want of foresight and weakness. The partic. with periesta/nai as in the eonstruction tugxa/nei ou)=sa. But cf. c. 120. 5.
20. th=| ... gnw/mh|—with cug., to share the risks of another's policy.
22. th\n ... naumaxi/an—internal accus.
23. kata\ mo/nas—perhaps duna/meis is the subst, omitted in this phrase=‘unaided.’
28. me/gas—sc. e)/stai h(mi=n.

1. mh\ meta\ kaki/as ktl.—not maliciously, but because we were mistaken in our policy, we boldly act in a manner inconsistent with our former inactivity. There is nothing mean in seeking an alliance now for the first time when we are in danger: we were mistaken in not seeking it before.
4. h( cuntuxi/a ... th=s h(. xrei/as—lit. the coincidence of our request, i.e. ‘our request, coming at such a moment.’
10. w(s a)\n ma/lista ... marturi/ou—se. kataqei=sqe, lit. as you would most with a record never forgotten, i.e. ‘in the manner most certain to be remembered for ever by us.’
11. kataqh/sesqe—necessary correction of kataqh=sqe, will confer the favour on us. The met. is from investment of money. Cf. c. 128. 4.
12. nautiko/n te still depends on o(/ti.
15. kai\ (pro\ pollh=s) xa/ritos—i.e. your gratitude would have been great even if you could only have gained this aceession of power for a large sum. Isocr. 13, 11; Dem. pro. 33.
16. du/namin—a power (powerful state), to be translated as subject of pa/restin.
18. fe/rousa e)s—producing in the minds of others an impression of generosity, a feeling of gratitude in those whom ... . Notice the use of a)reth/ here.
23. a)sfa/leian—referring to i)sxu/n: ko/smon referring to a)reth\n kai\ xa/rin.
1. u(mete/rw|—of you.

2. duname/nous—Stahl takes this and o)/ntas in apposition to *korinqi/ous, and removes the second kai/ so that only prokatalamba/nontas depends on ai)sqa/netai. It is better with Steup to render the first kai/ both, and to make o)/ntas also depend on ai)sqa/netai: ‘and are preparing by trying to subdue us for an attack on you.’
5. kat: au)tou\s ... stw=men—confront them.

duoi=n fqa/sai a(ma/rtwsin—(1) ‘may not lose two things’ means may secure one or the other: hence h)\ ... h)/ following. (2) But the construction of fqa/sai and duoi=n is doubtful. Taking duoi=n dependent on a(ma/rtwsin, as in Andoc. 1.20 duoi=n toi=n megi/stoin kakoi=n ou)k h)=n au)tw=| a(martei=n, most cdd. make fqa/sai epexegetic, to gain them before (we make alliance). The order is against this, and fqa/sai should then=to gain one of them. It has been proposed to remove fqa/sai; but it is best, with Croiset, to take duoi=n as dat.=‘fail to be beforehand with two things.’ Either they will inflict a disastrous defeat on Corcyra, or frighten her into joining themselves.
8. dido/ntwn—offering, as frequently.
9. proepibouleu/ein ... a)ntepibouleu/ein — the jingle called paronomasia, to which Thuc. is partial; e.g. 6.76 ou)k a)cunetwte/rou kakocunetwte/rou de/.
16. e)kpe/mpontai—sc. oi( a)/poikoi, from pa=sa a)poiki/a.
17. proklhqe/ntes—see c. 28. 2.
19. tw=| i)/sw| —tw=| no/mw| kai\ tw=| dikai/w|, par' oi)=s h( i)so/ths (Schol.).
ta\ e)gklh/mata metelqei=n—like di/khn me/teimi, enforce their claims.
21. w(/ste—for the construction cf. c. 49. 7; 129. 3.
22. e)k tou= eu)qe/os—in a straightforward way, with deome/nois.
25. lamba/nwn—the same use with subst. referring to the feelings, c. 77. 6; cf. 2.64 to\ e)pi/fqonon lamba/nein.
27. mhdete/rwn—on account of the subjective sense given by dexo/menoi—it is from the Lac. point of view.
28. ei)/rhtai—there is a clause in the thirty years' truce.
1. a)re/skhtai—sc. e)lqei=n, mid., not as in c. 129 toi=s lo/gois a)re/skomai. The use of the mid. is Ionic.
5. prokeime/nhs—open to all.
7. ei)=ta—and actually as a climax of arrogance an object if you help us.
9. e)n ai)ti/a| e)/xein—a frequent idiom in Thuc. (Kr., followed by Steup, reads w)feli/as ei)/ te e)n ... deo/meqa, polu\ dh/ ktl.)
11. ou)x o(/pws—so far from.
14. perio/yesqe—in sense=e)a/sete, hence the infin. With the partic. periora=n=to overlook what actually occurs; 1.24.6.
h(/n—sc. du/namin proslabei=n au)tou\s periidei=n.
a)ll)—sc. di/kaio/n e)sti.

15. ka)kei/nwn ... kai\ h(mi=n—i.e. stop them too from getting help, if you will not help us, or help us too if you let them ‘help themselves’ from your empire. kwlu/w with a pers. object and without infin., ‘stop the mercenaries they draw,’ is not common; Eur. frag. 1041 Nauck oi)kofqo/ron ga\r a)/ndra kwlu/ei gunh\ e)sqlh/.

16. pe/mpein w)feli/an—means send aid without concluding
a formal alliance: bohqei=n a)po\ tou= p. decame/nous=‘openly receive us into alliance and so help us.’
19. u(pei/pomen — ‘suggested.’ The ref. is to c. 33. 1 genh/setai kalh\ h) cuntuxi/a kata\ polla/.
20. me/giston—sc. to\ cumfe/ron a)podei/knumen. We have the same powerful enemies as you have; and that is a great advantage to you, because it will bind us to you.

21. h)=san—are, as we saw; the didactio imperf.; but the word is prob. spurious, because (1) this use of the imperf. is not made out for the speeches of Thuc.: (2) we cannot supply h)=san to what follows—ou)=toi ... bla/yai—but require ei)si/n, since nothing has been said to suggest that.

23. tou\s metasta/ntas—those who shall have abandoned your alliance. This seems more probable than the rendering ‘those who have abandoned them (Corinth),’ as the mothercity. Athens may feel that Corcyra would be afraid to abandon the alliance with her.

24. ou)x o(moi/a h( a)llotri/wsis—Classen and others understand ‘the rejection of it is not the same thing (as if it were a continental alliance),’ i.e is more dangerous to you. Stahl, Steup and others: to estrange us is not a matter of indifference to you, which accounts better for the a)lla/ following: ‘but you should make friends with a naval power if you cannot prevent its existence.’
26. e)a=n ... e)/xein—infin. in imperative sense. (Some think dei= is lost before ei) de\ mh/.)
2. fobei=tai de/—supply o(/stis as subject, but it is usual to omit the second rel. in Greek in such a case.

3. ta\s sponda\s lu/sh|—i.e. if he has not been convinced by what we have said on this point; see c. 35. 1. Legally, the speaker has already explained, there will be no breach of the truce; but the alliance might be considered by Corinth as a breach of its spirit.

4. to\ dedio/s—a favourite construction of Thuc. 2.59. 3 to\ o)rgizo/menon th=s gnw/mhs: below c. 84. 6; to\ me/llon 90. 2; 142. 8. The neut. partic. with art. as noun is rarely used by other prose authors: Xen. Cyr. IV. v. 39 to\ e)llei=pon.
i)sxu\n e)/xon—as the result of alliance with us.
5. mh\ decame/nou—if he rejects our request.
7. a)dee/steron—less formidable: here in passive sense. Cf. the double meaning of fobero/s, formidolosus.
ou) ... to\ ple/on=h)=sson.
10. e)s to\n ... e)ndoia/zh| ktl.—hesitates to secure for her in view of the war ... a place which beeomes friend or enemy with most important consequences to you (in either case).

13. th=s ... *sikeli/as depends on para/plou, the coasting voyage to I. and S., Corcyra being the half-way house when the ordinary route to Sicily and Lower (Greek) Italy was taken —viz. round the coast of Peloponnese and to Corcyra and thence across. The gen. para/plou depends on kalw=s in the phrase kalw=s kei=tai constructed on the analogy of kalw=s e)/xei, w(s e)/xei (e.g. c. 22. 3)etc.
16. e)pelqei=n—generally go to attack, here to help. Sparta hoped for sueh help from the west.
to/ te e)nqe/nde—a fleet going from Athens to Italy or Sicily. This passage was prob. written by Thuc. later in the war, when Athens had sent out such fleets via Coreyra.

18. braxuta/tw| ktl. — ‘this is the briefest summary, including the whole situation and the details, by which ...’ toi=s te cu/mpasi kai\ kaq' e(/kaston is taken by Classen as adverbial =‘on the whole as well as in detail,’ but there is no parallel for the phrase in dative. It is awkward, but better, to make it apposition to kefalai/w| (Kiuger). It is true that only one general matter is presently referred to (viz. the naval strength of Corcyra), so that ta\ kaq' e(/kaston seem wanting (Stahl); but the speaker means if you think out this summary, you will find it includes all detailed arguments too. If we look at the cumfe/ronta to Athens that are brought forward in this speech, we shall notice (1) that the speaker in each case leads up to the fleet of Corcyra as the crowning argument, (2) that he is well aware that this is the argument that will really impress Athens. It is therefore right to insist on it at the end. kefa/laion means summary of the points previously raised. Edd. seem to overlook the fact that this passage is rhetorical, and not necessarily strictly accurate. (The remedy proposed is to make toi=s ... e(/kaston masc., either as dat. commodi depending on b. kefalai/w| (Poppo, Steup) or placed after or before cumforw/tato/n e)sti.)
20. tri/a me/n—sc. e)sti/: o)/nta belongs to lo/gou a)/cia. (There is no anacoluthon here.)

26. plei/osi ktl.—‘with our ships in addition (to yours). For this use of plei/wn cf. e.g. Aesch. Ag. 755 to\ dussebe\s ga\r
e)/rgon ... plei/ona ti/ktei. (To take tai=s h(mete/rais as dat. of measure dependent on plei/osi gives an ugly construction.)

3. w(s kai/ for kai\ w(s, unless kai/ is due to dittography (w(s and kai/ are sometimes confused in MSS.). The parallels quoted, like 2.44 o(/ ti a)/cion kai\ ei)pei=n, are not close. (Steup thinks that after kai/ a clause is lost in which one of the two topics summed up in a)mfote/rwn was expressed.)
5. a)mfote/rwn—strictly to\ h(ma=s a)dikei=n and to\ au)tou\s polemou=sqai are but one topic differently expressed, and the two aspects of the matter are not clearly distinguished in what follows.
6. ou(/tw—like tum demum.
7. a)ci/wsin—claim.
8. mh\ a)logi/stws—together as one word.
10. to\ de/—but that. to/ being demonstrative in sense.
11. a)reth=|—either depending on e)pi/, or perhaps rather causal dat. a)reth/ means to\ sw=fron: cf. c. 32. 4.

cu/mmaxo/n te—we have here the only example of te followed by ou)/te (before parakalou=ntes. ou)/te ... te is common): ‘wishing to have no ally in their nefarious schemes (persecuting their neighbours) or witness (ou)de/ does not mean not even here as Mr. Forbes supposes), and to avoid exposing themselves to shame by asking others to aid them (in such schemes).’ The simplest change proposed is to alter ou)de/ to ou)/te (Weil), so that te would co-ordinate boulo/menoi to e)pi\ kakourgi/a| kai\ ou)k a)reth=| and ou)/te m. e)/xein=‘neither to have any ally as a witness in their schemes nor to ...’
15. au)ta/rkh qe/sin — internal accus.: the meaning is presently explained in dia\ to\ ktl.

16. pare/xei au)tou\s ktl.—makes them judges of the wrongs they inflict more than (they would be) if they were hampered by treaties. With ma=llon h)/ kata/, more than accords with, cf. c. 76. 3: 2.50 xalepwte/rws h)\ kata\ th\n a)nqrwpei/an fu/sin. (gi/gnesqai does not belong to the phrase, but to dikasta/s only.)

dikasta/s—the meaning is that a citizen of another state who went to law with a Corcyrean must proceed as a ce/nos in the Corcyrean courts: Corcyra does not experience a similar difficulty, whether real or assumed, because her citizens do not need to have dealings with other states to anything like the
same extent. Corcyra was, of course, the port of call for all vessels passing to and from the west by the ‘coasting’ route; but the grievance based on this fact is surely exaggerated here.
18. e)kple/ontas agrees with ‘the Corcyreans’: others when at sea a)na/gkh| katai/rousi to Corcyra.

20. kai\ tou=to ktl.—the speaker now alludes to disputes between Corcyra and another state (meaning Corinth). e)n tou/tw|, this being their conduct (see crit. note), is not right, because the argument shifts here to a new point.
to\ eu)prepe\s a)/spondon—cf. e.g. 6.34 to\ cunhqe\s h(/suxon.
21. probe/blhntai—as a shield or cloak to cover their a)diki/a.

22. kai\ o(/pws—this explains kata\ mo/nas a)dikw=si, and means whether they make unrighteous gains by force or by deceit— these two ways are summed up in h)\n ... prosla/bwsin—they feel no shame, because there is no witness.
25. kai/toi—the sentence that follows refers to both the grievances just alleged.
26. a)lhpto/teroi h)=san—the imperf. by assimilation to the other verbs. e/ch=n is, of course, potential according to Goodwin, M.T. 415. a)lhpto/teroi because of their au)ta/rkhs qe/sis.

1. didou=si kai\ dexome/nois ta\ d.—Corcyra had offered di/kas in this case (c. 28. 2); but the Corinthian means that they would not enter into an alliance, a condition of which was regularly the settlement of disputes by arbitration.
4. dia\ panto/s—temporal.
8. ta\ ei)ko/ta qauma/zesqai—to receive the proper marks of honour, for which see c 25. 4.
12. a)re/skontes—Soph. OT 274 o(/sois ta/d' e)/st' a)re/skont'.

13. e)pistrateu/omen — ‘nor is it our way to attack a colony exceptionally unless we have suffered ...’ The partic. must be conditional; but the sense is much improved by e)pestrateu/omen, sc. a)/n, nor should we be attacking them (Corcyra) in a manner so exceptional (as we are doing). Thus mh\ a). would=ei) mh\ h)dikou/meqa. If e)pistrateu/omen be right, e)kprepw=s may=‘unreasonably,’ being explained by mh\ ... a)dikou/menoi: but ‘exceptionally’ has much more point here.
14. kalo\n d' h)=n—cf. c. 37. 5.
16. ai)sxro/n—slight anacoluthon, adding to the vigour of the sentence.
17. metrio/thta—sc. ei) me/trioi h)=san.
u(/brei de\ ktl.—solemnity of ‘gnomic’ style; cf. L. & S. under ko/ros.
19. kakoume/nhn—temporal.
20. prosepoiou=nto—as in c. 8. 3. For the treatment of Epidamnus by Corcyra see c. 24, and for the intervention of Corinth c. 26.
21. e)/xousi—now hold it.

23. h(/n ge ktl.=a)lla\ tau/thn ge ou)k e)kei=non ds prou/xwn kai\ e)k tou= a)sfalou=s prokalei=tai, so that prou/xonta, from a position of superiority (gained by the use of force), is coordinate with e)k tou= a)sfalou=s.
25. le/gein ti—talk seriously.

26. e)s i)/son ... kaqista/nta—this clause is in contrast with prou/xonta kai\ e)k tou= a)sfalou=s, and must mean that in order that a demand for arbitration may be entertained, the party making the demand must first set himself on a level with the other party not merely in free discussion with him, but (what is more important), by giving up any advantage he has gained till a decision is arrived at. Transl. ‘but he who, before having recourse to arms, puts himself in deeds as well as in words on a level.’ pri\n diagwni/zesqai may mean before any solution, whether by arms or arbitration; but pri\n poliorkei=n favours the more confined sense. The meaning of e)s i)/son ... kaqista/nta cannot be, according to the old explan., ‘whose deeds square with his words.’
28. pri\n poliorkei=n —pri/n before; for the infin. after a neg. preceding pri/n cf. c. 68. 2.
5. cummaxei=n ... cunadikei=n—c. 33. 4.
diafo/rous o)/ntas agrees with sfa=s.
7. prosie/nai—to have applied to you.
8. e)n w)=|—under present circumstances, when.
11. a)pogeno/menoi=ou) metalabo/ntes.

13. koinw/santes—having given you a share in. The confusion of koinou=n and koinwnei=n (have a share in) in MSS. is very common. ta\ a)pobai/nonta means w)feli/a, the natural result tou= palai koinw=sai th\n du/namin. (e/gklhmatwn in C is an
oversight—see the next line. The text of G gives a Scholium on this false reading from pa/lai to e)gklhma/twn.)
21. a)gra/fwn=tw=n mh/pw e)ggegramme/nwn.
ou) toi=s ktl.—that clause does not apply to those whose application is intended to cause injury to others.
22. a)ll) (e)kei/nw|) o(/stis—who does not withdraw from another; cf. c. 38. 1. For the construction of a)posterw=n Croiset quotes Antiplion v. 78 ou)k a)posterw=n ge ... e(auto\n ou)deno/s (neut.).

24. toi=s decame/nois ktl.—will not cause war instead of peace for those who have admitted them: ei) swfronou=si applies to the whole sentence, and means as they—those to whom they make the application—know if they are prudent. The brachylogy is the same as in 6.11. 7 ou) peri\ tw=n e)n *sikeli/a| ... o( a)gw/n, ei) swfronou=men, and also in 3.44. 1. (This is Steup's view, the best explanation that has been given of this awkward sentence. Classen, Stahl, Kruger and others assume that the ref. is to the conduct of the parties after the alliance is concluded, and nnderstand ‘who will assure peace, not war to those who receive them, if they, oi( de/ca/menoi, show ordinary discretion.’ Croiset seems to refer ei) swfronou=sin to those making the application, but the two parallel passages tell against this. Weil proposes kei) swfronou=sin.)
25. poih/sei—will cause.
o(/—i.e. to\ po/lemon e)/xein ktl.
3. e)nspo/ndwn—i.e. you would be wiped out of the thirty years' truce, so far as we are concerned.
a)na/gkh ga/r—the threat, we shall include you with them in our hostile measures, is vagnely expressed. tou/tous is obj. to a)mu/nesqai, and mh\ a(/neu u(mw=n=meq' u)mw=n.
5. kai/toi—here means and surely, not ‘and yet.’
di/kaioi/ g)—the personal construction common with di/kaios.
6. e)kpodw\n sth=nai—neutrality is your best plan.
9. di' a)nokwxh=s ... e)ge/nesqe—cf. c. 73. 2 di' o)/xlou ei)=nai. a)nokwxh/ is an armistice.
10. w(/ste ... de/xesqai explains to\n no/mon.

11. *sami/wn a)posta/ntwn—in 440 B.C., c. 115. The resemblance between the two cases is more verbal than real.
The Corinthian keeps using a)posth=nai of Corcyra; but Corcyra's a)po/stasis was really only the estrangement of a colony from the mother-city, whereas Samos really revolted from the Athenian alliance.
13. di/xa e)yhfisme/nwn—were divided in their votes.
14. a)ntei/pomen—made a counter proposal.
15. au)to/n—ipsum. tina/=pa/nta tina/.

16. ei) ga\r tou\s kako/n ktl. — an argument from expediency to support the exhortation to\n no/mon mh\ kaqista/nai ... de/xesqai. But the ga/r is strange, and should perhaps be altered to de/ or te. (Steup proposes to place this sentence at the end of c. 42, where tw=| au)ti/ka fanerw=| fits in with fanei=tai kai\ a(/.)
17. timwrh/sete—supply a dat.; the case of the common object follows the partic. according to the usual const.; cf. c. 5. 1.

fanei=tai kai\ a(/ — perhaps ‘a prophecy after the event’ due to Thuc. himself. Potidaea, Lesbos and other parts revolted not so long after. a(/ (in place of oi)/) adds to the bitterness of the sentence; and the unexpected word fanei=tai is sarcastic, fai/nomai being constantly used in this way of the coming of deliverers, helpers, etc. (o: lwfh/swn ga\r ou) pe/fhne/ pw, w)= xro/nw| fanei/s and so on). From the point of view of Corinth the revolt would be a ‘coming’ of this kind.

23. h(/n—antecedent xa/ritos. We are not your enemies, so you cannot refuse on that ground; we are not your friends, so that you cannot object that services on both sides are natural, and that we should not reckon what we did for you as laying you under an obligation. The e)pi- denotes reciprocity: to be on terms of intimacy. This antithesis is somewhat artificial, and, but for the verbal correspondence, we should look for something like w)/st' ei)ko\s ei)=nai proi=ka e)pixrh=sqai h(ma=s (you and we) a)llh/lois. (The transl. ‘so as to use you freely’ would be easier; but there is no authority for e)pixrh=sqai in this sense.)
27. pote—in the first war with Aegina, 505-491 B.C.; hence u(pe\r ta\ *mhdika/=pro\ tw=n *mhdikw=n, see c. 14. 2.

2. e)pikra/thsin—the partiality of Thuc. for nouns in .sis formed from verbs is well known; some of them, like this and pre/sbeusis (c. 73), occur nowhere else in classical authors. A
good example of the preference for nouns over verbs occurs at c. 137. 4 gra/yas ... dia/lusin: e)nqu/mhsis, p. 117, l. 5.
4. oi(=s for e)n oi(=s after e)n kairoi=s, by a common idiom.
9. ta\ oi)kei=a—their own interests.

11. new/tero/s tis—in ref. to the Aeginetan War. The sing. has attracted the verbs into the sing. in spite of e)nqumhqe/ntes. au)ta/ might of course have been omitted, but Thuc. is fond of putting it into the second member of a rel. sentence. (To repeat the rel. is exceptional.)

13. toi=s o(moi/ois a)mu/nesqai—to requite us with like treatment. a)mu/nomai in this sense generally implies the paying back of injuries, and here we should expect a)mei/besqai (see crit. note, and cf. L. & S. under a)mei/bomai). Presently we have an ordinary phrase, to\ i)/son a)ntapodou=nai: but it may be that, in opposing the Corinthian “di/kaion” to the Corcyrean “cumfe/ron,” Thuc. purposely makes the speaker use a word that is properly used of dealings between enemies; the speaker means “They say we are your enemies (see c. 33. 3): you must judge of that by our actions in the past, and pay us for our so-called enmity with the same sort of ‘enmity.’”

15. ei) polemh/sei—in the event of war. The Corinthian, like the Corcyrean, insisted on (1) to\ di/kaion, (2) to\ cumfe/ron, but—as Fr. Muller says—he deals vaguely with the latter topic, since Corinth had clearly less to offer Athens than Corcyra had.

16. e)n w)=|—c. 37. 4. e(/petai=‘is found,’ ‘is there.’ It is a moral sentiment—much like ‘virtue is its own reward’— but not much in point here. Grammatically tis is for tini, being attracted into the relative clause.
17. to\ me/llon tou= pole/mou—i.e. it is not certain that war is coming.
20 e)parqe/ntas au)tw=|—prompted by that expectation; Eur. Orest. 286 o(/stis m' e)pa/ras e)/rgon a)nosiw/taton (to a ...) ktl.

22. u(parxou/shs pro/teron—that existed already. This is the Engl. equivalent, though u(parxou/shs is really imperf. partic., past in reference to u(fei/lomen. u(felei=n ma=llon is to diminish rather than to add to, and the gen. is partitive (ma=llon does not belong to sw=fron as Classen took it). For pro/teron u)ph=rxe cf. vii. 28 po/lemon ou)de\n e)la/ssw prosanei/lonto tou= pro/teron u:pa/rxontos. The transl. ‘that has existed for some time’ is simple, but scarcely justified.

dia\ *megare/as—what event is alluded to? Edd. are much divided between (1) ‘the Megarian decree,’ by which Athens excluded Megara from all her ports and markets (c. 67); (2) the revolt of Megara to Athens after a dispute with Corinth (c. 103 for to\ sfodro\n mi=sos that Corinth conceived for Athens on this account) in 465 B.C.; (3) the revolt of Megara with Corinthian support, from Athens in 445 B.C. (cc. 114-115). The u(poyi/a is that felt by Corinth, so that (3) appeais unlikely—note e)/gklhma. As (1) is the only one of these events that had happened since the thirty years' truce. it is the most probable; but the date of the Megarian decree is unfortunately doubtful, and some suppose, on insufficient evidence, that it was not passed so early as 433 B.C.
23. h( teleutai/a xa/ris—the service that Athens will render to Corinth by refusing the Corcyrean request. ‘This will be highly opportune, though involving a trifling sacrifice’ (Morris).
25. mei=zon e)/gklhma—the complaint that we have against you about Megara. (If the first explan. above is right, this e)/gklhma would be that Athens had violated the thirty years' truce.)

1. dia\ kindu/nwn — with e)/xein=e)pikindu/nws. Classen constructs to/ with ple/on, to which it is objected that ple/on e)/xein, not to\ ple/on e)/xein=pleonektei=n, be grasping; and hence Cl. proposed ti for to/. But dia\ ... e)/xein is a combination of two phrases:
(1) dia\ kindu/nwn th\n du/namin e)/xein,
(2) dia\ kindu/nwn ple/on e)/xein.

For (1) cf. vii. 8 to\ strato/pedon dia\ fulakh=s ma=llon h)\ di' e(kousi/wn kindu/nwn e)/xwn. The art. before ple/on is occasioned by the preceding du/namis. Stahl constructs to/ with e)/xein, but the position of the two members outside the article—tw=| ... e)parqe/ntas and dia\ k.—is against this.

2. peripeptwko/tes oi(=s ... kola/zein — the simplest explan. is ‘now that we find ourselves in the condition that we spoke of at Sparta, when we urged ...’ Thus oi(=s = e)kei/nois a(/, proei/pomen does double duty, ‘spoke of, and urged that’ and tou\s ... kola/zein is epexegetic. The only objection is that this is rather artificial. The condition alluded to is that of a city whose allies are in a:po/stasis, as Corinth holds that Corcyra is from her—dia\ panto\s a)festa=si. Stahl followed by Classen and others supplies peripeptwko/ta after
oi(=s, now that we find ourselves in the circumstances in which, as we ourselves urged ... This is doubtful giammar. Dobree bracketed tou\s ... kola/zein as spurious and repeated from c. 40: this gives an easy construction, and sfete/rous instead of e(autou=, with sing. au)to/n tina, is unusual.

18. th=| me\n prote/ra| — temporal, like ma/xh| th=| prw/th| vii. 11. e)n de\ th=| u(sterai/a|(e)kklhsi/a|) must mean in the assembly held on the following day, according to the meaning of such adjs. in -ai=os. Cobet read u(ste/ra|, in the subsequent assembly. We must assume that the assembly met on the next day when a debate was adjourned (and this seems to be the meaning of kai\ di/s). There is no evidence.
23. sfi/sin=toi=s *kerkurai/ois. au)toi=s =toi=s *)aqhnai/ois.
e)ke/leuon ... e)lu/ont' a)/n—the condition expressed from the point of view of Thuc. himself (Forbes).
25. e)pimaxi/an—a defensive (cummaxi/a, an offensive and defensive) alliance.
26. th=| a)llh/lwn—c. 15. 2.
1. kai\ w(/s—i.e. even if they rejected the Corcyrean request altogether. w(/s=ou(/tws often after kai/, a)ll' , ou)d', mh/d'.
6. nautiko\n e)/xousin—to be regarded as one word. Hence the insertion of toi=s before nautiko/n is unnecessary.
8. e)n para/plw|—contrast the construction at c. 36. 2.
14. *ki/mwnos—the great statesman. Plutarch says that he had given this name to his son out of compliment to Sparta.
18. e)kei/nwn=tw=n *kerkurai/wn.
22. pareskeu/asto—impers.
1. pe/mptos au)to/s—cf. c. 61. 1; 116. 1. The form of phrase denotes the chief in command.
2. kata/—opposite.

6. e)ci/hsi—of water discharging into the sea only in Thuc. and Herod. until Polybius. These geographical details remind us of a similar passage in 2.102. Mr. Forbes thinks
that Thuc. mentions the city because there was no town, but only a roadstead at Chimerium. But in the facts that follow there is no special significance, and it is more likely that we have here a trace of the manner of the logographers. Thuc., like them, is not averse to imparting information ‘by the way.’
8. e)sba/llei — the ordinary word in Attic in this sense is e)mba/llei.
10. e)/xei—sc. h( li/mnh.
r(ei=—sc. e)ntau=qa.
13. th=s h)pei/rou—partitive with a verb, as in a(/llh| th=s po/lews, etc.
20. parh=san—were there, not ‘arrived.’
au)toi=s—Thuc. has this curious order several times.
21. *zakunqi/wn—allies of Athens. The interest and policy of Zacynthus coincided with those of Corcyra.
24. para-bebohqhko/tes—along the coast; cf. para- plei=n.
27. triw=n h/merw=n siti/a—cf. triw=n mhnw=n misqo/s, o(/sou ei(=xon ta\ e)pith/deia, etc.
28. w(s e)pi/—both dat. and accus. are found in the same sense with this expression, and with a verb of motion the dat. occurs 3.4. 3; 6.34. 5.
5. to\ de\ a)/llo—the construction shifts.
7. tw=n—necessary, because of c. 47. 1. The object of the peculiar order is to draw e(ka/stou ei(=s together.
11. w(s e(/kastoi—cf. c. 3. 4.

12. tai=s a)/rista tw=n new=n pleou/sais—notice the order of the partitive gen.: the rule in Attic is that it is not placed in attributive position unless the last word is an adj. or partic., and even then it is rare except in Thuc.: the most exceptional instance of this order is 4.62 tou\s tw=n *sikelw=n (‘among the S.’) cumma/xous.

16. pollou\s me\n o(pli/tas—in the Peloponnesian War only ten e)piba/tai were on board; and it is specially noted (in the case of what battle?) in the seventh book as exceptional to have many fighting men on a trireme. But in the earlier sea-fights the
opposing ships were rowed alongside, and the battle was really ‘a land fight on sea.’
19. a)peiro/teron e)/ti—still with little experience of naval tactics.

21. te/xnh| — dat. of cause, ‘not so much because of the skill displayed, but for the most part (sc. kartera/) resembling a land engagement.’ The latter clause means it was like a stoutly contested land battle.
25. ma=llo/n ti — ‘considerably more.’ The phrase is common.
26. katasta/ntes —kaqi/sthmi means frequently ‘put into a (settled) state,’ with e)s: the intrans. ‘settle down.’ As the ships were motionless, a regular pitched battle was fought.

27. die/kploi—the famous manœuvre consisted of ‘rowing through the intervals of the enemy's linc, and thus getting in their rear, ... and before the ship of the adversary could change its position, of striking it either in the stern, or in some weak part’ (Grote). It is first heard of in Hdt. 6.12.
3. paragigno/menai—iterative.
5. ma/xhs ... h)=rxon—take the aggressive.
6. pro/rrhsin=a(\ proei/rhto.
10. spora/das—‘in confusion.
13. e)rh/mous—sc. ou)/sas: cf. Xen. Anab. 2.1.6 pe/ltai kai( a(/macai h)=san fe/resqai e)/rhmoi.
15. [te]—this joins the whole clause oi( *korinqioi ... h(ssw=nto to the second. It is scarcely necessary to bracket it.
18. a)po\ e)la/ssonos plh/qous—compare the total numbers, c. 46. 1; 47. 1.
24. e)gi/gneto—was beginning: better than e)ge/neto—the completion is first alluded to in c. 50. 1.
lamprw=s—decidedly. to/te dh/ introduces the decisive act.
26. cune/pesen—impers., ‘things came to such a pass.’
1. ta\ ska/fh me\n ktl.—all iterative, the imperfs. referring to the several huils disabled.

3. a(/s—when a rel. sentence stands for a substantive, no antecedent being expressed, Thuc. regularly attracts the rel., as in c. 37. 3 dikasta\s w(=n bla/ptousi. In 2.61 e)gkarterei=n a(\ e)/gnwte is for e)gkarterei=n e)kei=na (not e)kei/nois) a(\ e)/. But when a rel. sentence stands as an adjective, the rel. is not necessarily attracted; cf. e.g. c. 52. 2 ai)xmalw/twn ... ou(=s ... ei)=xon: 7.1. 2 etc. See n. on p. 87 l. 16.
katadu/seian—not sank, but ‘disabled.’ The usual way was to tow them away as prizes.

4. foneu/ein ... zwgrei=n — depending on e)tra/ponto as in e)tra/ponto ta\ pra/gmata e)ndido/nai 2.65. Thus e)tra/ponto has here a double construction. foneu/w is an Ionic word, not found in prose outside Herod. and Thuc.

diekple/ontes—the edd. point out that this cannot be the technical die/kplous—the object of which, indeed, was not to kill, but to disable an enemy's ship (see on c. 49)—but merely alludes to rowing in amongst the enemy's disabled ships.

6. oi( e)pi\ tw=| deciw=| ke/ra|—the Ambraciots and Megarians (c. 48. 4) who were defeated and pursued to the mainland (c. 49. 5). It is not possible to see how the conquering Corinthians on the left could have fallen in with any of the flying right wing unless some of those on the right wing had not fled with the rest towards the mainland; and that some were left behind is suggested by e)pi\ polu\ ... e)pexousw=n.
9. cune/meican—plup. in sense, and this clause belongs to what follows.

10. o(poi=oi—not much different from oi(/tines, but denoting, as Stahl points out, that there were no distinguishing marks of dress and appearance to show whether those they fell in with belonged to the winning or losing side. Cf. the common use of poi=os for ti/s in tragedy.
11. naumaxi/a ga/r—cf. c. 1. 2.
22. kai\ o(/sai—i.e. those that had taken no part in the previous engagement.
26. peirw=sin—only Herod. and Thuc. use the active where Attic generally has peirw=mai.
1. pru/mnan e)krou/onto—began to back, so as to retire; cf. a)nakrou/esqai with or without pru/mnan.
6. o)li/gai a)mu/nein — cf. 2.61 tapeinh\ u(mw=n h( dia/noia e)gkarterei=n; v. 3. 2 ta\ u(pa/rxonta braxe/a perigi/gnesqai.
7. u(potoph/santes—rare and poetical verb, used by Thuc. several times only in aor. inhn. or partic.
9. toi=s de\ *kerkurai/ois—dat. of agent, which Thuc. with the poets uses with all parts of the passive.
10. e)pe/pleon—sc. ai( *)attikai\ nh=es. With e)k tou= a)fanou=s supply au)toi=s, from a quarter where they were invisible.
12. pri/n—until: here and elsewhere the indic. is used after a positive sentence; but notice ou)x e(wrw=nto, and see M.T. 635.
13. e)kei=nai—yonder. Notice the vivid form.
16. h( a)pallagh\ e)ge/neto=a)phlla/ghsan.
17. e)teleu/ta e)s nu/kta—pregnant construction.

21. *(andoki/dhs—there is some donbt about the name, because an inscription relating to the expenses of this fleet is extant, and in it Glaucon is mentioned as strathgo/s, and two other names, both mutilated, are given (see crit. note); neither name can have been Andocides. However, if Andocides did hold some sort of command in this fleet, he is the grandfather of the orator Andocides. (My opinion is that the text is right, and that Thuc. has made a mistake here. If Andocides is the wrong name, Leogoras, too, must be due to corruption; and the double corruption seems very unlikely. If Andocides sen. had held this command, the orator would have alluded to the matter. He mentions that his grandfather had a hand in the thirty years' peace.)
26. w(rmi/santo—subject ‘the Athenian ships,’ the abrupt change being characteristic.
4. boulo/menoi — for this ‘sense’ construction after nh=es cf. 110. 4.
5. ta\s me\n nau=s—poetical construction with ai)/rw in this sense; elsewhere it is absol. or has tai=s nausi/n. Croiset compares ai)/rein sto/lon in tragedy.
12. e)piskeuh\n ou)k ou)=san—sc. o(rw=ntes, the two examples of ta\ a)/pora being given in different form.

13. tou= ... plou==peri\ tou= plou=, anticipating o(/ph| komisqh/sontai: the gen. placed thus at the head of a sentence with a verb
of speaking or thinking about is common in Plato; and the constn. comes down from epic. For trag. cf. Soph. OT 317, Trach. 169 tou= kasignh/tou ti/ fh/|s ; Plat. Rep. 576 D eu)daimoni/as w(sau/tws h)\ a)/llws pws kri/neis ;
18. a)/neu khrukei/ou—cf. c. 146. Had they sent him with a herald's wand they would have admitted a state of war, and treated the Athenians as enemies.
21. pole/mou a)/rxontes—acting as aggressors in war and breaking treaties: in reality the ref. is to the thirty years' treaty, but the vague expression heightens the effect.
26. lu/ete—we expect lu/ein. ei) d' nearly=e)pei\ de/.

1. tw=n de\ *kerkurai/wn—this is divided into to\ me\n strato/ pedon and oi( de\ *)aqhnai=oi, possibly because the Athenians and Corcyreans together make up the other, or Corcyrean, side; possibly by a slight anacoluthon.
2. o(/son—as far as they were within hearing.

16. ta/ te naua/gia kai\ nekrou/s—the te is answered by kai\ tropai=on a)nte/sthsan. The Corcyreans were able to recover their dead without asking permission. Hence, technically, they could support a claim to have won a success.
17. kata\ sfa=s—opposite them, i.e. ‘on their coast.’ The ta/ before kata/ makes tou\s nekrou/s unlikely.
18. (u(po\) a)ne/mou, o(/s—a wind which.
20. toi=s e)n th=| nh/sw| *subo/tois—Sybota must be the name of some place on one of the group of islands collectively called Sybota.

28. tria/konta nau=s—c. 49. 5: a)nelo/menoi c. 54. 1: o(/ti u(pexw/rhsan c. 51. 1: ou)k a)ntepe/pleon c. 52. 2. The claims put forward by the Corcyreans are set out in a formal style; notice esp. the repetition of e)peidh\ *)a. h)=lqon.
11. koino/n—in common. Corcyra must have had some share in the colonisation of Anactorium.
16. e)n qerapei/a| ei)=xon—treated them with great consideration, cf. qerapeu/w and qera/pwn. These prisoners returned in 427 B.C. and civil war broke out in Corcyra.
19. duna/mei—influence.
21. perigi/gnetai—not ‘defeated,’ but ‘maintained its ground.’ Corinth had not secured Epidamnus.
1. dia/fora—constituting matters of dispute leading to war.
2. prasso/ntwn o(/pws—forming plans of.
7. fo/rou u(potelei=s—c. 19.
8. to\ e)s *pallh/nhn — i.e. the southern wall (see map), so that Potidaea would be accessible from the sea.
10. e)pidhmiourgou/s —dhmiourgo/s is known from inscriptions to be the title of magistrates in many Dorian cities. e)pi- would mean chief magistrates exercising some sort of general supervision.

13. *perdi/kkou—Perdiccas II. of Macedon, son of Alexander the Philhellene. His shifty policy gave Athens much trouble in the Pel. War. Before 432 he was in alliance with Athens; but he presently encouraged Potidaea to revolt because Athens was in alliance with his brother Philip and his cousin Derdas. In 431 he was reconciled for a time to Athens.
14. e)pi\ *qra/|khs—prop. ‘in the direction of Thrace,’ the regular way of referring collectively to the Greek cities on the coast of Thrace, esp. Chalcidice.
15. tau=ta de\ ktl.—the battle ... had only recently been fought when the A... ...
19. fanerw=s h)/dh—their hatred of Athens is of earlier origin. See p. 38 l. 22 note.
21. e)pepole/mwto—c. 36. 1.

25. e)/s te pe/mpwn ... kai\ ... prosepoiei=to—the construction passes from the partic. to the finite verb. This form of anacoluthon is by no means confined to Thuc.; but cf. e.g. ii. 47. 3 lego/menon me\n ... ou) me/ntoi ... e)mnhmoneu/eto gene/sqai.
1. prosepoiei=to—tried to ... .
8. e)/tuxon ga/r introduces what follows, as in c. 31. 2.
10. au)tou=—Perdiccas.

11. de/ka—there would thus be eleven strathgoi/, and five more belonging to the same year are mentioned in c. 61. As the number of strathgoi/ was regularly ten, Kruger altered de/ka to tessa/rwn (d' ). But instead of met' a)/llwn tessa/rwn we expect pemptou= au)tou=. Perhaps Thuc. wrote only met' a)/llwn, and had no record of the number; cf. c. 51. 4.

20. [e)/prasson]—this spoils the structure of the period, for the principal sentence must begin at to/te dh/. There is, for example, a similar intrusion of a verb—metei=xon—in 2.16; e)/cestin in viii. 27.
22. e)k pollou=—for a long time.
23. ai( nh=es ai(—the ships that were to operate against M. were sent just as much against themselves. (c. 57. 6)
25. ta\ te/lh—c. 10. 4; cf. pan-telh/s, having full te/los.
27. kata\ to\n kairo\n tou=ton—this occurs after to/te dh/ again in 2.84.
4. a)noiki/sasqai—c. 7.
5. mi/an po/lin i).—predicate.

6. th=s e(autou= gh=s—partitive, with e)/dwke. th=s *mugdoni/as may be in apposition, but perhaps depends on peri\ th\n li/mnhn. The construction would be improved with ta/ before peri/, as ne/momai peri/ is unusual. ne/mesqai depends on e)/dwke: to cultivate and live from (Forbes).
14. a)festhko/ta—in a state of revolt.
16. cunafestw=ta—not ‘with Perdiccas,’ but ‘together.’
18. to\ prw=ton—this was their original purpose. The orders about Potidaea had been added subsequently.
20. a)/nwqen—from the upper country.
21. e)n tou/tw|—hereupon
24. peri/—common in Thuc. with dat. after verbs of fear, and this is usual in Attic. e)fobei=to peri\ tou= politikou= in viii. 93 is unusual.
27. tou\s pa/ntas—in all.
4. u(/steron ... h)/—cf. tou)nanti/on h)/. We might have e)pei/, e)peidh/, a)f' ou(= or o(/te in place of this. (h)/, not h(=|, is probably necessary. The confusion of the two is common.)
7. tw=n po/lewn—objective; cf. Antig. 11 mu=qos fi/lwn.

9. e)pipario/ntas — technical word of an army advancing on an objective. The force seems to have gone by land (e)piparo/ntas of the MSS. is almost certainly a blunder). Cf. Anab. III. IV. 30 kata\ to\ o)/ros e)pipario/ntes a)fi/konto ei)s ta\s kw/mas.
14. tou\s prote/rous—c. 57. 6.
15. *qe/rmh—Thessalonica.
16. proskaqezo/menoi—the form does duty as aorist; cf. c. 24. 7; p. 120 l. 5.
20. parelhluqw/s—the arrival of.

22. e)s *be/roian—Beroea is in Macedonia, and seems out of the route. Herbst proposed to read peraiwqe/ntes e)kei=qen for e)s *be/roian ka)kei=qen. The text cannot be regarded as certain. Grote thinks another Beroea, otherwise unknown, must be meant.

e)pi\ *stre/yan — this well-known conjecture for e)pistre/yantes suits excellently with peira/santes tou= xwri/ou, which with the MSS. reading gives no sense. The exact position of Strepsa is unknown; but no objection lies in the fact that it is not mentioned by Herod. in a list of Greek cities on the Thermaic Gulf (123), as it may very well have lain outside the limits with which Herod. is dealing.

6. pro\s *)olu/nqou—on the side towards Olynthus near Potidaea (=th=s po/lews). The other reading *)olu/nqw|, is inconsistent with 62.3, and as Jowett says, Aristeus cannot have left Potidaea unprotected.

8. e)/cw th=s po/lews — the plan of bringing the necessaries outside a city and selling them to troops encamped there was often adopted when it was desirable that the men should not go inside. We hear of it elsewhere in Thuc. and in the Anab.

14. tou= *)ariste/ws ... e)/xonti —e)/xonta (see crit. note) would be regular before the infin; but e)/xonti is likely to have been altered to this. The dat. is used as if e)/doce tw=| *)aristei= had
preceded. The only exact parallels cited for this are from Homer and tragedy; cf. Soph. OT 350 e)nne/pw se\ ... e)mme/nein ... w(s o)/nti. In order to avoid the change, tw=| me/n for to\ me/n agreeing with e)/xonti has been proposed; but the expression so produced (tw=| ... e)/xonti) is not very probable: we should expect au/tw=| me/n.
16. tou\s e)/cw i)sqmou=—the (other) allies from beyond the Istlimus (of Pallene). i)sqmo/s is treated as a proper name.
19. e)n me/sw| au(tw=n—i.e. himself being on their north side and the Chalcidians and Bottiaeans attackmg them from the city.
24. tou\s e)kei=qen—cf. c. 8. 2; 18. 1.
25. a)nasth/santes to\ s.—having broken up the camp at Gigonus.
1. cune/misgon — the battle of Potidaea. It was probably not in this battle that Socrates saved Alcibiades' life; but in another battle at Potidaea in 430 B.C.
4. loga/des—for the ordinary e)pile/ktoi, not used by other Attic prose writers. (Suidas, S.V. loga/dhn.)
to\ kaq' e(autou/s—the division that faced them.
5. e)pi\ polu/—of ground covered.
7. e)s to\ tei=xos—of Potidaea.
12. diakinduneu/sh|—deliberative. xwrh/sas with o(pote/rwse.
13. d' ou)=n—for MSS. gou=n: see the same correction at c. 10. 5. Here d' ou)=n suggests a hesitation on the part of Aristeus, the details of which Thuc. has omitted.
14 w(s e)s e)la/xiston xwri/on—i.e. to concentrate his division so that closely united it might force its way.

16. para\ th\n xhlh/n—the object is to enter Potidaea from the south, as it would have been risky with the enemy in the way to have forced a way in at the north. The xhlh/ is a mole or break-water running out into the sea, which at low tide is shallow, on the east side of the city.
18. a)pobalw/n—this is used specially of losing men by a sudden attack of an enemy.

19. a)pe/xei—sc. Olynthus; a)pei=xe (see crit note) would be a common use of imperf. in giving geographical details; cf.
e.g. 2.13 tou= ... tei/xous sta/dioi h)=san ktl.; many exx. from Anabasis is Kühner's n. on Anab. 1.4.9. Of course the pres. is also possible, and e)/sti favours it here. (The imperf. is equally used when the fact given implies the result of the writer's observation: so that it is not right to draw a distinction here.)
20. e)/sti—sc. the ground between the two cities.
22. h)/rqh—to summon the troops from Olynthus.
26. katespa/sqh—plup. in sense.
1. parege/nonto —e)n th=| ma/xh|.
6. *)aqhnai/wn de/—the inscription placed over the monument of these men in the Ceramicus is in the Brit. Mus.: Hicks, Manual, p. 59. The last of the three stanzas is:

p.foreign: *)/andras me\n po/lis h:/de poqei= kai\ dh=mos *)erexqe/ws, pro/sqe *poteidai/as oi(\ qa/non e)n proma/xois

div1.p: pai=des *)aqhnai/wn. yuxa\s d' a)nti/rropa qe/ntes h)lla/cant' a)reth/n—kai\ patri/d' eu)kle/i+san.
au)tw=n—Thuc. had not heard the numbers of the allies who fell.
7. e)k—cf. pro/s, which might have been used here, c. 62. 1.

8. tei=xos—this is deleted by Classen and others; but the sense is ‘they cut off (from communication with the north) the northern wall’—of course by building a wall farther north. See below 64.3. e)frou/roun is intrans.
10. a)tei/xiston—not ‘unfortified,’ which is not true (see c. 56. 2), but ‘not walled off,’ ‘not isolated’ from the south.
13. diaba/ntes—by sea.

14. genome/nois—the aor., though weakly supported, is necessary, ‘if they should have divided’ being clearly the sense. In 6.100 we have correctly fobou/menoi mh\ sfi/si di/xa gignome/nois r(a=|on ma/xwntai, because there the sense is ‘if they made a practice of.’
15. e)n th=| po/lei—at Athens.
18. *formi/wna—the celebrated admiral.
20. *)afu/tios—Ionic gen. of *)/afutis: cf.e.g. *th/rhs *th/rew 2.29.

23. a)petei/xise to\ ... tei=xos—the bracketing of tei=xos makes the sense ‘walled it off on the south side’; cf. to\ d' e)s th\n *pallh/nhn above 64.1 (where, however, tei=xos may be supplied). But ‘walled off the south wall’ may very well be the meaning as above in l. 8. Classen retains tei=xos here and renders ‘built across the south line of circum vallation.’ This is scarcely the meaning of a)poteixi/zw.
26. nausi\n a)/ma e)f.—with a fleet blockading it.
1. cunebou/leue ... h)/qele ... e)/peiqe — like e)ke/leue: such words being often used in imperf. when a speaker is giving advice.
3. a)/nemon thrh/sasi—cf. thrh/santes to\n porqmo/n 6.2.
6. ta\ e)pi\ tou/tois—cf. w(s e)pi\ tou/tois 6.45; vii. 45; ‘what was now necessary.’ Ar. Eccles. 82 ta)pi\ tou/tois dra/somen.
7. o(/pws also depends on paras keua/zein.
ta\ e)/cwqen — referring to what he could do for Potidaea when he got outside.
10. *sermuliw=n ... pollou/s—Sermyle on the west coast of Sithonia.
11. e)s ... e)/prassen—negotiated with; cf. e.g. pro\s o(\n e)/pracan 2.7.
12. o(/ph|=‘as to how.’
13. meta\ de/—now begins the costly siege of Potidaea.
18. ai)ti/ai me/n—answered by ou) me/ntoi. What follows shows that ai)ti/ai alludes only to the dispute about Potidaea—not to the affair of Corcyra as well.

prougege/nhnto — this (proe-), not prosegege/nhnto, is the reading of all good MSS. As the ref. is to Potidaea only we should expect either prosegege/nhnto had been added (to the Corcyrean dispute)—and this is read by many edd.—or ai)ti/ai me\n kai\ au(=tai: cf. c. 56. 1 kai\ ta/de cune/bh ... dia/fora. But prou- can stand; for now it is *)aqhnai/ois kai\ *peloponnhsi/ois, not merely *)a. kai\ *korinqi/ois. Thuc. clearly means that the Corcyrean affair did not constitute a ground of war with Pel. in generai; and now explains why the dispute about Potidaea was such, though even that was a matter for Corinth on her own account in the first instance. pro- means before Sparta took any part. Cf. c. 67. 1.
25. sfi/sin—with e)ma/xonto, not as in c. 13. 3; 27.1; 61.1 with e)lqo/ntes.
27. cunerrw/gei—currh/gnumi.
4. te—so.
pareka/loun — ‘invited,’ not by formal summons, which belonged to Sparta.
6. katebo/wn — with gen. ‘loudly accuse’; with accus., ‘shout down.’
7. sponda/s—c. 53. 2.
9. fanerw=s—they were dependent allies of Athens.
10. kru/fa—sc. presbeuo/menoi.
12. kata\ ta\s sponda/s—the thirty years' truce; nothing is known of this particular clause in it.

13. prosparakale/santes—thus supporting the Corinthian invitation. Steup renders ‘summoned before the assembly,’ holding that the embassies had already arrived in Sparta as the result of the Cor. invitation. This is impossible, unless we alter the text to proskale/santes: see c. 87. 4.

tw=n cumma/xwn te—partitive; edd. generally omit te and make tw=n cumma/xwn depend on ei)/ tis(kai/=‘also’). If te is sound, then ei)/ tis must mean any one else in the position of Aegina: no other state outside the Pel. alliance seems to have sent; see c. 69. 1; 87. 4.

14. a)/llo—besides those wrongs alleged by Corinth and Aegina. Some accept Reiske's a)/llos with or without the te. The invitation is to all who hold that in their case Athens had in any particular broken the thirty years' truce.
15. poih/santes—called.
20. ei)/rgesqai—see c. 139.
24. e)pei=pon—added to what the others had said.

25. to\ pisto/n—honesty, the good faith you show in your public and private life. This is the outcome of the ‘Lycurgean’ system. Cf. what Xen. says in the Polity of the Lac., of their virtues, which, when he wrote, were a thing of the past: ‘They endeavoured to be worthy to lead ... Others would go to Sparta and ask to be led by her against those who
were thought guilty of wrong-doing... . Nowadays they obey neither God nor the ordinances of Lycurgus.’
26. kaq' u(ma=s au)tou/s—among yourselves.
27. a)pistote/rous e)s tou\s a)/llous—i e e)s(h(ma=s)tou\s a)/llous, hence le/gwmen. Some, however, take e)s tou\s a)/llous h)/n ti l. together=‘if we bring any charge against others.’

28. a)p' au)tou=—i.e. a)po\ tou= a)pistote/rous ei)=nai. It is a mark of prudence or sobriety, but it leads you into more mistakes than you would make if you were less cautious in believing complaints.
5. tw=n lego/ntwn=(to/de)tw=n lego/ntwn, so that the w(s clause governs tw=n legontwn, cf. c. 52. 3. The gen. is often similarly used with qauma/zw.

6. tw=n ... diafo/rwn—private interests, i e. the interests of their city apart from the interests of the Pel. confederacy. i)di/a| does not mean individual here. For such complaints to Sparta see c. 90, and for the negligence of Sparta see c. 118. 2.
7. pa/sxein—we begin to ...

9. e)n oi(=s—(1) some render, ‘before whom’; cf. e.g. c. 85; (2) others, after Classen, with ou)x h(/kista, and we among them have the best right, as in viii. 68 e)n toi=s cugkatalu/ousi ... prw=tos h)=n. The latter suits the passage better.
10. o(/sw|—inasmuch as; the kai/ balances me/gista with ou)x h(/kista. We should render ‘inasmuch as ... , we have also the greatest right.’
15. ei)do/si—sc. u(mi=n.

16. makrhgorei=n, w(=n — most edd. supply h(ma=s (=tou\s cumma/xous). And tou\s me/n is then explained as Aegina; but how can Aegina be included under the cu/mmaxoi of Sparta? See c. 67. 3 ei)/ tis. It is on all grounds better to understand w(=n as for e)pei\ e)kei/nwn (i.e. tw=n *(ellh/nwn from th\n *(ella/da) with Conradt who is followed by Steup. Thus tou\s me/n naturally refers to the subject allies of Athens, against whom it was a constant complaint that she ‘enslaved the Greeks.’
18. h(mete/rois c.—Potidaea and her allies in Chalcidice: since they had revolted from Athens, they are reckoned as allies of Corinth.
19. propareskeuasme/nous—the relative is now lost sight of.
polemh/sontai—pass., ‘shall become involved in war.’
20. u(polabo/ntes—a gross misrepresentation.
23. a)poxrh=sqai—to make full use of (as a base of operations) in dealing with ... . (Poppo's view that au)toi=s=toi=s e)pi\ *q is to be supplied to a)poxrh=sqai is clearly wrong.)
27. kratu=nai ktl.—see cc. 90 and 107.
28. e)s to/de=me/xri tou=de.
1. a)posterou=ntes — a good ex. of the proper meaning, ‘withhold’ what belongs to another.
tou\s u(p' e)kei/nwn d.—the subject allies of Athens; see c. 68. 3. Sparta in the Pel. War claimed to be the ‘liberator of Greece.’ She had gained the reputation by her opposition to the tu/rannoi.

2. tou\s u(mete/rous - the plain meaning is that A. has begun to act aggressively towards Megara and Corinth. (Perhaps h(mete/rous used loosely as in c. 68. 3 is right here—see crit. note —or u(mete\rous should be read there.)
5. au)to\ dra=|—c. 5. 2.
th\n a)ci/wsin ... fe/retai—enjoys a reputation for generosity —lit. that, i.e. her, reputation ..., gained by such actions.
7. mo/lis de\ nu=n ge — see crit. note. If we assume a transposition for a)lla\ nu=n te mo/lis cun. kai\ ktl. the te might stand; but ge is certainly idiomatic here.
8 e)pi\ faneroi=s—with a clear issue before us. xrh=n ga/r explains this clause.

10. oi( ga\r drw=ntes ktl.—a notoriously difficult sentence. The transl. ‘for they who act advance with plans already formed and without delaying, against men who have not made up their minds,’ in ref. to Athenian energy, is simple; but the statement is not true when made universal, and we certainly look for a direct ref. to the Athenians (hence the conjectures oi(/ ge, oi(/per, oi( ga\r *)aqhnai=oi for oi( ga/r). Classen rendered oi( ga/r as ‘for they,’ like oi( de/, i.e. the Athenians, but himself doubted it; there is no prose ex. of o( before ga/r as pronoun, and more important, it is very artificial to separate drw=ntes. I should like to refer this general statement, with the transl. given above, to the conduct of the Lac., so that the general sense is ‘men of action (which you are not) take immediate steps, with their
minds made up before their opponents are resolved on their course.’ The Athenians have not yet decided on war, and now is your time skopei=n kaq' o(/ ti a)munou/meqa. It is a case for to\ proepibouleu/ein, not to\ a)ntepibouleu/ein. I think that oi( *)aqhnai=oi in the next sentence strongly favours my suggestion, as we then get a proper antithesis.

12. oi(/a| o(dw=| ... kai\ o(/ti kat' o)li/gon—the two clauses after e)pista/meqa are differently expressed: we should say rather, ‘we know that the A. are encioaching on others and how they do it.’ (The sentence is awkwaid: Cobet bracketed kai\ o(/ti. Possibly something is lost alter *)aqhnai=oi.)
15. oi)o/menoi—while they think, as they do at present. When they conclude that you know, but do not care, ‘they will press on with determination,’ and no longer kat' o)li/gon.
19. th=| mellh/sei—intentions=tw=| me/llein a)mu/nasqai.
21. diplasioume/nhn—see c. 123. 6; mind the tense. du/namin is evidently a gloss on the nnusual au)/chsin, for which, as applied to Athens, see c. 89. 1.

22. a)sfalei=s—sure, though slow; cf. Soph. OT 617, cited in L. & S, fronei=n ga\r oi( taxei=s ou)k a)sfalei=s. (In all other places in Thuc. a)sfalh/s=‘secure,’ but that is no reason why it should not mean sure here: he must have known of this meaning!)
w(=n=a)ll' u(mw=n.

o( lo/gos tou= e)/rgou e)kra/tei — so 2.42 ou)k a)\n polloi=s ... i)so/rropos ... o( lo/gos tw=| e)/rgw| fanei/h, there are but few cases in which report does not outweigh fact. o( lo/gos u(mw=n=‘the report about you,’ your reputation; cf. p. 52 l. 7.
24. e)k pera/twn gh=s—proverbial of remote countries.
pro/teron h)/ with infin., a rare constn. except in Herod. Thuc., Antiphon.
25. ta\ par' u(mw=n—your forces.
28. e)pelqei=n au)toi/—together: so bou/lesqe ma=llon.
1. e)s tu/xas k.—expose yourselves to the chances of war.
2. dunatwte/rous—sc. than they were.

3. peri\ au(tw=| ... sfale/nta—cf. 6.33. 5 ka)\n peri\ sfi/sin au)toi=s ta\ plei/w ptai/wsin: Aristoph. Pax 905 peri\ tai=si kam-
pai=s ... peptwko/tes: Soph. Ajax 828 peptw=ta tw=|de peri\ neorra/ntw| ci/fei.
4. ta\ plei/w—sc. than through you.
5. h(ma=s—we, your allies. Thuc. is referring to the thirty years' tince, which was a set-back to Athens for the time being.
7. u(me/terai—in you, of help from you.
8. kai\ a)paraskeu/ous—kai/ is explained by its correspondence with dia\ to\ pisteu=sai: because they had confidence in Sparta, they remained also (as a consequence) unprepared (E. Chambry).
9. e)/fqeiran—gnomic.
10. e)p' e)/xqra| to\ ple/on h)\ ai)ti/a|—to show our enmity, but rather to complain.

12. fi/lwn. e)xqrw=n—objective. ai)ti/a in this second sentence=to\ e)p' ai)ti/a| le/gein, but e)/xqra is not equivalent to to\ e)p' e)/xqra| le/gein, so Thuc. substitutes kathgori/a, which is. The habit of defining terms, common in Thuc., is, as Croiset remarks here, derived from Prodicus of Ceos, who gives a well-known specimen of his skill in this line in the Protagoras. Demosth. imitates this passage, Androt. 22.
a(martano/ntwn—milder than a(marto/ntwn.
14. a)/cioi—have a right.

16. a)/llws te kai/—this clause must give a reason for the claim just made, and this can only be if diafero/ntwn here= ‘the interests’ at stake, and not ‘differences’ between you and Athens. But diafe/rontas presently has the other sense.
20. u(mw=n with diafe/rontas.
kai\ w(s—kai/ is ‘nay’ or ‘in fact.’
21 newteropoioi/ ktl.—we have echoes of this famous comparison in Demosth.
22. e)pinoh=sai o)cei=s—cf. Dem. Ol. 3, 15 gnw=nai pa/ntwn u(mei=s o)cu/tatoi.
24. sw/|zein—sc. o)cei=s. sarcastic.
e)pignw=nai—adopt further measures beyond a resolution to preserve what you have got.
ou)de\ ta)nagkai=a—contrast e)pignw=nai mhde/n. The last clause =kai\ ou)k o)cei=s e)ste e)/rgw| ou)de\ t. e)c. By ta)nagkai=a he means what will just do.

26. para\ gnw/mhn—gnw/mh here and below prob.=‘judgment,
forethought’: the A. are ever taking risks that their judgment forbids them to venture on; you hesitate to follow the sure indications of your judgment. There is an evident allusion to the favourite contrast between gnw/mh and tu/xh.
28. eu)e/lpides—m Ar. Av. Euelpides personifies the venturesome character of Athenians.
4. kai\ mh/n in oratory draws attention to a new and striking point, ‘then again.’
5. e)ndhmota/tous—a marked trait in the Spartan character which was much modified by the Pel. War; though for a long time S. was deficient in vigour in the war.
7. tw=| e)pelqei=n — ‘aggression.’ There is no need to read e)celqei=n; cf. 70.7, and the eontrast is as old as the Odyssey; p 27 ou) me\n ga/r ti qa/m' a)gro\n e)pe/rxeai ... | a)ll' e)pidhmeu/eis.
9. e)ce/rxontai ... a)napi/ptousin—explained (by Bonitz) as a metaphor from boxing: to follow up an advantage) (to be forced back—celerique elapsus vulnere cessit Aen. 5.445.

10. toi=s me\n sw/masin ... th=| de\ gnw/mh|—the points of this rhetorical passage are two: (1) the A. give their lives just as much as the S. for their city, but the A. regard their lives as of little worth, while the S. devote themselves entirely to the care of the body as the most precious thing they can offer to their city; (2) the A. use their intelligence in the service of their city, and for that end they cultivate their minds, whereas the S. neglect them. Thuc. has obscured his meaning by introdueing a contrast between a)llotriw/tatos not their own (but of course belonging to their city) and oi)keio/tatos nearest and dearest to them. The Spartans too gave their lives for their city, but they regarded them as oi)keio/tatos.
