13. a(\ me\n a)/n—i.e. when they do not carry out a new plan they have hit upon, they regard the failure as a loss of something that belongs to them.
15. pro\s ta\ me/llonta—in comparison with what is to be done.
16. tuxei=n pra/cantes—that in reality they have done, a very eommon meaning of tugxa/nw with partic.: e.g. Plat. Gorg. p. 468 D oi/o/menos a)/meinon ei)=nai, tugxa/nei de\ o)\n ka/kion.
tou kai\ pei/ra| s.—if they fail too in anything they attempt. kai/ (in ref. to a(\ a)\n e)pelqo/ntes kth/swntai) emphasises the phrase.
17. e)plh/rwsan—iterative.
18. mo/noi ga/r—possession and desire, ‘have’ and ‘hope’ overlap, so impetuous are these Athenians.

20. kai\ tau=ta ktl.—imitated by Dem. de Cor..203 (Athens) a)gwnizome/nh peri\ prwtei/wn kai\ timh=s kai\ do/chs kinduneu)ousa pa/nta to\n ai)w=na diatete/leke. (A misuse of the poetical ai)w/n is that of Polus te/xnh ap. Plat. Gorg. init.) It is a fine stroke of style that at the end of the contrast here, the antithesis is dropped and Athens alone is spoken of.

24. e(orth/n—predicate. It is not likely that there is any ref here, as the Schol. who is followed by some edd. supposes, to the refusal of Sparta to set out for war during festivals. The passage is hyperbolical, and is spoiled by making it too precise. mh/te and te correspond
25. ou)x h(=sson ... h)/=ma=llon h)/.
1. e)a=n—sc. h(suxi/an e)/xein.
3. tau/ths—subject: toiau/ths po/lews pred., lit. this (city) that is opposed to you being such a city.
4. diame/llete—persist in ... .

5. oi)/esqe ktl.—you think that peace lasts longest not for those who in using their forces confine themselves to what is right, but (none the less) by their resolution show that, if wronged, they will not put up with it: instead of that, you deal out fair treatment with the object of not annoying others and, where you defend yourselves, of avoiding harm to yourselves. (1) to\ i)/son ne/mete represents di/kaia pra/ssete with slight modification: ‘fair treatment to you means (a) not provoking others and (b) overlooking a wrong if you find that self-defence will entail suffering on you.’ (2) e)pitre/pein as practised by Sparta is explained as an attempt mh\ lupei=n te ... bla/ptesqai. (All other explanations seem (1) to render a)muno/menoi mh\ b as if it were mh\ a). b, (2) to strain the meaning of to\ i)/son ne/mete: ne/mw is not ‘control’ here; cf. p. 103 l. 25.
9. a)ll' e)pi\ ktl.—there is anacoluthon here, since strictly we ought to have a)ll)(e)kei/nois)oi(\ a)\n ... ne/mwsi corresponding to ou) tou/tois ktl But the ehange greatly heightens the effect.
11. mo/lis d' a)/n—even if A. were as conservative as you, it would be almost impossible mh\ lupei=n te a)/llous kai\ au)toi\ a)muno/menoi mh\ bla/ptesqai.
12. nu=n de/—but in fact.
14. pro\s au)tou/s—as compared with theirs.
w(/sper ktl. — full form: w(/sper te/xnhs (‘in an art’) ta e)pigigno/mena (‘what is new’) kratei=n a)na/gkh, ou(/tw kai\ e)pithdeuma/twn ktl te/xnhs is possessiie, with ta\ e).
16. ta\ a)ki/nhta no/mima—alluding to the conservative no/mima of Lycurgus: ta/de ... kate/sthsen o( *lukou=rgos e)n th=| *spa/rth| no/mima Xen. Lac. Pol. 7. 1.
17. pro\s polla\ ... i)e/nai—those on whose resources there are many demands need constantly to think out new devices; cf. e)pitexna=sqai, plan something untried before, Herod. 2.2. 3; 119. 2.
20. e)pi\ ple/on u(mw=n—more than yours; cf. l. 14.
me/xri ... tou=de w(ri/sqw — cf. Aeschin. 3.24 me/xri tou=de ei)rh/sqw moi so far and no farther, ‘let this be the limit of.’ Strictly we have a fusion of—
(1) ‘So far let your slowness have proceeded,’
(2) ‘Here let your slowness end.’
Cf. on p. 69 l. 26.
22. u(pede/casqe—see c. 58. 1.
26. e(te/ran—i.e. pro\s tou\s *)argei/ous, says the Scholiast. Such an alliance was formed between Corinth and Argos in 421 B.C.
28. pro/s—in the eyes of.

29. tw=n ai)sqanome/nwn—intelligent men. The rendering ‘men who take notice of our actions’ does not suit the context. All Greece must ‘note’ an alliance formed by Corinth; not any special part of Greece; but a)nqrw/pwn tw=n ai)sqanome/nwn could hardly mean tw=n *(ellh/nwn here. Those who look below the surfaee of things will not eondemn Corinth. ai)sqa/nomai is abs., as in 5.26 ai)sqano/menos th=| h(liki/a|. That this limitation of a)nqrw/pwn does not stand in the same relation to the noun as tw=n o(rki/wn stands to qew=n is not a valid objection in Thuc.
1. e)rhmi/an—isolation.
a)/llois—in quest of an alliance.
2. oi(=s a)\n cunomo/swsi — the parties to a cummaxi/a have ‘the same friends and enemies’: hence the point.
3. menou=men—remain firm, pregnant sense fixed by u(mw=n.
5. cunhqeste/rous — sc. u(mw=n (not u(mw=n proqu/mwn o)/ntwn, as with ou)/te ga\r ktl.).
7. mh\ e)la/ssw—proleptic. e)chgou=mai of exercising h(gemoni/a in a league appears to take aceus. or dat.
9. tw=n de\ *)aqhnai/wn e)/tuxe ga/r—cf. c. 115. 4; viii. 30. The gen. follows the constn. of the clause immediately following, and this produces a confusion of constn. between
oi( d' *)a. (e)/tuxon ga\r ... parou=sa)w(s h)/|sqonto and tw=n d' *)a. e)/tuxe presbeia parou=sa kai w(s h/|sqonto.
The anacoluthon is lessened by deleting kai/, but it is only a matter of degree.
13. parithte/a—Thuc. alone among prose writers affects this use of the plur. neut. of the verbal adj.; cf. c. 79 etc.
14. e)gklhma/twn — cf. c. 67. 4. The Athenians saw that their business was to answer the Corinthian's speech. See Intr. p. XXXV.
16. dhlw=sai de/—if this were expressed as strictly parallel to the me/n clause, we should have dhlw/sontas de/.
17. e)n ple/oni—of time, like e)n me/sw|, e)n o(/sw| etc.
24. proselqo/ntes—to the ephors; contrast parelqo/ntes below.

26. ei)/ ti mh\ a)pokwlu/oi—this is the reading of the Laurentian, and its evidence in such a point outweighs all the other MSS. The confusion between the forms of indic. subj. and opt. is continually met with in MSS.; this passage does not stand on the same footing as 6.21 where ei) custw=sin is the only reading.
1. a)ntilogi/an toi=s — the dat. following the constn. of a)ntile/gw, as in e/pi/plous th=| *peloponnh/sw| etc.
7. ou)/te h(mw=n ou)/te tou/twn—prob. to be taken with oi( lo/goi. The emphasis is on dikastai=s: we are not in a court of law.
11. tou= e)s h(ma=s kaqestw=tos—the general line of argument that is used against us.
16. a)koai\ ... lo/gwn—hearsay.

18. ei) kai\ di' o)/xlou ma=llon e)/stai ai)ei\ proballome/nois— ‘even if it will prove an annoyance to you to have them continually brought before you.’ proballome/nois, sc. u(mi=n, is personal pass., cf. c. 126. 11; 140. 1; the act. would be
proba/llomen tau=ta u(mi=n. (To supply h(mi=n, as many edd. do, produces a sense inconsistent with what follows, esp. tou= de\ lo/gou mh\ panto\s steriskw/meqa. There is no need to read proballo/mena with Classen; and to place the comma after e)/stai, as I formerly proposed to do, is no improvement.)

21. e)kinduneu/eto—impersonal. ‘It was to help the cause that we faced danger’—it was not filoniki/a (ni/kh) that prompted us. e)p' w)feli/a| is intentionally vague, because the speaker is to emphasise the share that the Peloponnesians received; cf. c. 74. 3.
tou= e)/rgou—the reality) (tou= lo/gou the mention of it, ‘reference to it,’ when such reference is opportune for us.
24. marturi/ou—evidence (not ‘protest’).
25. u(mi=n with katasth/setai.

27. prokinduneu=sai tw=| b. — ‘stand forward,’ ‘bear the brunt of battle against,’ as a pro/maxos. Demosth. brings in prokinduneu/w in the famous oath in de Cor. 208 ma\ tou\s *maraqw=ni prokinduneu/santas ktl.: he probably had this passage in mind.

3. a)duna/twn a)
 o)/ntwn — masc.=oi(\ (sc. oi( *peloponnh/sioi from th
 *p.) a)du/natoi a)
 h)=san (Mr. Forbes takes a)duna/twn o)/ntwn as neut., like plwimwte/rwn o)/ntwn c. 7, ei)saggelqe/ntwn c. 116— where see notes—as if we had a)du/naton a(
 o)/n. This will not do).
6. o(moi/as—sc. kai\ (‘as’) pri\n naumaxh=sai (not ‘equal to the Greek’).
8. a)nexw/rhsen—cf. c. 118. 2.
toiou/tou ktl.—cf. c. 71. 1.
9. dhlwqe/ntos—cf. c. 76. 2.
e)n tai=s nausi\ ... e)ge/neto—cf. e.g. Soph. OT 314 e)n soi\ ga/r e)smen.
13. cunetw/taton—again of Themistocles in c. 138; cf. 6.39 fhmi\ ... bouleu=sai a)\n be/ltista tou\s cunetou/s. to\ suneto\n o( qeo\s di/dwsin says Euripides.

14. e)s ta\s tetrakosi/as—to make up the total of 400. Herod. gives 378 as the total, Aeschylus (Pers. 339) 310; cf. Dem. de Cor..238 triakosi/wn ou)sw=n tw=n pasw=n, ta\s diakosi/as h( po/lis pare/sxeto. Herod. also puts the number provided by Athens at 200. There is therefore an exaggeration here. (Some edd. read triakosi/as.)
15. tw=n du/o moirw=n—in fractions when the denominator exceeds the numerator by 1, the larger number is omitted; cf. c. 10.

16. ai)tiw/tatos naumaxh=sai—instead of tou= n., as Antiphon v. 23 e)gw\ ai)/tios h)=n pemfqh=nai a)/ggelon. When the Peloponnesians in the fleet wanted to retreat to the Isthmus, Them. sent a false message to Xerxes to the effect that now was his chanee to destroy the Greeks. The king then attacked the Greeks from the south. See on p. 121 l. 23.

17. kai\ au)to/n—dia\ tou=to=di' o(/ after o(/per: see c. 10. 3 (or au)toi/—sce erit. note, ‘you yourselves admitted how great a service he had rendered’). Cf. Herod. 8.33 of the visit of Them. to Sparta, mou=non dh\ tou=ton pa/ntwn a)nqrw/pwn ... *spartih=tai proe/pemyan.
18. a)/ndra c.—though ... tw=n ... e)lqo/ntwn with ma/lista. Them. was presented with an olive wreath and a chariot at Sparta, and was escorted to the frontier by 300 mounted Spartans.
20. oi(/ ge—quippe qui.
22. douleuo/ntwn—Greeks used dou=loi esp. of the subjects of the Great King.
2. tou/tou—sc. tou= u(f' u(mw=n w)felei=sqai. ou)x h(=sson ... h)/= ... ma=llon h)/.
u(mei=s me\n ga/r—the ref. is to the tardy dispatch of the Spartan army under Pausanias to Boeotia in 479 B.C.

3. a)po/ te oi)koume/nwn—from your cities that were undisturbed) (a)po\ th=s ou)k ou)/shs e)/ti(po/lews): e)pi\ tw=| to\ loipo\n n., ‘with the object of occupying them in the future’) (u(pe\r th=s ... ou)/shs, which there was but little hope of recovering. (Some following the Schol. see in po/lis a reference to the Athenian navy; this is only artificial and does not give a clear antithesis to e)pi\ tw=| ne/mesqai.)

9. to\ me/ros—cf. c. 127. 2, like to\ so\n me/ros, tou)mo\n me/ros in tragedy. ‘Did our part in rescuing you as well as ourselves.’ The emphasis is on u(ma=s, and there is a contrast with u(pe\r u(mw=n kai\ ou)x h(mw=n to\ ple/on of l. 5.
11. w(/sper kai\ a)/lloi=w(/sper kai\ a)/lloi dei/santes pros., as others did.
13. w)s—regarding ourselves as.
ou)de\n a)\n e)/dei e)/ti—because it would have been of no use.
15. kaq' h(suxi/an—without interference.
17. a)=ra=nonne.
18. gnw/mhs—resolve, sc. th=s to/te: the gen. is governed by cune/sews.
19. a)rxh=s depends on e/pifqo/nws diakei=sqai = fqonei=sqai. For the point see c. 96.
23. paramei=nai pro\s ta\ u(po/loipa tou= b.—remain at your post to attack what was left of the power of the Persians. See c. 95. 7; 96. 1; Herod. vir. 107.
26. e)/rgou—the fact of accepting the h(gemoni/a.
28. u(po\ de/ous—fear of the Persians. timh=s—the honour enjoyed by Athens when she had once accepted the h(gemoni/a. w)feli/as —interest.
1. kai\ ou)k a)sfale/s takes up to\ prw=ton: when we had acquired this power it was necessary to guard it.
2. kai/ tinwn ktl. = kai\ e/pei/ tines kai\ a)posta/ntes h)/dh katestramme/noi h)=san.
5. u(po/ptwn—there seems to be no advantage in rendering ‘suspieious’ here in preference to ‘suspected.’
6. pro\s u(ma=s—i.e. now that you were no longer friendly to us, our allies would have taken to revolting to you.
8. tw=n megi/stwn pe/ri k.—when the greatest dangers are involved.
eu)= ti/qesqai—cf. c. 25. 1; to manage well matters that are for their interest.
9. u(mei=s gou=n—an example of the principle just stated.
10. e)pi\ ... katasthsa/menoi—referring to the oligarchies; see c. 19.
12. e)chgei=sqe—governs ta\s po/leis.
to/te—in the Persian War.
13. a)ph/xqhsqe—had become unpopular, cf. c. 75. 2. This is better than a)ph/xqesqe, had been hated.
14. eu)= i)/smen mh/—mh/ generally with a verb expressing confident belief impressed on others.
15. guphrou/s—severe.
18. a)po\ tou=—like a)po\ tou= pra/gmatos Dem. 24.6.
19. didome/nhn—when it was offered.
21. triw=n—cf. c. 74. 1, and so 3.40. The conjecture is however scarcely certain, though elegant. See c. 75. 3.
24. kaqestw=tos—abs. like dhlwqe/ntos c. 74. 1 (not governed by u(pa/rcantes), ‘it being established by precedent.’
25. a)/cioi/ te—the te joins the clause to what precedes, and does not belong to the kai/ following.
26. dokou=ntes—imperf.

me/xri ou(= ... nu=n = me/xri nu=n o(/te (Croiset): ‘when, while (really) thinking of expediency, you profess to argue from justice.’ So in Bk. v. in the Melian dialogue to\ cumfe/ron is opposed to to\ di/kaion, and cf. the Corcyrean speech. o( di/kaios(a)/dikos)lo/gos = ‘the argument from justice (injustice)’; you tell us what we ought to do, but really think of your own interest.
1. paratuxo/n—when there was an opportunity; to proqei/s supply th=s i)sxu/os.
2. tou= mh/—cf. c. 10. 1.
4. dikaio/teroi h)\ kata/—cf. c. 37. 3

6. ge/nwntai after oi)/tines: if this is the true reading — see crit. note—we have an instance of the epic and Ionie usage. See Goodwin M.T. 540. The only other ex. of pure subj. with o(/s in Thuc. is 4.17 ou(= me\n braxei^s a)rkw=si, which is thought to be from a gnomie poet.
g' a)\n ou)=n = gou=n a)/n.
ta\ h(me/tera labo/ntas = ei) e)/labon th\n h(mete/ran i)sxu/n.
8. e)k tou= e)pieikou=s—i.e. e)k tou= metria/zein.

11. kai\ e)lassou/menoi ga/r—an ex. to show how Athens got a bad name as the result of her moderation. ‘For though in suits arising out of contracts against our allies we are at a disadvantage and in our own city have instituted courts for these cases under equal laws (i.e. laws under which they and we are treated alike), we are considered litigious.’ cumbo/laiai d.
is probably from cumbo/laion, a contract, and not from cu/mbolon, a treaty, di/kai a)po\ sumbo/lwn were suits arising out of international treaties; but (1) it is not clear that Athens had such su/mbola with the u(ph/kooi, and (2) it is most improbable that in all such suits an Athenian had to sue in the courts of the subject state. It is known that di/kai a)po\ sumbo/lwn were tried in the court of the defendant's state. If we assume that di/kai e)mporikai/, commercial suits, which were tried in the state in which the contract was made, are referred to, the passage becomes clear. An Athenian litigant in the courts of the u(ph/kooi is in an unfavourable position, whereas u(ph/kooi in the courts at Athens are treated exactly like Athenians. Some think that poih/santes ta\s kri/seis refers to the compulsory jurisdiction at Athens in certain criminal cases, when a subject ally was involved. But even when both parties were u(ph/kooi such cases were tried at Athens, whereas Thuc. is speaking only of cases in which one party was an Athenian: so supply e)n tai=s ... di/kais in the second clause. In these latter cases the allies considered that they were badly treated. ([Xen.] Ath. Pol. 1.16 tou\s me\n tou= dh/mou sw/|zousi, tou\s d' e)nanti/ous a)pollu/ousin e)n toi=s dikasthri/ois. On the difficulties surrounding the judicial arrangements of the Athenian League see Holm, Hist. of Greece 2.217, Engl. Transl.)
13. o(moi/ois—contrast with e)lassou/menoi. kri/sin poiei=n = institute a trial.

18. dio/ti—why. The reason why others in our position do not go to law is that they use force. Mr. Forbes points out that the Persians, Scythians, and Carthaginians are instanced as ruling powers by Socrates in Xen. Mem. 1.1.11.
19. oi( de/—but they.
21. para\ to\ mh\ oi)/esqai xrh=nai —mh/ with x., contrary to their opinion that it is wrong that they should be deprived.

h)\ gnw/mh| h)\ ktl.—either by a decision (in our courts) or through the power we enjoy on account of our Empire. This passage refers not only to defeats of allies in the Athenian courts, but to cnrtailments of their rights (duna/mei ktl.).
24. tou= e)ndeou=s—at their (slight) inferiority. The gen. after xalepw=s fe/rein as in 2.62. 3 probably, unless sterisko/menoi is to be supplied.
25. a)po\ prw/ths—cf. c. 15. 3. Perhaps o(rmh=s or a)rxh=s originally completed the phrase.
to\n no/mon—law in general.
3. biazo/menoi—pass. as often in Thuc. and trag.

to\ me\n ktl.—the one (to\ a)dikei=sqai) seems to be an act of over-reaching where both are equal, the other an act of compulsion where one is stronger. The infins. are impersonal. i)/sou and krei/ssonos are neut.

8. ei)ko/tws belongs only to h( de\ h(mete/ra ktl., and is added as an afterthought, the general sense being: ‘It is inconsistent that they should chafe at our empire when they endured worse from the Persians, but it is not strange; for’ etc. The Persian power too was baru/, but they had to put up with that.
10. a)/rcaite—ingressive, ‘gain an empire.’
11. eu)/noian—good-will, which at present they enjoyed as professed ‘liberators’ (2.9. 4).
h(me/teron—c. 33. 3

12. oi(=a ... o(moi=a—measures like those of which you gave some examples. di' o)li/gou, for a short time. For the conduct of the Spartans as leaders, esp. for the hatred excited by Pausanias, see cc. 94 f.
14. gnw/sesqe—are going to adopt.
15. a)/meikta ... toi=s a)/llois—i.e. toi=s tw=n a)/llwn n. For no/mima see c. 71. 5.
17 e)ciw/n—when he goes abroad Xen. Lac. Pol. also speaks of the change for the worse in the Spartan when he left home to assume a command.
oi(=s with nomi/zei = xrh=tai, an Ionic use.
19. ou) braxe/wn—no trifling matters.
22. pro/sqhsqe—assume, ‘take upon yourselves,’ cf. c. 144. 1. 4; Eur. Her. 146 i)/dia prosqe/sqai kaka/.
24. filei= e)s tu/xas ... perii/stasqai—is wont to turn out at last a series of chances, from which we (you and we) are equally remote (i.e. we cannot see into them).

26. e)n a)dh/lw| k.—depends on what is hidden. The ordinary phrase would be e)n a)dh/lw| e)sti/, and so we have a compression of e)n a). e)sti\ kai\ kinduneu/etai. For this kind of expression cf. vii. 77 e)n kindu/nw| ai)wrou=mai.
28. tw=n e)/rgwn—without stopping to think: as Thuc. says elsewhere, at the beginning of a war, men are impulsive. e)/xontai is equivalent to a(/ptontai.

a(\ xrh=n u(/steron dra=n — if a(/ is right (and the Schol. as well as all MSS. has it), we cannot render a(/ a thing which, but must make tw=n e)/rgwn antecedent: nor is there any objection to this except that Thuc. regularly uses dra=n(au)to/ or au)ta/) differently; see c. 5. 2: but drw= ta\ e)/rga is good Greek, e.g. sunnoi/a| q' a(/ma oi(=on de/draken e)/rgon Eur. And. 806.
29. h)/dh—only when, with kakopaqou=ntes.
2. o)/ntes ou)/t' au)toi/—strictly this should have been ou)/t' au)toi\ o)/ntes.
3. le/gomen u(.—we charge you.
au)qai/retos—i.e. not forced on us by circumstances.
6. lu/esqai—cf. c. 140. 2 ta\ e)gklh/mata dialu/esqai.
cunqh/khn—in the thirty years' truce.
8. a)/rxontas—c. 49. 4.
tau/th| h(=| a)\n u(fhgh=sqe—following just wherever you may lead.
14. pa/ntas—sc. tou\s cumma/xous kai\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.
16. e)pi\ to\ au)to\ ... e)/feron—led to the same conclusion.
17. a)dikei=n—were guilty.
24. o(rw=—sc. pollw=n p. e)mpei/rous o)/ntas.
25. tou= e)/pgou—the thing, i.e. war.
26. oi( polloi/—in contrast with Archidamus and the elderly Spartans.
27. nomi/santa—parallel to a)peiri/a|.
2. *peloponnhsi/ous kai\ tou\s a).—i.e. our allies in Peloponnese and neighbours (who are not allies), esp. Argos. (Some see a hendiadys here, but it is unnecessary.)
3. paro/moios—a match for; cf. a(nti/palos.
5. e)f' e(/kasta—we can strike at any point promptly.

9. i)/ppois kai\ o(/plois kai\ o)/xlw|—the transl. ‘cavalry and hoplites and light-armed troops’ is possible (cf. e.g. Xen. Anab. 3.236); but the simple rendering (o)/xlw| = population) is borne out by toi=s o(/plois kai\ tw=| plh/qei, c. 81. 1.
12. fo/rou u(potelei=s—contrast c. 19. 1.
13. ti/ni—neut.
17. e)/nestai = metacu\ genh/setai (Croiset).
a)lla\ toi=s x .—a)lla/ in rhetorical altercation, as often (e.g. 6.38. 5), ‘well then.’

18. e)n koinw=|—the treasury. The want of money at Sparta previous to Lysander's conquests is well-known. After the Pel. War there was a great change; but the money then acquired found its way into private hands, not into the treasury.
19. e(toi/mws—easily. (The Spartans had not yet become conspicuous for covetousness, as after the war.)
20. fe/romen—as an ei)sfora/.
21. tw=| plh/qei—the king includes the population of the confederate states. It is true that Sparta could pour a far greater number of troops into Attica than Athens could into the Peloponnese.
22. e)pifoitw=ntes—by repeated incursions. This was the method adopted, and this is probably written after the event.
26. ti/s = poi=os.
1. ka)n tou/tw|—‘in that case.
2. kalo/n—sc. h(mi=n. In katalu/esqai the mid. denotes reciprocity, as in spe/ndesqai.
3. ma=llon—sc. h)\ anagkasqh=nai polemei=n.
7. ou(/tws—adeo.
8. fronh/mati—pride, ‘high spirit.’
th=| gh=| douleu=sai—slaves to their land, so that they will not endure to see it ravaged, but will resist vigorously. Cf. Archidamus to the same effect in 2.11.6-8.
11. ou) mh\n ou)de/—c. 3. 3.
a)naisqh/tws—with e)a=n; a reply to the Corinthians; see c. 69. 3.
14. katafwra=n—properly ‘catch (a criminal) in the act’; hence ‘detect,’ ‘discover.’
16. dhlou=ntas with po/lemon implying a threat, and w(s e)pitre/yomen (for which cf. c. 71. 1) implying an admission; properly ‘explaining’; cf. c. 129. 1.

17. ta\ h(me/ter' au)tw=n—our own resources, both cumma/xwn prosagwgh=| and tw=| ta\ au(tw=n a(/ma e)kpori/zesqai The kai/ clause takes a new constn. after the long parenthesis. (Croiset thinks that ta\ h(me/ter' au)tw=n means our home resources only, and that ta\ h(me/ter' au)tw=n e)cartu/esqai is answered by ta\ au)tw=n (sic) a(/ma e)k. which refers to the resources of the cu/mmaxoi. But te after cumma/xwn is much against this; and why should ta\ h(me/ter' au)tw=n be limited by cumma/xwn prosagwgh=|?)
19. kai\ barba/rwn—efforts by Sparta (and perhaps Athens) to obtain the support of Persia are already heard of in the early part of the war.
22. e)pibouleuo/meqa—by attraction to the w(/sper-clause.

24. ta\ au(tw=n = ta\ h(me/tera au)tw=n, our own as distinct from those of our cu/mmaxoi This is awkward after ta\ h(me/ter' au)tw=n above in a wider sense, and the use of au(tw=n, otherwise common, for h(me/ter' au/tw=n does not occur elsewhere in Thuc. Hence au)tou= (adv.) and au)to/qen have been proposed.
26. e)tw=n du/o kai\ triw=n—cf. di\s kai\ tri/s, du/o kai\ tri/a bh/mata: kai\ (‘even’) di\s kai\ tri/s (see crit. note) etc. is also used.
1. h)/dh with what follows: when they see that while negotiating we are preparing quietly for war and maintaining a firm tone.

6. mh\ ga\r a)/llo ti—Archidamus argues against invading Attica at once, that as long as it is unravaged it is a hostage for the conciliatory behaviour of Athens in the negotiations; when once it is wasted, they will know that they have nothing to lose.
7. e)/xein (sc. u(ma=s), by an idiom common in Thuc.=ei)=nai u(mi=n.
ou)x h(=sson—the more so. The cultivation of the poor soil of Attica was necessarily carried on with great care.

12. o(ra=te o(/pws mh/—the result may be trouble for the confederacy (th=| *peloponnh/sw|). There is much difference of opinion about the transl.: Classen says, ‘see that it do not turn out for us as regards Pel. in a more disgraeeful and difficult
fashion’; Krüger and others, ‘see that we may not bring about a more disgraceful and difficult state of things for Pel.’—making pra/comen trans. and ai)/sxion kai\ a). adjj.: so Steup, but he renders, ‘see that we do not do (something) too disgraceful and awkward for Pel.’ Some think that h)\ th=| *)attikh=| is to be supplied to the comparatives, others—but wrongly—h)\ nu=n. I construe ‘see that we do not fare in a manner more humiliating and difficult for the confederacy,’ sc. than if we refrain from invading Attica now, spurred on by these accusations. These e)gklh/mata against Athens, it may be said, if we do not take up the cudgels (see next sentence), may involve ai)sxu/nh and a)pori/a to the confederacy; but they can be disposed of by negotiation. To go to war at once may involve us in worse difficulties.
16. i)di/wn—separate, or ‘individual,’ thinking of Corinth and Megara.
18. eu)prepw=s—contrasted with ai)sxrw=s kai\ a)po/rws pra/comen.
qe/sqai—cf. c. 25. 1.
22. xrh/mata fe/rontes—and they contribute money. The Lac. allies paid no tribute.
23. o(/plwn—is a matter of, ‘calls for.’ Kruger compares e.g. Dem. de Cor..190 h)=n e)kei=nos o( kairo\s tou= ge fronti/zontos a)ndro/s. The gen. is one of description.

24. w)felei=—are of avail. The dat. with w)felei= is not very rare in poetry (see Jebb on Soph. Ant. 560), but h)peirw/tais here belongs to e)/sti as much as to di' h(/n, etc., ‘especially in the case of a land power fighting against a naval power.’ Different explanations have been put forward of the meaning: some suppose Archidamus to allude to the necessity of obtaining a fleet (see c. 81. 4), others think that the allusion is to the equipment of large armies to remain in the field; but this is against the general argument of the speech. In qalassi/ous is included the idea of tribute-paying subjects: the Lac. have no fleet and no subject allies bound to pay for one. (This is a succinet restatement of cc. 81. 4, 82. 1. Archidamus rightly sees that success in a war with Athens depends on getting control of the sea. You cannot conquer a sea power on land, cf. c. 121, esp. 4 and 5, and c. 81. 1, 2. The two things needful to give success to the Pel. are dapa/nh and meleth/.)
28 tw=n a)pobaino/ntwn depends on th=s ai)ti/as, the greater share of responsibility for the eonsequences.
e)p' a)mfo/tera—i.e. for good or ill (kai\ eu)klei/as kai\ dusklei/as says the Schol. on ii 11 do/can oi)so/menoi e)p' a)mfo/tera).
1. ti au)tw=n—i.e. tw=n a)pobaino/ntwn, let us take some thought of them beforehand.
to\ bradu\ kai\ me/llon—referred to in tou=to and au)to/ below; me/llon is only another name for bradu/.
2. h(mw=n depends on o(/.
4. pau/saisqe—reach the end. If we begin in a hurry, we shall not be properly prepared, and the war will be prolonged.
5. kai\ a(/ma—the meaning is ‘we have always been free and famous, so our bradu/ths has served us well.’ This leads naturally to the reflexion that the so-called bradu/ths is really swfrosu/nh.

7. du/natai ... ei)=nai—when du/natai = ‘means’ we do not find ei)=nai: du/natai ma/lista ei)=nai = literally ‘can be on the whole,’ i.e. ‘may be called.’ tou=t' is emphatic, ‘it is just this that.’ e)/mfrwn too is emphatic; hence its position; and the etymological jingle sw-fros-u/nh e)/m-frwn is equivalent to ‘true prudence.’ For swfrosu/nh cf. c. 68. 1, to which this is a retort.

10. tw=n ... e)cotruno/ntwn depends as objective gen. on h(donh=|. There must be here a side ref. to the increasing influence of oratory in the Athenian ecclesia—e)/painos, h(donh/ (produced by rhetoric), kathgori/a all show it. The whole of this paragraph is an independent criticism of Athens as well as an answer to the contrast drawn by the Corinthians.
cu\n e)pai/nw| —cu/n of the means is very rare (cf. 84.3 and c. 141 cu\n fo/bw|), but occurs sometimes in Xen., as well as in poetry.
11. e)pi\ ta\ deina/—cf. c. 70. 2.
13. cu\n kathgori/a|—like the Corinthian speech.
14. a)nepei/sqhmen—for the aorist cf. c. 70. 7.

15. to\ me/n—i.e. polemikoi/. The meaning is ‘we are brave because we have a keen sense of honour, and we have a keen sense of honour because we are moderate’ But Thuc. proceeds in the opposite direction, and says, ‘The chief element in moderation (swfrosu/nh substituted for to\ eu)/kosmon) is honour, and the main ingredient in the sense of honour (ai)sxu/nh = ai)dw/s) is bravery.’ Cf. 3.83 to\ eu)/hqes, ou(= to\ gennai=on plei=ston mete/xei.
17. a)maqe/steron. paideuo/menoi—causal partic., ‘not so highly as to despise the laws’; see c. 68. 1, but a different turn is given to a)maqi/a here in the retort.
18. kai\ cu\n x.—sc. paideuo/menoi, which is again to be supphed to the following infinitives.
20. ta\ a)xrei=a—thinking on public policy for one's self, for instance, and putting before the assembly what you have thought of.
22. a)nomoi/ws—not so well as the fine criticism would lead one to expect.
e)pecie/nai—sc. au)toi=s, i.e. toi=s polemi/ois (Stahl).
23. paraplhsi/ous—as good as ours.

24. ta\s prospiptou/sas ... diaireta/s—the chances that befall cannot be determined by argument. The general sense is ‘just as we do not despise the intelligence of our enemy, so we know that we cannot see into the future—how war will go —but must depend on our eu)yuxi/a and swfrosu/nh in preparing.’ diairei=n is properly to make a gap in.

26. paraskeuazo/meqa—see crit. note: ai)ei/ favours the indic., kai\ ... dei= the subjunc. But an exhortation here would come in very awkwardly before c. 85, where the peroration begins; and Steup, reading paraskeuazw/meqa, thinks this whole section (84.4) properly follows c. 85.1.

4. e)n toi=s a)nagkaiota/tois—in the most rigorous discipline; cf. cu\n xalepo/thti paideuo/menoi above. (The rendering of Bonitz, ‘trained (only) in what is indispensable,’ as distinct from the useless wisdom of the Athenians seems to take us far beyond anything that Archidamus has said on the small extent of Spartan education, and a limitation—only—does not fit in well with the context.)
12. bouleu/swmen—come to a decision.

13. dia\ i)sxu/n—i e we need be in no hurry, because the Athenians, knowing our strength and that we are not overlooking what they have done (cf. c. 69. 3), will not dare to take any further step against us in the meantime.
18. pro/teron—before you too consent to arbitration.

20. kra/tista—this and foberw/tata are pred. to tau=ta (Classen). If Thuc. means kai\ toi=s e)n. foberw/tata to explain
kra/tista, the first kai/ must be omitted (see crit. note). The double kai/ makes two ideas.
2. kai/toi—yet surely, a common use.

6. kai\ to/te kai\ nu=n —h)=men is implied after to/te. The same form of sentence occurs in 3.40.2 and 6.60. 2. But in Plat. Gorg. p. 488 B we have a)lla/ tau=ta e)/legon kai\ to/te kai\ nu=n le/gw(e)/legon del. Schanz).
11. paradote/a—for the plur. see c. 72. 2.
12. ou)de\ di/kais ktl.—nor must we decide by arbitration and words where we are ourselves being injured not in word. mh/ is caused by the prohibition of which the whole clause consists.
24 e)/foros w)/n—in his capacity as ephor.
25 e)s th\n e).—after e)peyh/fizen.
26. kri/nousi—decide in the assembly.
3. o(/tw| me/n — the method of taking the division adopted seems to be introduced for this special occasion.
8. e)ge/nonto—amounted to.
12. yh=fon e)pagagei=n—put the vote to them.
13. koinh=| bouleusa/menoi—arrive at a common decision before ...
18. tou= ta\s sponda\s l.—the gen. of definition. Some edd. think these words spurious.
e)ge/neto ... prokexwrhkuiw=n—lit. took place in the fourteenth year of the thirty years' truce when it had lasted (so long, sc. e)s tosou=ton), i.e. in the fourteenth year of its course.
21. ta\ *eu)boi+ka/—see c. 23. 4 and 114.

1. oi( ga/r—now begins the so-called penthkontaeti/a, or sketch of the growth of Athenian power in the half century between the battle of Mycale (479 B. C.) and the beginning of the war (431 B.C.). This sketch continues to c. 118. 2; and
it consists of two parts: (1) to c. 96—how they obtained the leadership (h(gemoni/a)—or, as he says here, h)=lqon e)pi\ ta\ pra/gmata e)n oi(=s hu)ch/qhsan; (2) to c. 118—how the leadership was transformed into an empire—e)n oi(/w| tro/pw| kate/sth(h( a)rxh/), c. 97. 2.
4. nausi/—Salamis (480). pezw=|—Plataea (479).
7. diefqa/rhsan — by Leotychides, the Spartan king, and Xanthippus, father of Pericles.
11. oi( ... cu/mmaxoi—probably there was no formal treaty, but cu/mmaxoi is used because they were fighting side by side with the Athenians. (There is no need to remove cu/mmaxoi with Wilamowitz.)
14. e)pixeima/santes—the winter of 479-478 B C. The history of Herodotus ends with the fall of Sestos.
19. eu)qu/s—in autumn of 479.

o(/qen = e)kei=qen oi(=. Cf. Soph. Trach. 701 e)k de\ gh=s o(/qen | prou/keit', a)naze/ousi, from the earth where it was strewn, for o(/pou. The omission of antecedent before o(/qen is not very rare; e.g 2.94 tropai=on e)/sthsan o(/qen a)nagago/menoi e)kra/thsan, for e)ntau=qa o(/qen. The places are Salamis, Troezen and Aegina.
21. kataskeuh/n—stock, goods, of all kinds.
22. a)noikodomei=n—in the autumn of 479.
24. braxe/a—only a small remnant, of the wall round the city left by the Persians.
1. h)=lqon presbei/a| = e)presbeu/santo, the sociative dat. as in naval and military expressions; but there is no other example of this phrase and hence the variant readings.
ta\ me\n ktl.—partly because etc. mh/te not ou)/te because apprehension is implied.
5. to\ plh=qos o(/—see c. 14. 2.
6. genome/nhn—for the order see c. 11. 3.
8. ei(sth/kei—sc. tei/xh.
9. to\ boulo/menon (= th\n bou/lhsin) kai\ u(/popton — see c. 36. 1. e)s tou)s *)a. certainly belongs to dhlou=ntes and means before the assembly. For dhlou=n in this use cf. c. 82. 1.
11. w)s de\ tou= b.—but on the ground that, still depending on h)cioun.
13. a)po\ e)xurou= poqen ... o(rma=sqai—to use any stronghold as a base of operations. poqen by attraction for pou.
nu=n—lately. Herod. 9.33 fol. tells us how the Persian general Mardonius made Thebes his headquarters.
15. a)naxw/rhsi/n te kai\ a)formh/n—as a place to retreat to or advance from, abstract for concrete.
24. i(kano\n a)/rwsin—for the pred. adj. cf. 2.75 h)/|reto to\ u(/yos tou= tei/xous me/ga. The aor. (see crit. note) is necessary: the pres. would mean so long as.
25. a)nagkaiota/tou—cf. c. 2. 2.

pa/ntas—on this the Schol. notes au)tou)s kai\ gunai=kas kai\ pai=das. It is therefore evident that he did not find these words in the text. Mr. Forbes defends the words as ‘forcible,’ and adds that the note may only mean that the words kai\ ... pai=das in the text themselves explain pantas. Steup finds something wrong with their ‘force,’ rightly saying that kai\ oi)ke/tas is missing after pai=das: e.g. Diodorus xi. 40 says sunelamba/nonto tw=n e)/rgwn oi(/ te pai=des kai\ ai( gunai=kes kai( kaqo/lou pa=s ce/nos kai\ dou=los; but the details of his account are not drawn wholly from Thuc. The second point raised in defence is not borne out by the scholia to Thuc.
26. tou\s e)n th=| po/lei—cf. c. 64. 2: in contrast with those away from Attica.

3. ta)=lla ... ta)kei=—the rest, namely what was to be done there: an intentionally vague and mysterious suggestion of cunning, both being object of pra/coi. The order throws emphasis on both. The Athenians liked such oracular remarks from those whom they regarded as cunetoi/: this style reflected the manner of the Delphic oracle, the gnomic poets, the sages and early philosophers.
6. a)rxa/s—magistrates.
11. w(s—for o(/pws, how (not ‘that’).

13. dia\ fili/an au)tou= —au)tou= objective: the reason of this favour was, no doubt, that Them. was regarded at Sparta as a protector from the Persians: they owed him gratitude for the Athenian fleet; cf. c. 74. 1.

tw=n de\ a)/llwn ktl.—Classen makes a)fiknoume/nwn substantival; and renders kai\ safw=s quite positively (e)pei\ oi(
a)/lloi a)fiknou/menoi, visitors—arrivals, as they say—kai\ safw=s kathgo/roun). The contrast to this subject will then be sfw=n au)tw=n a)/ndras below. Others render ‘(all) the other (visitors) arriving and announcing.’ In either case there is probably an allusion to tw=n cumma/xwn e)cotruno/ntwn c. 90. 1 in tw=n de\ a)/llwn: these ‘others’ were persons afraid of Athens.
15. teixi/zetai—sc. to\ tei=xos.
18. oi(/tines xrhstoi/—parts of ei)mi/ are often omitted in short rel. sentences.
24. h(=kon—were come.
29. e)pesta/lh—impersonal.
1. toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois—i.e. tai=s a)rxai=s (c. 90. 5).

4. ei) de/ ti ktl—a claim to complete recognition as an equal. ti=‘in regard to any matter:’ w(s pro\s ktl. lit. to go in future as to men who could discern both their own interests and the common interests of the Greeks. i)e/nai depends on ei)=pen in sense of e)ke/leusen: w(s pro\s d. is placed early so as to make it emphatic, and the emphasis must be marked in translating. There is no reason for interfering with the text here: prod (see crit. note) is only a slip for pro\s d.
10. e)/fasan—sc. the Athenian ambassadors.

11. bouleu/esqai—the attraction of the verb of short rel. sentences in O.O. into infinitive is less rare in Gk. than in Lat.: Thuc. has several examples, e.g. 2.102 le/getai ... o(/te dh\ a)la=sqai. This sentence stands as accus. of respect to ou)deno\s ktl.

14. kai\ i)di/a| ktl.—and for the Athenians themselves and with a view to (the interests of) the allies in general it would be beneficial. The position of the allies would be secure in the general council if Athens was strong. (This passage has been much discussed: (1) Classen takes toi=s poli/tais with e)s tou\s p. cumma/xous also, and understands, ‘would be of more advantage to the Athenians (both) separately and with regard to their relations with the allies.’ But it is rightly objected that the advantage of the fortification cannot be limited to the Athenians, who want to prove that it is good for the allies too (cf. c. 91. 4 ta\ koina/). Steup deletes a)/meinon ei)=nai, and is thus able to transl. the kai\ i)di/a| ktl. both for the A. themselves and
for the allies. But there is no decisive objection to the text as it stands. It is true that we expect i/di/a| te or kai/ (‘both’) i)di/a|; cf. ta/ te sfi/sin au)toi=s ... kai( ta\ koina/: but the omission and the unusual e)s tou/s instead of dative serve to make the allusion to ‘the allies’ a climax; kai/=‘and in fact.’)
15. w)felimw/teron e)/sesqai—the argument is that this, like the earlier actions of Athens, was done e)p' w)feli/a|, not only for Athens but for the Greek allies in general. Cf. c. 73. 2.

ou) ga/r—this alludes to all the allies quite as much as to Athens: they would feel that the right to strengthen themselves was vindicated by Athens, thus all would be on an equal footing in the common council and their views would be equally respected.
18. e)/fh—Themistocles.
22. gnw/mhs paraine/sei—sc. e:pi/, to recommend a resolution to the Athenian assembly, i.e. to give advice. tw=| koinw=| depends on paraine/sei. dh=qen is of course ironical.
25. ta\ ma/lista—best taken with e)n tw=| to/te, at that time more than at any other.
4. oi( ga\r qeme/lioi—the upper part of the wall was of brick (pli/nqoi), but there was a lower course of stone. Cf. Dem. de Cor..299 ou) li/qois e)tei/xisa th\n po/lin ou)de\ pli/nqois e)gw/.
5. cuneirgasme/nwn—shaped for fitting together.
6. sth=lai—fragments of some of these belonging to the walls of Themistocles have been found. Hicks, Man. p. 13.
8. pantaxh=|—the extension did not include the SW. side of the city. For mei/zwn cf. c. 90. 3.
10. kinou=ntes h)pei/gonto—disturbed in their haste: kinei=n is specially used of things that should not be interfered with.
12. u(ph=rkto d' au)tou=—a beginning had been made on it; au)tou= is neut. = ‘the work.’

13. e)pi\ th=s ... h)=rce—during his office of archon, which he had held for a year at Athens. It is not necessary to understand by kat' e)niauto/n annually, which complicates the grammar of the sentence. kata/, with words dcnoting time,
is not always distributive. The year is now thought to be 482 B.C.
15. lime/nas—Piraeus, Zea, Munychia.
16. kai\ au)tou/s—and that the A., having once become a naval people, were in a very advantageous position for the acquisition of power. (Classen understands profe/rein as fut. in sense.)
18. th=s ga\r dh/—as often, there is an ellipse here; in full the sense is ‘he naturally thought of this, for,’ etc.

19. th\n a)rxh\n eu)qu\s cugkateskeu/azen—at once began to help them to lay the foundation of their empire. This seems, on the whole, better than the version preferred by Classen and others, ‘prepared to begin (a)rxh/n) the building,’ in which cun- is left obscure, and is, in fact, variously explained; and a)rxh/n (cf. c. 96. 2) is strange for e)/rgon. The allusion is to the whole period after Salamis.
21. nu=n e)/ti—generally supposed to have been written after the destruction of the walls of Piraeus by Lysander in 404 B.C. There is, however, no certainty in the matter; cf. 93.2.

22. du/o ga\r a(/macai—this is supposed to mean that wagons in two rows drawing up stones from opposite ends met and passed one another on the wall (Classen); or, much better— because the idea of Classen could not possibly be carried out in building—the wagons worked from one end up an incline, and after discharging their load turned and passed the laden wagons still coming along the wall. (So already Procopius.) It is almost incredible, however, that Thuc. should have intended this Greek to represent (1) two rows of wagons (2) passing along the wall, and (3) the one set returning empty. But I have no other explanation to offer. Some suppose that two wagons worked on the level and deposited stones ready for the building on either side; perhaps this does prove to\ pa/xos tou= tei/xous.
24. e)nto\s de/—i.e. the inside was not filled with clay and small stones, but large blocks were cut and fitted and fastened together on the outside by iron clamps.
25. e)ntomh=|—by cutting into them, so that the ends could fit together and overlap. This is much better than e)n tomh=|, which cannot=‘at the ends.’
28. ou(= dienoei=to—i.e. ekei/nou d dienoei=to telei=n.
1. e)piboula/s—an e\piboulh/ would lead to an e)pibolh/: Thuc. as often gives to the cause the meaning of its effect: there is no need to alter the text, despite the gloss in the Schol.
2. a)xreiota/twn—in its strict military sense.
16. cune/pleon—it is not clear whether this expedition took place in 478 B.C. or in the early spring of 477. The Athenian leaders were Aristides and Cimon.

21. e)n th=|de th=| h(.—during the command of Pausanias. h(gemoni/a refers to his leadership, not to the Spartan ‘hegemony’; see e.g. c. 128. 7. The story of Pausanias is given in cc. 128130. Some, to improve the sense, connect these words with the sentence that follows; see crit. note.
24. kai\ o(/soi ktl.—see c. 89. 2; those who had revolted from Persia after Mycale.
27. gi/gnesqai—the pres., if correct, implies that the change could not be made in a minute.
kata\ to\ cuggene/s—they were not all Ionians, but the greater number of them were.

9. e)fai/neto—it is not necessary to supply a subject such as h( a)rxh/: the lit. rendering is ‘an imitation of despotism was apparent (was to be seen)’; so in 2. 65. 9 e)gi/gneto lo/gw| me\n dhmokrati/a, e)/rgw| de\ ... a)rxh/, nominally a democracy was being formed.
10. kalei=sqai—before the court at Sparta.

14. tw=n me\n i)di/a| ... hu)qu/nqh—was punished for the injuries he had privately inflicted on any person. tina is prob. masc., the sing. being used for the plur. as elsewhere, e.g. c. 40. 5; pro/s tina, in certain respects. seems flat, and tina as neut. plur. is avoided where it is ambignous.
15. ta\ de\ me/gista—those against the state. internal accus. to a)dikei=n.
17. e)do/kei—sc. tou=to.
23. oi( e)cio/ntes—cp. c. 77. 6; the pres. of the succession of commanders.
xei/rous—corrupted.
27. e)pithdei/ous =fi/lous.

2. e)/tacan—cf. Ath. Pol. c. 23 tou\s fo/rous ou(=tos (Aristides) h)=n o( ta/cas tai=s po/lesin tou(s prw/tous e)/tei tri/tw| meta\ th\n e)n *salami=ni naumaxi/an—in 478-77. Trans. ‘assessed the contributions both of the states that were to provide money and of those,’ etc.—not ‘fixed which of the states,’ which overlooks the technical use of ta/ssein, rate.
5. w(=n=e)kei/nwn a(/, gen. of cause.

6. *(ellhnotami/ai ... a)rxh/ —a)rxh/ is pred., ‘as an office,’ and the verb is attracted into its number. Only Athenians could hold the office. They were ten in number, and were elected annually in the Eeclesia, one from each tribe See Sandys' note on Ath. Pol. c. 30.2.

9. o( prw=tos fo/ros taxqei/s—for the order cf. c. 11. 3. The sum is thought, on the evidence of the extant lists of the quota of 1/60th paid to Athena, to be impossibly large; and Classen therefore considered the whole passage interpolated. Perhaps the sum given was assessed, but not realised.
11. *dh=los—the treasury of the leagne was removed to Athens in 454 B.C.
14. bouleuo/ntwn—co-ordinate with au)tono/mwn. a)po/ expresses the method.
tosa/de e)ph=lqon—the series of enterprises that are about to be noticed (c. 98-118); tosa/de diepra/canto o(/sa ... e)rei= Schol.
15. diaxeiri/sei pragma/twn—by the management (manipulation) of political affairs.
16. metacu\ tou=de tou= pole/mou kai\ tou= *m.—between the Persian and Peloponnesian wars. Greek often proceeds in this manner from the nearer to the more remote.
a(/—the antecedent is tosa/de. e)ge/neto stands as the passive of poiw=.

20. tou\s ai)ei\ prostugxa/nontas e)n e(ka/stw|—who in the several incidents came in contact with them as enemies (‘took part with the allies’ as some understand prostug. does not seem to be supported by the usage of the word; it occurs only here in Thuc.).
21. au)ta/—i.e. a(\ e)ge/neto ktl.
23. xwri/on—period.

26. *(ella/nikos—this is the only instance in which Thuc. names another historian. H. of Mitylene was contemporary with Pericles, and in his *)atqi/s (here called *)attikh\ cuggrafh/) he included a sketch of historical events, and is said to have carried his work down at least to 406 B.C.

27. braxe/ws te kai\ toi=s xro/nois ou)k a).—Hellanicus must have been very scanty and inexact in the dates for this period, since this description would apply in a considerable degree to the better account that Thuc. proceeds to give. For the probable dates of the events to be noticed see Introd. p. xxix.
29. e)/xei—sc. tau=ta.
1. *)hio/na—this place became later the port of Amphipolis. Miltiades is the victor of Marathon.
6. w)(/|kisan au)toi/—Scyros was parcelled out among Athenian settlers, or ‘cleruchs’; sessores veteres eiecit (Cimon), agros civibus divisit, says Nepos. (Cimon 2.5)
7. a)/neu tw=n a)/. *eu)boe/wn—Carystus sided with Persia, but the rest of Enboea was in the league.
8. cune/bhsan—the Carystians.
12. to\ kaqesthko/s—not ‘recognised principles of right,’ but the existing arrangement’ which was that the allies retained their autonomy. doulei/a as in c. 8. 3.

13. cune/bh—sc. doulwqh=nai, e)doulw/qhsan. The Schol. supplies e)doulw/qh, and acting on this hint Kruger iemoves cune/bh, so that w(s e(ka/sth (nom.)=‘severally.’ This gives a simpler constn., out the text may be sound; and, as Classen says, cune/bh points to the ‘varying circumstances under which the loss of au:tonomi/a occurred.
16. lipostra/tion—i.e. failure to furnish any ships as distinct from e)/kdeiai, which means that part only of the number was supplied.
17. a)kribw=s e)/prasson—were exacting in regard to fo/rwn e)/kdeiai, not quite ‘exacted (the tribute).’
18. luphroi\ h)=san—cf. c. 76. 1: talaipwrei=n refers to new=n e)/kdeiai kai\ lipostra/tion.
20. ta\s a)na/gkas ‘their coercive measures.’ Cf. Aesch. PB 1052 a)na/gkhs sterrai=s di/nais, and see L & S S V a)na/gkh 3.
22. a)/rxontes—as rulers they were not popular as they had been at first. pws implies the omission of the details.
24. w(=n—i.e. o(/ti ou)/te cunestra/teuon ktl.
27. xrh/mata e)ta/canto ... fe/rein—the mid. denotes a reciprocal arrangement. xrh/mata is prob. object of fe/rein and to\ i(k. a)na/lwma, the sum that fell to them is in appos. to it.
1. hu)/ceto—Thuc. never uses the ordinary Attic form au)ca/nw.
10. a)mfo/tera—cf. c. 13. 5.
12. *foini/kwn—the Persian fleet consisted almost wholly of Phoenician ships.
ta\s pa/sas—in all.
15. a)ntipe/ras—often used of the coast opposite an island, or vice versa.
16. a(\ e)ne/monto—see notes on p. 2, 11 and p. 44, 3. Here the two antecedents in different number require a)/, which would otherwise be w(=n.

23. au)toi\ e)kra/thsan—in contrast with the *)hdwnoi/—but the use of au)toi/ here, to which Steup objected, is strange. Notice how the precise sense of oi( *)aqhnai=oi shifts in this passage with the different verbs (e.g. pe/myantes and diefqa/rhsan).

26. u(po\ tw=n *qra|kw=n cumpa/ntwn oi(=s—all the Thracians who objected, as distinct from the Edonians only oi(=s pole/mion h)=n replaces a tw=n + partic. limiting cumpa/ntwn. Poppo's conj. cu/mpantes, supported by Valla's transl. omnes, brings this passage more into harmony with Herod. 9.33 and other passages in which the Edonians alone are named as destroying the A. But if Thuc. meant the Edonians only, why should he say u(po\ tw=n *qra|kw=n?
27. to\ xwri/on ktizo/menon—the founding of the place.
8 au)toi=s—ethic: it is constantly placed early in this manner.
perioi/kwn—the free, but dependent Lacedaemonians descended from the pre-Dorian inhabitants and living in separate towns.

11. to/te—the descendants of the M. of former times who had been enslaved in the war made up most of the helots.
plei=stoi is pred.; to/te refers to a well-known occasion, as elsewhere in Thuc. (often too, to some event that has been already recorded by Thuc.)—here to the first Messenian war, after which the Messenians became, as Tyrtaeus says, w(/sper o)/noi mega/lois a)/xqesi teiro/menoi: doulwqe/ntwn is epithet, the order being justified by palaiw=n, cf. c. 11. 3 katesxhko/tos.
12. e)klh/qhsan—came to be called; cf. c. 2. 4. oi( pa/ntes, sc. *ei(/lwtes.

16. kaqelo/ntes—this and the following aor. partic. are what are called ‘timeless,’ i.e, they denote merely the act, not time anterior to the verb. This happens only when the leading verb is in aorist. Cf. the constn. with e)/tuxon e)/laqon, e)/fqasa.

17. xrh/mata/ te ktl.—the order is taca/menoi au)ti/ka a)podou=nai x. o(/sa e)/dei kai\ to\ loipo\n fe/rein(x. o(/sa e)/dei), and x. o(/sa e)/dei is the common object and so is put first. Note the aor. of one act and the pres. of a system. (It is certainly wrong to make a)podou=nai depend only on e)/dei and to render kai/ also. This would mean that they were always to pay as much as the indemmty now exacted).
23. cumma/xous—in virtue of the alliance under Sparta still formally existing in spite of the Athenian hegemony.

24. oi( d' h)=lqon—there was opposition at Athens to the proposal, but Cimon's view was that Sparta on land was as necessary to Greece as Athens on sea: Greece was ‘lamed’ while Sparta was tied down (Plut. Cim 16).

27. toi=s de/—edd. are divided as to whether this refers to the Athenians who fell short of their reputation, or to the Lac., i.e. whether to transl. (1) ‘but in their case (the Ath.) it gradually appeared that there was a deficiency in this (viz. tou= teixomaxei=n dunatou\s ei)=nai),’ as they did not succeed in taking Ithome; or (2) ‘whereas it was apparent to them (the Lac.) that they lacked skill in this’—so that the full form would be o(/ti(oi( me\n *)aqhnai=oi) ... toi=s de\(*aakedaimoni/ois). This seems better. The reading th=s of the Schol. is prob. only a conjecture. e)ndea= is again the plur, adj. for sing. (=e)/ndeia). Thuc. might have said tou=to e)ndee\s e)fai/neto in the same sense.
2. bi/a| ga/r—for otherwise (had they been competent teixomaxei=n) they would have captured it by assault—and would not have had to turn the siege into a blockade. Cf. on c. 11. 1.
8. h(ghsa/menoi—considering; so often in the aor.: they reflected o(/ti oi me\n *dwriei=s, oi( de\ *)/iwnes (Schol.).

mh/ ti ktl.—this depends on dei/santes, the clause between being parenthetical; a not very common form of constn.; cf. Soph. Antig. 1278 ta\ d' e)n do/mois | e)/oikas h(/kein kai\ ta/x' o)/yesqai kaka/, with Jebb's note.
9. newteri/swsi—i e. by joining the helots. This would be an instance of their tolmhro\n kai\ newteropoii/a.
12. e)pi\ tw=| belti/oni lo/gw|—for the better reason, viz. that they were no longer needed. Of course belti/wn implies a contrast with a suppressed kaki/wn ai)ti/a viz. to\ u(poyi/an tina\ gene/sqai
15. deino\n poihsa/menoi=d. h(ghsa/menoi: but deino/n(-a/)poiei=n=to declare a thing intolerable.

23. deka/tw| e)/tei—this year (see chron. table p. xxx) would be 456 B.C.; but there are several reasons for thinking deka/tw| wrong; e.g. (1) we know from [Xen.] Ath. Pol. that the Messenians were reduced before the battle of Tanagra, which occurred in 457 B.C., nor is it possible that Sparta should have sent a large army out of the Pel. unless this were so; (2) with deka/tw| the chronological order of events is here only in this sketch of the rise of Athens interrupted to notice an event that occurred after events that are still to be noticed. Hence Kruger proposed teta/rtw|, supposing that Thue. wrote *d which was taken for the initial letter of deka/tw| instead of the sign for four. Unfortunately, in view of the fact that Cimon was not sent to Sparta until after the capitulation of Thasos, and that then e)mhku/neto o: po/lemos, it is doubtful if four years is long enough.
28. ei)=nai—the infin. in O.O. for e)/stw dou=los of O.R. This infin is particularly eommon in the terms of treaties.
3. *)iqwmh/ta—Doric ending, recalling the original.
5. kat' e)/xqos h)/dh—closely together,=kata/ (‘in consequence of’) to\ h)/dh gegenhme/non e)/.

e)s *nau/pakton—the settlement proved most important to Athens in the Pel. War; they were expelled from Naupactus by Sparta at the end of it, and lived dispersed until Epaminondas befriended them in 370 B.C.

12. e(/sxon—ingressive. The possession of Megara and its
ports was of the utmost value to Athens, hecause they thus blocked the roads from Pel. to Attica and Boeotia.
20. u(pe/r—above, i.e. further inland.
22. *)artace/rcou—the suceessor of Xerxes.
4. *(alia=s—nom. *(alih=s or -ei=s (cf. *dwrieu/s). The object of Athens was to begin a plan of connecting up the coast from the Saronic G. to the G. of Argos.
19. pro/teron with e)pikou/rous.
21. kate/labon—the heights command the Megarid.

29. oi(/ te presbu/tatoi kai\ oi( n.—those over fifty or under twenty did not as a rule serve outside Attica: here peri/poloi (18-20) and oi( u(pe\r penth/konta e)/th gegono/tes, as Classen points out, are meant
3. au)toi/—subj. of e)/lasson e)/xein.
6. kakizo/menoi=yego/menoi (Schol.).
8. h(me/rais—with e)lqo/ntes a)nqi/stasan. The dat. is much better than accus. taken with paraskeuasa/menoi.

15. prosbiasqe/n—driven to it, viz. pro\s to\ u(poxwrei=n (to take ou)k o)li/gon as adverbial and qualifying prosbiasqe/n with Steup is very forced). Others explain pro\s to\ e)spesei=n ktl. which on account of diamarto\n th=s o(dou= e)se/pesen (=pass of e)sba/llw) is less likely.
16. w(=| e)/tuxen—sc. o)/n.
19. ei)=rgon—sc. au)tou/s. toi=s o(. is dat. of means.
22. to\ plh=qos—the main body.

25. ta\ makra\ tei/xh—these are not the two parallel ‘Long Walls’ or ‘Long Legs’ so familiar, but (1) the northern or to\ e)/cwqen tei=xos running to Piraeus, and (2) the wall to Phalerum, to\ *falhriko\n tei=xos. The third wall, parallel to the northern wall, and called to\ dia\ me/sou or to\ no/tion tei=xos was added some years later. (Steup supposes that all three walls are here meant, the two to Piraeus heing included in to\ e)s *peiraia= . This is contrary to Andoc. de pace 37 and Plat. Gorg.
p. 455 E, and in 2.13. 7 it is not likely that Thuc. means both walls by to\ makro/n, esp. as immediately afterwards he uses the plur.)
28. *dwria=s—i.e. the territory of the Dorians. The names of the towns in this distriet are variously given by different authors; but no doubt the three places here mentioned are the most important.
3. *nikomh/dous—brother of Pausanias. The Lac. must have crossed the Corinthian (‘Crisaean’) gulf.
9. a)pexw/roun—began to ...
15. du/sodos—i.e. the passes are difficult.
20. to\ de/ ti —to\ de/ is ‘on the other hand’ (cf. ta\ me\n ... ta\ de/), and ti in some measure (cf. ou)/ ti in Plato).
22. e)ph=gon—were egging them on.
25. pandhmei/—i.e. all liable to serve who remained at Athens.
28. nomi/santes de\ ktl .—nomi/santes and u(poyi/a| are the emphatic words (Forbes).

8. fo/nos ... polu/s—see Hicks, Man. Gk. Hist. Inscr. p. 23 Cimon, who had been banished after the return from Ithome (c. 102), was recalled after this defeat on the motion of Pericles. Plato (Mener.) and Demosth. speak of the battle of Tanagra as indecisive. Plato also misrepresents the ostracism of Cimon in the Gorgias.
11. dia\ *geranei/as—a good proof of the severity of the defeat is that the Athenians did not attempt to hold the passes against the returning Lac.
14. *murwni/dou—cf. c. 105. 4.
26. to\ new/rion—Gythium. This Chalcis is in Aetolia.
1. e)n a)poba/sei th=s gh=s=e)s th\n gh=n a)poba/ntes.
5. i)de/ai—vicissitudes, dia(foroi po/lemoi, oi(=on ... ni=kai kai\ h(=ttai (Schol.).
12. a)/llws —ma/thn (Schol.).
19. *proswpi/tida—an island formed by one of the mouths of the Nile and a canal.
24. h)/peiron—sc. e)poi/hse.
27. polemh/santa—there is no need to read polemhsa/ntwn with Cobet; cf. such expressions as nosei= ta\ pra/gmata: edd. quote Herod. 7.33 e:s tou=to qra/seos a\nh/kei ta\ )*ellh/nwn pra/gmata.
3. e)n toi=s e)/lesi—the Nile Delta.
5. kai\ a(/ma—the coustn. changes from suhord. to principal form: strictly we require kai\ a(/ma o(/ti ktl.
7. ta\ pa/nta e)/prace—i.e. th\n a)po/stasin e)poi/hse th=s *ai)gu/ptou (Schol.); see c. 104. 1.
11. *mendh/sion ke/ras—one of the Nile mouths named after a town Mendes. ke/ras kalei= *nei/lou to\ sto/ma (Schol.).
12 ei)do/tes—after trih/reis, of the crews, as often; e.g. vi. 104. 1.
20. basile/ws—he belonged prob. to the Scopadae, one of the two branches of the royal house of Thessaly.
feu/gwn—living in exile.
25. o(/sa—sc. kratei=n e)du/nanto. See Jebb on Soph. OT 347.
26. e)k tw=n o(/plwn—i.e. outside the camp. ta\ o(/pla is properly the space in front of a camp where the arms were piled: so commonly in Xen.
5. *perikle/ous—first mention of him (year 454 B.C.).
9. th=s *)akarnani/as depends on *oi)nia/das.
15. e)/sxon—abstained from war with Greeks.
18. a)p' au)tw=n—out of the 200.
19. metape/mpontos—Thuc. often uses this verb in act., while other authors use the mid.: so too metaxeiri/zw, peirw=.
22. *ki/tion—in Cyprus (now Chitti)
23. u(pe\r *s—off S., with e)nauma/xhsan.
25. a(mfo/tera—see c. 13. 5.
26. ai( ... pa/lin [ai(] e)lqou=sai—which had returned from Egypt. ai( is to be omitted.
5. e)ggenome/nou—cf. c. 80. 4.
6. feugo/ntwn—after the battle of Oenophyta, the democratic party in Boeotia had driven out the anti-Athenian oligarclis. But the exiles had recovered some of their lost power.

13. kai\ a)ndrapodisantes—there is no sufficient ground for omitting these words (see crit. note); that a scribe copied them from c. 98 is very unlikely. It is remarkable that Athens should have taken such drastic measures against a place in the heart of Greece and so near.
14. katasth/santes—sc. e)n au)th=|, unless e)g- should be read (if Thuc. wrote in the old Attic alphabet, e)g would be nearly identical with the last two letters of fulakh/n); cf. c. 115. 3.
15. *korwnei/a|—in this engagement Clineas, father of Alcibiades, was killed; and Tolmides himself.
17. gnw/mhs—i.e. sympathised with the oligarchs.
22. oi( a)/lloi—the other Boeotians, as well as those who had been driven out.

26. diabebhko/tos—the gen. abs. in place of dat., throwing emphasis on the partic.; cf. 6.10 sfale/ntwn de\ (h(mw=n) ... taxei=an th\n e\pixei)rhsin h(mi=n oi/ e(xqroi\ poih/sontai: gen. for nom. 8.76. 4; for accus. 2.8. 4.
9. *qriw=ze=e)s to\ *qria/sion pedi/on (cf 2.19); Thria near Eleusis.
11. to\ ple/on—further. Pleistoanax was banished from Sparta on his return, being thought to have taken a bribe to leave Attica (2.21).
15. o(mologi/a| katesth/santo—arranged their affairs under a convention. See Hicks Man. p. 33.
20. a)podo/ntes—for the aor. cf. c 101. 1.
28 th\n politei/an—this is the only case in which newteri/zw has an aceus. except a neut. pron. (ti, ou)de/n etc.).
5. *ah=mnon—Athenian colony.
6. tw=n de\ *sami/wn—for the constn. cf. c. 72. 1.
8. toi=s dunatwta/tois—the leading oligarchs in Samos. cummaxi/an seems to be used somewhat loosely as applied to toi=s dunatwta/tois.
10. ei)=xe *sa/rdeis—as satrap of Lydia.
13. tw=n plei/stwn—most of them; the sense is not clear.
16. oi(/ h)=san para\ sfi/sin—this seems to refer to Athenian e)pi/skopoi who were sent out to superintend the affairs of the new democratic government of Samos.
18. pareskeua/zonto strateu/ein —met' au)tou= (i.e. Pissuthnes) says the Schol.; and this note has strayed into the text of CG (see crit. note).
21. tai=s me\n e(k.—for the article cf. c. 10. 2.
24. tw=n *foinissw=n new=n—i.e. the Persian fleet that Pissuthnes might be expected to employ.
ai( d' e)pi\ *xi/ou—Sophocles the poet was strathgo/s of this sqnadron. See Jebb's Intr. to the Antigone.
25. periagge/llousai bohqei=n—calling for the contingents they were entitled to. Chios and Lesbos were not entirely to he depended upon.
6. kratou=ntes—being superior.
trisi\ tei/xesi—intended to blockade the town on the three sides that did not face the sea. Why they built three separate walls is not explained.
10. e)saggelqe/ntwn—cf. dhlwqe/ntos c 74. 1, and for the plur. c. 7. 1.
e)p' au)tou/s—i.e tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.
14. a)fa/rktw|—i.e. the Athenians had neglected to protect their naval station with a stau/rwma.
21. pa/lin tai=s nausi/ with kateklh/|sqhsan.

23. *qoukudi/dou—it is not known who this Thuc. is, probably not the well-known politician, nor the historian. For Phormio see c. 64: after winning great victories he died about 428 B.C.
Hagnon led the colony to Amphipolis in 437 B.C., and was again Strategus in 430 and 429 B.C. After the Sicilian disaster when an old man he was one of the ten pro/bouloi.
27. a)nti/sxcin—the advantage of this pres. form over the aor. of a)nte/xw (see crit. note) is that continuation of resistance is implied.
1. kaqelo/ntes—for the aor. see c. 101. 3.
3. kata\ xro/nous—at fixed intervals.
9. pro/fasis—see c. 23. 6.
11. o(/sa e)/pracan oi( *(/ellhnes—in spite of the verbal similarity to c. 97. 1, Thuc. here includes everything related between cc. 89 and 118.

12. e)n e)/tesi penth/konta—i.e. between 480 and 431 B.C Perhaps it is in order to round off the period to fifty years exactly that Thuc. here says metacu\ th=s *ce/rcou a\naxwrh/sews whereas at c 89 he began e)peidh\ *mh=doi a)nexw/rhsan—which is a different event.

14. e)n oi=s—since the period begun at c. 97. In such a summary as Thuc. here gives we need not look for absolute accuracy in the details: he is giving the useful landmarks in the chronology. Think of the retreat of Xerxes, he says, and think of the beginning of the war, you have just fifty years, and a convenient plan for remembering how the power of Sparta among the alhes was lost and that of Athens was gained.
16. au)toi/—Athens, independently of her empire.
18. e)pi\ braxu/—to a small extent, ec. 90; 107; 112; 114.

19. o)/ntes me\n pro\ tou= mh\ taxei=s—the mh/ is unusual: ‘it is as if he had said w(s ei)ko\s me\n h)=n kai\ pro\ tou= mh\ taxei=s o)/ntas’ (Croiset). i.e Thuc. wants to represent a general cause persons who had been slow before would naturally be slack in such a case: this connexion of cause and effect is well brought out by the mh/. Cf. next note hut one. (Goodwin, M.T. 685 offers a curious explanation.)
21. to\ de/ ti—see c. 107. 4.
tole/mois oi\kei/ois—the use of the plur. where only the Messenian War is meant shows that Thuc. is still representing the eause as a general one that would naturally have the effect mentioned.
22. pri\n dh/, ‘until at length,’ with past indic. often introduces the decisive event.
23. th=s cummaxi/as—esp. the Corinthians.
26. kaqairete/a—fem.
1. au)toi=s—as distinct from their allies: see c. 87. 6.
5. a)/meinon e)/stai—formula used in inquiring of oracles, and a)/meinon often in the metrical replies.
7. au)to/s—the oracle said cullh/yomai au)to/s.
8. au)=qis with parakale/santes only; this is the cougress referred to in c. 87. 4. The earlier meeting implied is that of c. 67. 3.

18. paro/ntes de\ kai\ to/te—as they had already expressed their views to the allies as well as to Sparta, their presence at this second meeting is specially mentioned. (There is no sufficient ground for rejecting paro/ntes. Steup conjectures parocu/nontes.)
19. teleutai=oi e)pelqo/ntes—cf. c. 1.67.5.

21. ou)k ... e)/ti—the charges (1) that the Lac. were neglecting their allies in not deciding to fight Athens, and (2) that they had not brought the allies together to vote on a clear issue, viz. on the question of war, had been brought by the Corinthians in the earlier assembly (c. 68).
23. e)s tou=to=e)s to\ yhfi/sasqai to\n po/lemon.
24. ga/r implies ‘otherwise we should blame them.’

25. ta\ i)/dia e)c i)/sou ne/montas—while attending to their own interests as much as others do. ta\ i)/dia is the interests of Sparta in contrast with ta\ koina/, the common interests of the confederates. e)c i)/sou=with as much care as others of the confederates (esp. the Corinthians) attend to their own interests. ne/mw is here not ‘assign,’ but ‘direct, manage,’ as often in trag.: how distinet the two senses are may be seen from Soph. OC 237-240
gh=s
th=sd' h(=s e)gw\ kra/th te kai\ qro/nous ne/mw
mh/t' e)sde/xesqai mh/te prosfwnei=n tina
... mh/te xernibo\)s ne/mein. Here ne/montas ta\ i)/dia has reference to au)toi\ e)yhfisme/noi to\n po/lemo/n ei)si, and proskopei=n ta\ koina\ to h(ma=s e)s tou=to cunh/gagon.
26. proskopei=n—not to foresee, but to consider before others, in a higher degree, in contrast with e)c i)/sou and corresponding to the pro- in protimw=ntai.

e)n a)/llois—the Schol takes this as neut., and so many edd., ‘in other respects’ or ‘on other occasions’: but some prefer the masc., and this is better, ‘among others,’ i.e. when the Lac. send representatives to a meeting in any allied city.
27. e)k pa/ntwn—above all (masc,; some render ‘by all,’ which is less likely).
28. e)nhlla/ghsan—only here in this sense, sune/mican kai\ w(mi/lhsan (Schol.). Cities on the coast who have had commercial dealings with Athens are meant.

2. katw|khme/nous—Thuc., like Herod., uses this verb in mid. as well as in act.: but only the perf. and plup. in mid. For the accus, Kruger quotes Herod. 4.33 katoikhme/non th\n ... nh=son. e)n po/rw| —in the track of trade: this constn. is strange after th\n meso/geian and prob. th/n is meant to extend over mh\ e)n po/rw| (sc. gh=n).
4. th\n katakomidh/n—i e. for exportation; pa/lin qualifies a)nti/lhyin; cf. e.g. h( pa/lin kata/basis vii. 44. th/n of course goes with both nouns.
8. pote with proelqei=n.
11. bouleu/esqai depends on xrh/.
13. a)ndrw=n ga\r swfro/nwn—in sense subord. to a)gaqw=n de\ ktl.

e)stin, ei) mh\ a)dikoi=nto—instances of this idiom in Sophocles are given by Bayheld on Antig 666: Goodwin M.T. 555: Spratt on Thuc. iii 9. This opt. is esp. suited to such gnw=mai because it puts the case in the most general way possible. Jebb on Soph. Antig. l.c. a\ll' o(\n po/lis sth/seie, tou=de xrh\ klu/ein.

14. a)dikoume/nous=ei) a)dikoi=nto. The speaker impresses on the allies of the interior that they too are involved when those of the coast are wronged. The change of case (a)dikoume/nwn might have been written) makes the partic. more emphatic.
15. eu)= de\ parasxo/n—this clause added to a)ndrw=n a)gaqw=n rather than to swfro/nwn shows that the a)ndrei/a meant is not opposed to the swfrosu/nh.

16. kai\ mh/te ... e)pai/resqai—this clause gives the negative of e)k pole/mou pa/lin c. and mh/te ... a(dikei=sqai that of a)dikoume/nous ... polemei=n in chiastic form. Thuc. is fond of restating in a negative a point just made; while his style is brief, there is yet a tendency to redundaney. See Intr. p. xlvii. tw=| h/su/xw| th=s
ei)rh/nhs is according to the constant habit of substituting the adj. neut. for subst. in giving the quality of a person or thing. The form h(su/xios (see crit. note) is rarer, and as to\ h)/suxon occurs in 6.18 and 34, not to be preferred. h/do/menon is in the sing. as if tina had preceded.
19. o)knw=n—sc. polemei=n. Some regard ei) h)suxa/zoi as a gloss, but if it is tautological after o)knw=n so is di' o(/per o)knei= after dia\ th\n h(donh/n.
22. pleona/zwn—e)pairo/menos (Croiset).
e)ntequ/mhtai ... e)pairo/menos—the constn. as with oi)=da. Why the qra/sos is a)/piston is explained in what follows.
23. gnwsqe/nta—planned.

24. tuxo/nta—luckily finding the enemy more ill-advised have been brought to a successful issue. It is difficult to choose between tuxo/nta and tuxo/ntwn, chanced to be, agreeing with e)nanti/wn, but in such a matter the authority of CG is to be preferred (the Schol. read tuxo/nta): for the same reason a(/ is best omitted after plei/w.

26. e)nqumei=tai ga\r ktl.—lit. no man by his confidence forms plans in the same spirit (o)moi=a=o)moi/ws) as he carries them but, i.e. a man may be confident when he makes a plan: it does not follow that he does not carry it out in the same spirit. Reiske's o)moi/a|, with the same degree of confidence, makes the eonstruetion easier, but is not certainly necessary. e)/rgw| goes so closely with e)pece/rxetai that th=| pi/stei just before in a different relation to its verb is not felt to be awkward. The security with which the notion is formed gives place to apprehension, and so ‘we are found wanting.’ Hence ta\ kalw=s bouleuqe/nta miscarry.
3. h/mei=s de/—the application of the general statements in e. 120. 3.
5. a)munw/meqa—aorist (fut.-perf.).
6. kataqhso/meqa—cf. ti/qesqai c. 82. 6.
7. kata\ polla/—on many grounds.

9. o(moi/ws pa/ntas—all with equal readiness carrying out the orders given, i.e. in the field, as usual; and the edd. point out that the allusion is to the ku/smos for which the Dorians
were famous. Cf. 5.66. i/e/nai e)s ta\ paraggello/mena occurs again in in. 55 in the sense to answer to a call. For i)e/nai e)s of eager action cf. c. 1.
12. e)cartuso/meqa—the reading of C is clearly right: there is no place here for the hortative subj.
tw=n ... xrhma/twn—the treasure in the temples. These could only be treated as a loan.
15. ce/nous—adj., those from the subject allies.

17. h(=sson a)\n tou=to pa/qoi—i.e. to\ u(polamba/nesqai misqw=| mei/zoni, because our men are not paid—it is the service of men, not money, that gives us our strength. toi=s xrh/masi corresponds to w)nhth/.

19. naumaxi/as—defining gen; a(li/skontai of course is pres. for fut., ‘they are lost.’ (Some see here a reference after the event to the battle of Aegospotami and the capture of Athens; but the te shows that the sentence is a conclusion from what precedes; and Aegospotami was not the result of the cause there stated.)
ei) d' a)nti/sxoien—supposing they should hold out, i.e. if they are not defeated at sea after all (meaning suppose we are defeated instead), we shall get the better of them in the end.

24. d d' e). e)pisth/mh| prou/xousi—the advantage that they have in point of skill. o(/ is aceus. of measure, and the dat. as usual gives the point of excellence (o(/ is not accus, of respect; and as to Antig. 208 timh\n proe/cous) see Jehb's note). For the superiority of fu/sis over didaxh/ see c. 139. 2.
25. kaqaireto/n—we can annul: kaqairete/on would mean we must, which does not give a good antithesis to ou)k a(\n ge/noito. Again C alone has the correct form.
26. e)s au)ta/—viz. e)s to\ meleta=n ta\ nautika\ e(/ws a)\n e)s to\ i)/son katasthsw/meqa.
27. h)/—otherwise.

ei) ou)k ... a)perou=sin ... ou)k a)/ra dapanh/somen—in a bimembered sentence of this kind, ou) is regularly used in the second clause if the verb is in indic., mh/ if the verb is in opt. The first clanse is logieally subordinate to the second. Cf. Andoc. 1.102 ou)k ou)=n deino/n, ei) u(po\ me\n tou/twn dia\ tou=t' a)\n a)pwlo/mhn ... e)n u(mi=n de\ krino/menos ... ou( swqh/somai;
3. a)/ra—we then decide not, i.e. infer that this is the way to attain our objects.
4. au)ta/—this and autoi=s tou/tois refer to xrh/mata.

6. cumma/xwn te a)po/stasis ktl.—such as revolt of allies, which means in the main withdrawal of the revenues that give them their strength, and erection of a hostile fortress in their country. The first ‘way of war’ was followed by Brasidas in 424 B.C.: the second was not used until 413 B C. (Decelea), but the Athenians had then long feared such an attempt. The context makes it clear that a)po/stasis implies the bringing about of revolt.
11 e)pi\ r(htoi=s—in accordance with fixed conditions; cf. c. 13. 1: the meaning is explained in the following words.

13. e)n w(=| ktl.—and in this case, i e. ‘and this being so, he who enters on war in a calm spirit is safer, whereas he who loses control of himself over it gets more falls.’ The meaning is ‘opportunities arise in war and have to be seized as they arise: it is not well for us to get excited now in thinking out plans of campaign—such cut and dried schemes generally miscariy—but what we must do is to enter on war calmly and take opportunities as they occur.’ o)rgh/ means excitement, not anger here; cf. 2.11. 7: ou)k e)la/ssw euphemism for plei/w, i.e. probably h)\ o( eu(orgh/tws prosomilh/sas.
17. e(ka/stois—each state.
pro\s a)ntipa/lous—with an enemy equal to us (and not stronger)
18. oi)sto/n—the position would be easy, i.e. there would be no need for us to combine.

20. kata\ po/lin=(pro\s h(ma=s)kata\ po/lin, lit. as compared with us separately city by city. For e)/ti we expect polu/, far more powerful, since we want a strong contrast after i(kanoi\ pro\s cu/mpantas. e)/ti must be regarded as a meiosis (Conradt and Steup have proposed considerable changes, but the text appears to be sound)
21. kai\ a(qro/oi—not only as a confederacy, but every tribe and every single town.
25. a)/ntikrus doulei/an—downright slavery; cf. viii. 64 h( a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/a; the adv. qualifies noun though without the art., as in vii. 81 ou/ custado\n ma/xais e)xrw=nto.
26. d kai\ ktl.—the very mention of which as a possibility is disgraceful (Wilkins). o(/ is to\ douleu/ein.

27. kai\ po/leis ktl.—some edd. make this a second subject to e)ndoiasqh=nai (Kruger, Classen, Croiset), which gives an excelleut sense: but the constn. is simpler if ai)sxro/n is made pred. to this—and that so many cities should be maltreated by one. Whichever be right, the ref. must be to the misery of political slavery imposed by Athens; and cannot, in view of the next sentence, and of h/leuqe/rwsan, opp. doulei/an, apply to the present treatment of the confederacy.
28. e)n w)=|—in that case; cf. 122.1;=ei) po/leis tosai/de ... kakopaqoi=men.

2. h(mei=s de/—this is in contiast with oi)/=oi) me\n ga\r(pate/res). au)to/ means th\n e)leuqeri/an implied in h(leuqe/rwsan. h(mi=n au)toi=s of course means for the Peloponnesiaus: and this clause implies ‘much less do we give freedom to all Greece’: hence there is no difficulty in supplying e)n th=| *(ella/di to egkaqesta/nai.

3. tu/rannon de\ ... katalu/ein—we allow a despotic state to establish itself in Greece; and yet we make a point of putting down despots in any single city. tou\s e)n mia=|, sc po/lei (which possibly has dropped out of the text), mona/rxous is opposed to tu/rannon po/lin e)n *(ella/di. The traditional policy of Sparta is alluded to.
5. i)/smen—sc. h(mei=s (of the speaker). The subject is not identical with that of a)ciou=men (the confederacy).

6. ta/de ... a)ph/llaktai—this policy is (=can possibly be) free from—viz. the policy of allowing an Athens to flourish. As it is not free from all three, it is exposed to at least one: hence there is no need for e(no/s after cumforw=n: see p. 31 l. 5.

8. ou) ga\r dh\ pefeugo/tes au)ta/—the rendering ‘we cannot suppose that you have avoided these evils only to’ etc. (Classen, Croiset, Forbes, etc), meaning by irony ‘we suspect that you have,’ cannot be right, since the previous sentence distinctly says, ‘you have not escaped all three of these cumforai/.’ Hence we must transl. (with Kruger, Bohme, Steup): ‘For it is not the case that you are free from these errors in assuming that contempt which has proved ruinous to so many (dh/ strengthens plei/stous), and which from its tendency to trip men up, has received instead (sc. from prudent men) the opposite name of folly.’ Nothing is gained by preserving the jingle in katafro/nhsis and afrosu/nh, because (1) to a Greek writer such a jingle
has some rhetorical merit; in English it is detestable and pointless; (2) though a)frosu/nh is spoken of as the opposite (e)nanti/on) of katafro/nhsis, it is really only different, but early Greek thinkers on the meaning of terms often confuse the contiary with the contradictory. to\ e)nanti/on o)/noma is internal accus. to metwno/mastai.
13. toi=s nu=n—neut., and so mello/ntwn and parou=si.
14. peri/=u(pe/r, with e)pitalaipwrei=n, i.e. prosqei=nai to\n po/non (Schol.).

16. e)k tw=n po/nwn ta\s a)reta/s—famous characteristic of the Dorians. Cf. Hesiod, W. and D. 289 (Plat Rep. p. 364 D, Xen. Mem. 2.1.20) th=s a)reth=s i(drw=ta qeoi\ propa/roiqen e)/qhkan, quoted by several edd ˙ in the Funeral Speech Pericles speaks of the e)pi/ponos a)/skhsis of the Spartans.
18. e)cousi/a|—duna/mei.
profe/rete=proe/xete, only used in this way by Herod., Thuc., and poets.
21. kata\ polla/—three grounds for confidence are presently given.
22. au)tou=—see c. 118. 3.

24. ta\ me\n fo/bw| ktl.—those who are not yet enslaved by the Athenians fear to be so (fo/bw|); those who are so already hope to regain their liberty (w(feli/a|), Croiset. w)feli/a|, dat. of motive, is, as Mr. Forbes says, here used for the idea (desire) of the thing rather than for the thing itself; he compares a(reth/ c. 33 and timh/ c. 75; and so elsewhere.
25. sponda/s—c. 53. 2.
2. koinh=|—in the common interest.

3. ei)/per bebaio/taton ktl.—inasmuch as the surest ground (for taking common action) is that both cities and individnals have the same interests. This is the only natural way of taking the words, for the order does not allow kai\ po/lesi kai\ i). to go with bebaio/taton, as Classen supposed (Stahl and others alter the text to make this constn. possible). The meaning is explained by ou)=si *dwrieu=si ktl.: it is the interest of every city and every individual member of the confederacy that Dorians should be protected from Ionians. (The MSS. have tau=ta for tau)ta/, and this is transl. ‘since it is most certain that this course—to go to war—is to the interest of,’ etc.)
7. ou(= pro/teron h)=n t.—in former times Dorians were recognised as supertor in war to Ionians. In such a rhetorical statement we need not look for any specific historical reference.

9. w(s ou)ke/ti e)nde/xetai ktl.—for it is now out of the question that we should wait (for common action by the confederacy), and that some of us (e g. we Corinthians) should now be suffering and others ... should shortly have the same experience. Cf. vii. 42 nomi/sas ou)x oi(=o/n te ei)=nai diatri/bein ou)de\ paqei=n o(/per o( *niki/as e)/paqen.
16. au)tou=—tou= pole/mou.
17. dia\ plei/onos—of time, in contrast with au)ti/ka.
e)k pole/mou me\n ktl.—the sentence becomes clear when toi=s e)s a)na/gkhn a)figme/nois is supphed from above, i.e. where war becomes a necessity. polemh=sai is ingressive.
23. dianoei=sqai—cf. c. 1. 1.
4. to\ plh=qos—often of the greater number.

6. e)kpori/zesqai ... e(ka/stois—as the several states were to carry out a general resolution, it is best with Steup to take e)k, as passive and e(ka/stois as agent. It is then unnecessary to read e(ka/stous.
8. kaqistame/nois—paraskeuazome/nois (Schol.).

9 e)niauto\s me\n ou) d., e)/lasson de/—this certainly emphasises the length of time occupied, in spite of their haste, and not the promptitude of the coufederacy; the latter would be inconsistent with all that precedes (c. 71. 4; 124. 1, and this section).
