Thuc. means clearly (it seems to me), ‘I was going to say a year was consumed: but no, it was less than that’; i.e. it was not much less. (1) In 2.2, if the text is sound, we read that the entry into Plataea took place at the very beginning of spring 431, and in the sixth month after the battle of Potidaea (see c. 62); and (2) we are further told that the first invasion of Attica was eighty days after the seizure of Plataea. Hence the whole time between the battle of Potidaea and the first invasion would be less than nine months, and to arrive at the length of time that separates the resolution of the confederacy from the first invasion, we must deduct the time occupied by the events narrated in cc. 63-88 and 118-125, which are:
1. The Athenians built a wall on north side of Potidaea and garrisoned it
2. xro/nw| u(/steron Phormio was sent from Attica with 1600 hoplites, and kata\ braxu\ proh/ei.
3. Phormio built a wall south of Potidaea.
4. The Corinthians called a meeting at Sparta. (At what exact stage of affairs this was done is not clear.)
5. The Spartans sent to Delphi.
6. The general meeting was held at Sparta, and the decision taken.
Hence the time would be much less than a year; and it is probable that the mhni\ e(/ktw| of 2.2 is somehow coriupt.
pri\n e)sbalei=n—under Archidamus. The account of it is in 2.19.
12. e)presbeu/onto—following, as it turned out, the advice of Archidamus; see c. 82. He was afterwards blamed for not having been eager to begin the war.

18. to\ a)/gos th=s qeou=—i.e. those who were under the curse of Athena. The chief authorities for the story of Cylon and the Alcmaeonidae are, besides Thuc, Hdt. 5.71 (Thuc. differs from him, and is perhaps correcting his account), Plut. Sol. 12. The Ath. Pol. mit. shows that the attempt of Cylon preceded the legislation of Draco. a)/gos is a pollution under which a person, a house, or a community labours.
20. *ku/lwn h)=n—two scholia show that the following narrative was admired in antiquity for its clearness and smoothness; one says ‘The Lion laughed here.’
*)olumpioni/khs—in 640 B.C. (see Sandys on Ath. Pol. init.).
21. tw=n pa/lai—part., ‘of his date’ (not, ‘of an ancient family’).
23. kat' e)kei=non to\n xro/non—his expulsion is supposed to have occuried in 600 or 590 B.C.
24. xrwme/nw|—cf. c. 123. 1. Both act. and mid. are rare in Attic, the act sense being given by a)nairw= or manteu/omai, the mid. by e)perwtw=.

1. e)ph=lqen—the reading e)ph=lqon has not enough MS. support to be acceptable; but in 5.49 all MSS. give *karnei_a etu/gxanon o)/nta. In two other places in Thuc. all MSS. give plur. with neut. plur. subj.—5.26 a(marth/mata ege/nonto; 6.62 e)ge/nonto ... ei)/kosi kai\ e(kato\n ta/lanta. In Xen. the plur. is common.
4. ti prosh/kein—had some connexion.
7. e)/ti kateno/hse ... e)dh/lou—had not gone on to consider ... gave no information.

8. *dia/sia—for the Athenians too have (their festival of Zeus) the Diasia, which is called the greatest festival of Zeus Meilichius, in contrast with other festivals of Zeus Meilichius. Of course kai/ before *)aqhnai/ois does not imply that the Pel. had Diasia, but *dia/sia is a brachylogy for e(orth\ *dio\s *dia/sia.
10. pandhmei/—by the whole people together, not in separate demes.

polla\ ou)x i(erei=a, a)ll' < a(gna\ > q. e).—Pollux 1.26 (2nd cent. A.D.) says ‘spices are also ealled “incense”: Thuc. calls them a(gna\ qu/mata in contrast with ta\ ai(ma/ssonta kai\ sfatto/mena,’ i.e. with i/erei=a. Hence a(gna/ is to be read here. The Schol. says ‘cakes made in the shape of animals’ are meant. polloi/ of the MSS. will not do, because it is inconsistent with pandhmei/. (polloi/ without de/ could not=but many, as the Schol. suggests; and the Schol. eannot have read here pandhmei\ e(orta/zousi, qu/ousi de\ polloi/, which Stahl prints, since those are the very words of his note, and he would merely have copied out the text verbatim. Lastly qu/mata e)pixw/ria, meaning cakes or ‘incense,’ is not inconsistent with Xen. Anab. vii. 8, where we read that Xen. had sacrificed holocausts to Zeus Meilichius when at home: this cannot refer to the Diasia, but must mean another feast of Zeus Meilichius.)
14. au)tou/s—Cylon and his supporters, who had seized the acropolis.
proskaqezo/menoi—this form serves for the aor. as well as pres.
15. e)ggignome/nou—being spent over the matter. Cf. xro/nos e)ne/stai p. 61 l. 17.
17. toi=s e)nne/a a)/rxousi—Megacles the Alcmaeonid was one of them.
18. au)tokra/torsi—without reference to the assembly.
19. a)/rista—adj., sc. ei)=nai, like a)/meino/n e)sti, for this is merely plur. for sing.
to/te de/—the ten strathgoi/ did not as yet exist, and the archons were appointed (not elected by lot) by the Areopagus. In the time of Thuc. their duties were almost entirely judicial.
26. to\n bwmo/n of Athena
1. a)nasth/santes=a)nasth=nai pei/santes, and on this depends e)f' w(=|, for which cf. c. 103. 1.
tw=n *)aqhnai/wn—partitive: see c. 9. 2.

5. e)pi\ tw=n semnw=n q. toi=s bwmoi=s—at the altars of the Eumenides, probably the most sacred asylum at Athens. The shrine stood by the cleft in the NE. side of the Areopagus, where the Furies were established, after being reconciled to Athena. toi=s bwmoi=s is however probably spurious; the order is suspicious (cf. 5.50 e)pi\ to\n bwmo\n tou= *dio/s), and cf. Arist. Knights 1311 kaqh=sqai/ moi dokei= ei)s to\ *qhs ei=on pleou/sais h)\ 'pi\ tw=n semnw=n qew=n, and Thesm. 224 (qe/w)e)s to\ tw=n semnw=n qew=n.
6. e)n th=| paro/dw| with kaqezome/nous, on the way, while passing from the altar of Athena. It was because they feared they were to be killed that they sought asylum a second time.

7. e)nagei=s kai\ a)lith/rioi th=s qeou=—cf. Arist. Eq. 445 e)k tw=n a)lithri/wn se/ fhmi gegone/nai th=s qeou= (Cleon to the Sausage-man). a/lith/rioi were thought dangerous people to live with (cf. Neil ad l.c.), and so the Alcmaeonidae were all banished, and at first for ever, Ath. Pol. i. But they returned, and in 508 a second expulsion took place at the instigation of the opponents of Cleisthenes the Alcmaeonid, who were supported by Cleomenes.
12. stasiazo/ntwn—the party opposed to Cleisthenes and led by Isagoras. Cleisthenes was almost immediately recalled.
13. ta\ o)sta= a)nelo/ntes—so Ath. Pol. i. e)k tw=n ta/fwn e)ceblh/qhsan, but the incident is there connected with the first expulsion.
17. prw=ton—first and foremost. dh=qen shows this is sarcastic.

19. kata\ th\n mhte/ra—the family tree is as follows:— Megacles, the Archon Alcmaeon Megacles, opponent of Peisistratus Ariphron Cleisthenes o( th\n dhmokrati/an Agariste m. Xanthippus katasth/sas Pericles Ariphron
20. r(a=|on <a)/n>—the addition of a)/n is necessary; cf. c. 57. 5. There is no ex. of pres. in fut. sense after nomi/zw (Stahl, Q.G. pp. 6 f.).
22. paqei_n a)\n ... oi)/sein—the aor with a)/n expresses a contingency, the fut. a certainty. The subject of oi)/sein is prob. au)to/ or to\ pra=gma supplied in sense.
23. w(s—since.
24. to\ me/ros—partly; cf. p. 66 l. 9.
26. a)/gwn th\n politei/an—cf. 2.65 of Pericles to\ plh=qos h)=ge. In Ath. Pol. c. 27 th\n p. a)/gein ei)s au(tou/s=to get political power into their own hands.
2. to\ a)po\ *t. a)/gos—the pollution resulting from (the affair of) Mt. Taenarus.
8. seismo/n—c. 101. 2.
9. *xalkioi/kou—there was a bronze temple and statue of Athena at Sparta on the Acropolis; hence the name The te/menos covered a considerable space and contained several buildings.
11. to\ prw=ton—for the first time; see c. 95.
15. *(ermioni/da—of Hermione, in Argolis.
16. a)/neu—without the orders of; cf. c. 91. 5. i)di/a| gives, in the positive form, the same sense as a)/neu *l.; cf. 1.119.

17. *(ellhniko/n—national, that against Persia; if the reading is right the object is to make an antithesis with ta\ pro\s basile/a p., but *(ellhniko\s p. generally means a war against or ‘between Greeks.’ Many edd. accept *mhdiko/n (see crit. note).
19. pra/ssein—inf. of purpose; cf. 6.8. 2 cugkatoiki/sai *leonti/nous. The sense of diplomatic or secret negotiation often underlies pra/ssw.
20. *(ellhnikh=s—to rule Greece.
21. a)po\ tou=de—referring to what follows. For kate/qeto cf. c. 33. 1.
23. *buza/ntion—see c. 94. 2.
th=| prote/ra| p.—dat of time without e)n is possible, as parousi/a implies time; cf. c. 44, 2.20, e)kei(nh| th=| e)sbolh=|.

26. to/te—at that time, viz. th=| prote/ra| parousi/a|: many edd. following Kruger put to/te inside the parenthesis and take
it with e(a/lwsan, and this seems more likely. tou/twn has been conjectured for tou/tous: but tou/tous refers prob. to basile/ws prosh/kontes kai\ cuggenei=s, and e)/laben=‘captured,’ not ‘received as his share of the spoil.’
1. tw=n a)/llwn c.—the exclusive use of a)/llos, the rest, i.e. the allies.
2. *goggu/lou—he received from Xerxes certain places in the Troad in reward for his treason, and in the time of Thuc. his descendants still possessed them.
5. au)tw=|—basilei=.
9. dori/=ma/xh|, poetical, a remnant of the Ionic in which the original letter was composed.
gnw/mhn poiou=mai—propose. Stephanus altered a)pope/mpei above to a)pope/mpw, but the same change from 3rd to 1st pers. occurs in the terms of the Peace of Antalcidas, Xen. Hell. 5.1.31.
10. th\n sh/n—sh/n=‘a daughter of yours’ may be right (sce crit. note).
17. h(/sqh te kai\ a)poste/llei—the co-ordination of historic pres. and aorist is common in Thuc; cf. c. 131. 2.
20. *daskuli=tin—Dascylium in Bithynia was the capital of this province, *frugi/a e)f' *(ellhspo/ntw|, or ka/tw *frugi/a. The Persian empire was divided into twenty satrapies.
22. kai/ answers te, so that strictly we should have a second infin., but the constn. of the kai/-clause is changed and made independent, as in 3.94. 3; 4.3.3; 5.61. 4.
23. a)ntepeti/qei—charged him with ... in return; Croiset compares Dem. 34.28 ta\s e)pistola/s a(\s e)peqh/kamen. The infin. follows as with di/dwmi, as if he had said a)ntepe/stelle.
24. a(podei=cai—i.e to show to Pausanias, through the messenger, the great king's seal on the letter.
25. e(autou=—basile/ws.

2. tw=n a)ndrw=n ... kei/setai/ soi eu)ergesi/a—lit. in connexion with the men ... a service is set down to you in the record for ever. tw=n a)ndrw=n is objective gen; eu/ergesi/a is the service
rendered by Pausanias (not, as Mr. Forbes supposes, due to him). The benefactors of the Great King were recorded in a chronicle, Herod. 8.33. kei=tai is the pass. of kate/qeto, c. 128. 4. Pausanias had established a right to consideration for himself and his descendants.
6. a)re/skomai—not the Ionic use of e. 35. 2.
mh/te nu\c mh/q' h(me/ra—this and xrusou= kai\ a)rgu/rou dapa/nh| are quite in the Persian style: we can hardly doubt that the letter is substantially genuine.
9. kekwlu/sqw—se. w(=n e)moi\ u(pisxnei= ti. The 3rd pers. is awkward, and kekw/luso has been proposed.
12. ka/llista kai\ a)/rista—cf. Xen. Anab. 3.1.6 e(ph/reto ti/ni a)\n qu/wn ka/llista kai\ a)/rista e)/lqoi.

19. skeua\s *mhdika/s—the dress was the ka/ndus, a long robe with long broad sleeves over a short tunic, a)nacuri/des, trousers, and tia/ra, head-dress; also bracelets (ye/lia) and necklaces (streptoi/).
22. tra/peza/n te—epulabatur more Persarum luxuriosius, says Nepos (Pausanias 3.2; cf. the Persicos odi apparatus of Horace, The simplicity of the Greek dei=pnon is notorious.
24. braxe/si—small.
th=| gnw/mh|—with e)/melle, he meant to.
26. o)rgh=|—temper in neutral sense; cf. c. 122. 1. He made men ‘wait before his doors’ as if he were a satrap.
4. a)neka/lesan—plup. in sense.
7. e)k tou= *buzanti/ou—see c. 128. 5.
10. *trw|a/das—adj.=*trwika/s; cf. 6.62 *(ella\s po/lis. The use of such forms as adj. is poetical and Ionic.

14. skuta/lhn—a secret message. Plut. Lys. 19 gives a complete description: when a general was sent out from Sparta two sticks of exactly the same size were prepared; the ephors kept one, the officer the other. When the ephors wished to send a secret message, they wrapped a strip of papyrus round their stick spirally and wrote on it. They then sent the papyrus only, and in order to read it, the officer had to wrap it again round the other stick. Both sticks and message were called skuta/lh.
16 proagoreu/ein—depending on ei)=pon, but in a different relation; cf. c. 26. 5.
20. to\n basile/a—and Pausanias was only the king's guardian.
21. diapraca/menos—by some form of negotiation (probably bribery) he was released from prison.

23. peri\ au)tw=n—i e. tw=n kathgorhma/twn (Schol.): sc. e)auto/n. The other reading peri\ au)to/n is hardly detended by e)k tw=n peri\ *pausani/an e)le/gxwn c. 135. 2, for the verb is regularly trans.
26. a)/n—with e)timwrou=nto.

4. i)/sos ei)=nai toi=s parou=si — to conform to existing conditions, toi=s h)/qesi tw=n *aakw/nwn (Schol.), or better, to the circumstances in which he found himself as a *spartia/ths. (Various alterations of the text have been proposed here, e.g. e+|n toi=s parou=si, in his present conduct Croiset—or e)pi\ toi=s p. Stein—but there seems to be no very definite objection to it as it stands.)
5. ta/ te a)/lla—the te=‘both,’ looking as to what follows; so that we have here an explanation of upoyias ... parou=si. (Some edd. insert kai/ before ta/.)
6. e)cededih/|thto ktl.=e)/cw tw=n ... e)dedih/|thto.

7. to\n tri/poda—this was a golden tripod suppoited by a bronze stand in the shape of three serpents twisted together (Herod. 9.33). It was dedicated after Plaraea. The gold part was afterwards destroyed by the Phocians in the Sacred War (Pausan. x. xiii. 9), but the stand was removed to Byzantium, and still exists at Constantinople. See Hicks Man. Hist. Inscr. p. 11.
10. to\ e)legei=on—this ‘couplet,’ which ‘he dared to have inscribed on his own authority,’ is attributed to Simonides of Ceos. In the Anthology it reads thus:
*(ella/nwn a)rxago\s e)pei\ strato\n w)/lesa *mh/dwn *hausani/as *foi/bw| mna=m' a)ne/qhka to/de.
a)rxhgo/s was a title of the Spartan kings.
14. eu)qu\s to/te—at the time that the tripod was offered.
17. me/ntoi—although the offensive inscription was removed.

a)di/khma kai\ to/t' e)do/kei ei)=nai—(this act) was thought even at that time to be a crime. The subject of e)do/kei is au)to/, the act of having the couplet inseribed. to/t' was first adopted by Classen for tou=t', and kai\ e)pei/ ge dh\ e)n tou/tw| kaqeisth/kei requires it as a contrast of time: also there is no point in kai\ tou=t', as no other offence of P. in earlier times has been mentioned to justify kai/. Stem inserts tou=to after a/di/khma, but this is not necessary.
18. e)pei/ ge dh\ e)n tou/tw| kaqeisth/kei—i.e now when he was accused of ‘Medism.’ e\pei/ ge dh/ is more emphatie than e)peidh/.
25. ou)de\ tw=n ... pisteu/santes—an explanation of ou)d' w(/s.
mhnutai=s—the technical word for an informer who had not full citizen-rights
27. ei)w/qasin—sc. xrh=sqai.
4. *)argi/lios—he was a slave from the Thracian town Argilus.

5. au)tou= ... e)kei/nw|—applying to the same person; cf. IV. 73. 4; VI. 61. 7 kate/gnwsan au)tou= kai\ tw=n met' ekei/nou: Audoc. 1, 64 ei)=pon au)toi=s ... e)kei/nois de/: conversely vii. 14 ei) prosgenh/setai ... pro\s e)kei/nous xwrh=sai, diapepolemh/setai au)toi=s: Plat. Rep. p. 343 C eu)dai/mona e)kei=non poiou=sin u(phretou=ntes au)tw=|.

mhnuth\s gi/gnetai, dei/sas ... kai\ parashmhna/menos ... lu/ei —kai/ joins dei/sas to lu/ei, which should strictly be lu/sas: the constn. is thus changed from partic. to finite verb, as 2.47 lego/menon me\n ... ou) me/ntoi e)mnhmoneu/eto: vii. 13 tw=n nautw=n me\n ... a)pollume/nwn, oi) de\ qera/pontes ... au)tomolou=si.

Stem reads ds dei/sas, but no change is needed. kai/ does not join gi/gnetai to lu/ei because the clause with lu/ei is anterion in time to g. mhnuth/s, and such a hysteron proteron is without example in Thuc.
6. kata\ e)nqu/mhsi/n tina=e)nqumhqei/s, because he noticed.

8. parashmhna/menos—counterfeiting; ‘for Thuc. says parashmhna/menos th\n sfragi=da in the sense of paratupw/sasqai’ Pollux viii. 27. This reading, restored by Hude, is better than parapoihsa/menos, which is probably a gloss on it.

h)\n yeusqh=| th=s do/chs—i.e. if his suspicion about the contents of the letter proved false. He could then replace the seal and go on to Artabazus. Did it not occur to him that even in this case he might ‘never return,’ i.e. be put to death?

9. h)\ kai\ e)kei=nos—i.e. in case Pausanias should ask for the letter back before the messenger left, in order to alter something in it. If the messenger's suspicion about the letter proved false, he would say nothing, but seal up the letter. But suppose the man's suspicions proved true, why should be not have contemplated an immediate visit to the ephors, without giving Pausanias time to ask for the letter back? In point of fact this is what the man did. (The text is suspected by some edd.—e.g Herwerden and Stenp—but the confusion of the messenger's motives seems to come from Thuc.)
14 e)pi/steusan—sc. that the information they had received from the helots was true.
16. a)po\ paraskeuh=s—cf. Lysias 13.22 ei) mh\ e)k paraskeuh=s e)mhnu/eto, by collusion, or arrangement, here with the gen. abs.
17. e)pi\ *tai/naron—the shrine of Poseidon on Taenarus was sanctuary (asylum).

18. skhnhsame/nou—both skhna=sqai and skhnei=sqai are elsewhere intrans., but here the sense must be trans.: hence Madvig proposed skeuasame/nou, and one inferior MS. gives skhnwsame/nou: Stein reads e)s diplh=n.
19. tw=n [te]—the te has no correlative and is no doubt spurious.
23. ta/ te ... kai\ ta)=ll' a)pofai/nontos—the position of te shows that a)pofai/nontos is added by an afterthought.
24. w(s ou)de\n ... paraba/loito—that he had never hazarded P.'s interests—a gambling term.
26. protimhqei/h de/—ironical: this was all the reward he had got. e)n i)/sw|=o(moi/ws.
2. pi/stin ... a)nasta/sews—pledging his word for his departure from the temple, sc. in safety. (e)k tou= i(erou= is perhaps a commentator's note on th=s a)nasta/sews.)
4. ta\ prasso/mena—the negotiations with the king. The sentence here concluded is a remarkable instance of the partiality of Thuc. for the circumstantial participle.
12. dhlw/santos—sc. what was about to happen. eu)noi/a| is dat. of cause.
19. e)/ndon o)/nta—i.e. making sure that he was in the oi)/khma.
21. e)cepolio/rkhsan—the terms are taken from the starving out of a city.

22. w(/sper ei)=xen—as he was, ‘in his present condition,’ i.e. shut up in the building; cf. e.g. 2.46. (In 6.57. 3 I accepted Krüger's version ‘forthwith’; but I agree with Steup that this is wrong.) If he had ‘expired’ inside, the holy place would have been profaned.

25. to\n *kaia/dan—the exact site of this ravine called Caeadas is not known: it was in the hills near Sparta. kai/ata, crevices produced by earthquake, were so common in Laconia that Sparta is called kaieta/essa in Homer.

26. ou(=per tou\s kakou/rgous—the Schol. is e)mbalei=n dhlono/ti (scilicet). to/pos o( *ke/adas o)rwrugme/nos e)n *lakwnikh=|, o(/pou tou\s kakou/rgous ei)w/qasi r(iptei=n. The words of this note have got mixed with the text in the MSS. in several ways, and it is very probable that ou(=per tou\s kakou/rgous is due to the note. (ou(=per ought to be oi(=per, but this error—which is common in MSS.— does not count against the genuineness of the words. Volgraff first bracketed them.)
2. ou(=per—the omitted antecedent is e)kei=se.
3. protemeni/smati —o( pro\ ... tou= teme/nous to/pos (Schol.) until then unconsecrated.
4. o(/—i.e. to\ to\n ta/fon kei=sqai e(n tw=| p.
w(s ktl.—accus. abs.
7. a)ndria/ntas—not necessarily statues of Pausanias; but symbolic fignres consecrated to the gods of the upper world.
15. toi=s au)toi=s—i.e. qana/tw|.

16. e)/tuxe ga\r w)strakisme/nos—when this had happened is unknown; 471 B.C. is generally favoured in spite of the statement in Ath. Pol. that Them. was at Athens in 462 B.C.: the year depends upon other events such as the reduction of Naxos (see c. 137. 2)—of which the date is uncertain. For a discussion see Sandys on Ath. Pol. c. 25.
20. a)/gein—sc. to Athens.

23. eu)erge/ths—by some official act, probably in some dispute with another state, according to Plutarch with Corinth. In all such decrees of honour conferred on a ce/nos a clause giving him a)suli/a was contained; and on this clause Them. relied.
23. au)tw=n—the Corcyreans; for this idiom cf. c. 34. 4.

26. a)pexqe/sqai —e)xqro\s (leg. e)xqrou\s)gene/sqai (Schol.). The MSS. a)pe/xqesqai assumes a pres. form a)pe/xqomai: similarly in vii. 75 ABEFM give ai/sqesqai as from ai/sqomai, but CG have ai)sqe/sqai: in Eur. Phoen. 300 the MSS. have qi/gein as from qi/gw(qigga/nw). But that these only oceur in forms that may be aorists is very suspicious: with other such double forms—e.g. au)/cw beside au)ca/nw—the indic. forms occur.
28. kata\ pu/stin h(=| x.—in accordance with inquiry as to the road he took. The opt. is iterative.
2. *molossw=n—in Epirus. What the ‘diffieulty’ was that led Them. to one who was ‘no friend of his’ is not explained.
5. kaqe/zesqai—aor. in sense: the mid. form kaqi/zomai is not used.
7. ou)k a)cioi=—asks him not to ...
8. *)aqhnai/wn deome/nw|—Them. must have opposed a request from Admetus for Athenian help.

9. kai\ ga\r a)\n ktl.—for at the present time I might be ill-treated by one far weaker than you (e)kei/nou=h)\ e)kei=nos, depending on a)sqeneste/rou); but it is generous (like a gentleman) to take vengeance on equals (not on inferiors) and when equal to them (and not stronger). This curious form of appeal must be the invention of Thuc.; and we may doubt whether it would have moved such a king.
13. xrei/as tino/s—in reference to, the gen. of separation parallel to e)s to\ s. sw/|zesqai.

e)s to\ sw=ma sw/|zesqai—lit. with reference to preserving his life, i.e. in a matter of life and death. sw/|zesqai is mid. Recent edd. take to/ with sw/|zesqai: but it is possible Poppo was right in supposing that in cases like the present the single article does double duty. Cf. Plat. Gorg. p. 489 C mhdeno\s a)/cioi plh\n i)/sws tw=| sw/mati i)sxuri/sasqai. Note that yuxh/ below, coriesponding to sw=ma, has the article.
16. a)posterh=sai a)/n—would withhold; this is the proper sense of a)posterei=n, and hence swthri/as is required.
18. w(/sper kai/—the kai/ marks the connexion of the two acts, a)ni/sthsi—e(kaqe/zeto e)/xwn au)to/n =met' au)tou=. Notice the extreme solemnity of supplication by the life of the child.
19. kai\ me/giston h)=n i(. tou=to—parenthetical.
23. e(te/ran—the Aegean.

24. th\n *)a.—sc. po/lin. This Alexander was father of Perdiccas (see c. 57). Thuc. calls the town ‘Alexander's’ because it lay south of Macedon proper. Its status caused difficulty at various times, for it never fully acquiesced in Macedonian rule till conquered by Philip the Great.
26. xeimw=ni—the wind was north, and unless the captain tacked would carry the ship right into Naxos.

27. o(\ e)polio/rkei *na/con—the accession of Artaxerxes, who had lately ascended the throne when Them. arrived (see 137.4) took place in 465 B.C. Hence, to make the dates suit, the siege of Naxos was assigned by Schafer to 466 B.C.; but, judging from the narrative of cc. 89-90, this leaves too short an interval between the siege of Naxos and the death of Xerxes; for Eurymedon was fought before the latter event, and yet, apparently, some time after the revolt of Naxos. Hence other modern authorities assign the siege of Naxos to 468, 470 or even 473 B.C. But then the narrative here cannot be correct. In Plut. Them. 25, where this passage is used, some MSS. have *qa/son for *na/con: and this would suit here better (see c. 100. 2); but there may be a mistake on Thuc.'s part.
4. th\n de\ a)sfa/leian ei)=nai—i.e. ‘his safety depended on.’
5. me/xri—with me/xri, me/xri ou(= and pri/n Thuc. occasionally uses subj. without a)/n according to the older idiom; but e(/ws with plain subj. does not occur.
plou=s—until fair weather came, in contrast with xeimw/n above: this and not ‘until he sailed’ seems to be the sense; plou=s=eu)/ploia, as also in 3.3 plw=| xrhsa/menos kai\ tritai=os a)fiko/menos.
6. a)pomnh/sesqai—the ordinary fut. in Attic is mnhsqh/somai, but Herod. uses mnh/somai.

11. au)tw=|—for the poetical use of dat. after h)=lqe cf. c. 13. 3. The aor. is plupert. in sense, and u)/steron means after his flight. At Athens his goods were confiscated so far as they were found, because he was a traitor.
13. ka/tw ... a)/nw—as in a)na/-basis and kata/-basis.
15. newsti\ basileu/onta—for newsti/ with imperf. partic. cf. 3.20 a)ndrw=n ncwsti\ po/lin e)xontwn.
o(/ti—this convenient form of quasi-oblique speech, where the speaker's actual words follow o(/ti, oceurs only in prose.
17. u(me/teron—referring of course to the royal family.
18. e)pio/nta e)moi/—a fine touch due to self-confidence.
20 e)n tw=| a)sfalei= me\n ktl.—when he retreated (pa/lin belongs to a)pokomidh/) himself in danger, while I was in safety.
22. gra/yas—referring to; cf. c. 87. 2, but here the constn. is kata\ su/nesin after e)dh/lou h( grafh/.

th\n e)k *s. proa/ggelsin th=s a)naxwrh/sews—Herod. 8.33 relates that Themistocles sent a inessage to Xerxes saying that he had persuaded the Greeks not to break down the bridges over the Hellespont, and consequently the king might retreat at leisure. The story agrees with Thuc. here, except that Herod, says the message was sent from Audios, not Salamis. The true object of Them. was to cause Xerxes to retreat rapidly, since Xerxes had been once taken in by a false message from Them. (viz. that the Greeks were about to retreat from Salamis, Herod. 8.33) and would be sure to assuine this one also was false. Them. now misrepresents the object he had had in sending the message. (Haacke and others refer th\n ... a)naxwrh/sews to the earlier message of Them., viz., that the Greeks were about to withdraw from Salamis. By this message Them. caused the defeat of the king; by the later one he rescued the king. This explanation seems simpler; but it looks as if the parenthesis gra/yas ... dia/lusin refers only to what Them. pretends to have done to serve the king.)

24. h(\n yeudw=s prosepoih/sato—Herod. says Them. urged the Gk. fleet to break down the bridges, but he was opposed by the Peloponnesians The Athenian fleet was then willing to go alone, but this Them. successfully opposed. It looks as if Thuc. did not believe in this last part of the story. (Croiset understands ‘which he misrepresented,’ others avoid the appearance of an mconsistency with Herod.)
25. ou) dia/lusin—cf. e.g. iii. 95. 2 th\n ou) peritei/xisin: vii. 34 th\n tw=n *korinqi/wn ou)ke/ti e)panagwgh/n.
27. th\n sh\n fili/an—my friendship for you.
4. o(/n—duration of time.
10. tou= *(ellhnikou=—about the Greeks, but in sense this is object of doulw/sein.
12. pei=ran didou/s—so pei=ran lamba/nw.

13. h)=n ga\r ... dhlw/sas kai\ ... a)/cios—the aor. partic. with h(=n is here joined to an adj. with h)=n: the consin. is nunsual, and some edd. place bebaio/tata ... dhlw/sas between commas, taking kai/ as emphasising diafero/ntws ti. Transl. ‘Them. was in fact one who showed most convincingly natural powers, and he was beyond all others worthy of the very highest admiration in this respect.’ e)s au)to/ refers to fu/sews i)sxu/n: diafero/ntws ti belongs to qauma/sai: for ma=llon e(te/rou cf. c. 84. 2 h(=sson e(te/rwn.
14. fu/sews i)sxu/n—Thuc. evidently holds with the old view, as against the sophists, that fu/sis is superior to ma/qhsis.
15. e)s au)to/ —e)s to\ cuneto\n fai/nesqai.

16. ou)/te promaqw\n ... ou)/t' e)pimaqw/n—not aiding it (th\n cu/nesin) by any knowledge acquired before or after, i.e. either by learning or by experience. (What time is alluded to in the pro- and e)pi-? Some say his entry into public life, others, much better, the time when he gave any advice derived from this cu/nesis—but interpret, ‘his opinion was not based on previous knowledge, nor, after giving it, had he to modify it because he found he was wrong.’ Neither verb occurs elsewhere in Thuc. Croiset sees an allusion to Prometheus and Epimetheus.)
18. di' e)laxi/sths boulh=s—with the least consideration.

19. e)pi\ plei=ston tou= genhsome/nou—those edd. who connect these words understand to the remotest future, so that e)pi\ plei=ston refers to time: the objection lies in the sing. tou= genhsome/nou after the plur. mello/ntwn, and so some think it spurious, others join tou= genhsome/nou to tw=n mello/ntwn, which is very forced. But all difficulty disappears if we understand by to\ genhso/menon the particular event that was going to happen and take e)pi\ plei=ston of extent, as in e)pi\ plei=ston a)nqrw/pwn in c. 1. 2, so that the whole phrase emphasises only the extraordinary accuracy of his ei)kasi/a: ‘his forecasts of the future were the best, in every event proving more accurate than those of others.’ e)pi\ p. tou= gen. is lit. so as to cover the greatest part (i.e. a greater part than any one else) of just that which was coming.
20 meta\ xei=ras e)/xoi—so Aeschin. 1.70 a)\ nuni\ meta\ x. e)/xete: =metaxeiri/zoito.
21. e)chgh/sasqai—expound his views on it.
w(=n d' a)/peiros ei)/h in contrast with a(\ meta\ xei=ras e)/xoi=‘that which he took no personal share in.’
22. ou)k a)ph/llakto—he did not fail to, ‘was not without the power’; in later prose we should have tou=.—Them. lived before the days of developed oratory.
23. to/ te a)/meinon h)\ xei=ron—the advantage or disadvantage of any proposed step.
24. to\ cu/mpan ei)pei=n—parenthetical inf., to/ belonging to cu/mpan.
25. mele/ths de\ braxu/thti—with the shortest preparation, a second way in which he showed his power of hitting on the right thing in a minute. The two phiases are not really quite parallel.
28. farma/kw|—the story was that be drank bull's blood: Thuc. evidently thinks it a foolish tale, Aristoph. Eq. 83.

4. a)/rton ... oi(=non ... o)/yon—according to a Persian custom: cf. Plat. Alc. i. p. 123 B ‘he said (the person meant is perhaps Xenophon) he passed a district which the inhabitants called zwnh\n th=s basile/ws gunaiko/s: and another called “the mirror” ... kai\ o)no/mat' e)/xein e(ka/stous tw=n to/pwn a)po\ e(ka/stou tw=n ko/smwn.’ Lampsacns and Myus belonged to the Delian League, so Them. cannot have actually enjoyed their revenues.
8. oi( prosh/kontes—Cleophantus, a son of Them., lived at Athens. In later times the grave of Them. was located at the entry to Piraeus.

21 prou/legon ... mh/—in the terms of an ultimatum it is not surprising to see mh/ where ou) would be ordinarily used: prole/gw contains a meaning of advice or warning. For the Megarian decree and Aegina see c. 67.
27. e)pergasi/an —e)pi- denotes encroachment, as in e)pine/momai.
th=s i(era=s—he means the land between Megara and Attiea consecrated to the Eleusinian goddesses (Schol.).
28. th=s a)ori/stou—as Mr. Forbes says, this seems to be distinct from th=s i(era=as, and may mean an undefined or neutral strip of land.
a)ndrapo/dwn u(podoxh/n—this matter is parodied by Aristoph. in Acharn. 325 f.: runaway slaves from Attica found a refuge in Megara.
6. poih/santes—having called through the officials.
7. gnw/mas sfi/sin au)toi=s prouti/qesan—opened a debate, a technical phrase applying properly to the president of the ecclesia (e)pista/ths), who allowed the discussion.
10. e)p' a)mfo/tera gigno/menoi—ranging themselves on both sides, i.e some taking the one view, some the other.
11. w(s (xrh\) mh\ e) —generally e)mpo/dios takes dat. of person.
14. le/gein te kai\ p. d —this explains prw=tos, and always denotes eapacity for public affairs.
19 o)rgh=—spirit, their ardour cools when they have to carry out their resolution.
21. ta\s cumfora/s=ta\ sumbai/nonta, events; so below.
trepome/nous—passive.
22. o(moi=a kai\ paraplh/sia—these occur together several times, without substantial coherence of sense.
24. toi=s k. do/casin—fut. perf. in sense=a(\ a)\n do/ch|.

27. ta\s cumfora\s tw=n p.—the issues of things (lit. “events following from affairs”) can be as incomprehensible in their course as man's thoughts, so that failure is no proof that a resolution was wrong.
29. o(/sa a)/n—whenever anything=(e)n pa=sin)o)/sa a)/n.
3. ei(rhme/non—in the thirty years peace.
di/kas dido/nai kai\ d.—cf. c. 28. 2. The best MSS. give diaforw=n from diafora/: the parallel passages, as cc. 56. 1 and 78. 4 favour diafo/rwn from dia/foros, but cf. cc. 23. 5, 146.
8. dialu/esqai—middle.
12 teleutai=oi—pred. with h(/kontes.
15. peri\ braxe/os—about a trifle; cf. c. 78. 1.
16. o(/per—accus. de quo, becoming the subject of kaqaireqei/h. prou/xontai=profasi/zontai.
18. u(poli/phsqe—after the war has begun.

20. e)/xei—involves: u(mw=n depends on gnw/mhs: ‘the confirmation
and trial of your resolution’ are explained in chiastic order by the two clauses that follow.
21. oi(=s—masc.=e(kei/nois ga/r.
24 safe\s a)\n k.—make it clear to them that they must deal with you on an equal footing rather than as superiors.

28. kai\ e)pi\ mega/lh| kai\ e) b. p.—be the reason great or small for yielding. The constn. changes from infin. u(pakou/ein to partic. ei)/contes ... e)/contes, with the intention of not. It would be more usual, but it can hardly be necessary, to have w(s after profa/sei.
3. a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn—masc.
4. pro\ di/khs—before, meaning instead of proceeding by arbitration. Cf. Dem. 23.28 a(\n a)fe/lhtai/ tis ... mh\ boulo/menos pro\ di/khs e/kdou=nai.
toi=s pe/las—cf. c. 32. 1.
5. ta\ de\ tou= pole/mou ktl.—object of a)kou/ontes, but its position gives it the effect of an accus of respect.
8. au)tourgoi/ —di' e(autw=n th\n gh=n e)rgazo/menoi spa/nei dou/lwn (Schol.).
11. braxe/ws—only for a short time. The object of e)pife/rein is pole/mous.

13. nau=s plhrou=ntes=nau=s a(\s plhrou=sin. Several edd. accept the conjecture plhrou=n, which is very probable. In Plat. Gorg. p. 494 C plhrou/nta is probably a corruption of plhrou=n. Apart from the awkward constn. here there seems to be no point in plhrou=ntes.

15. a)po/ntes—the three particc. are causal, and the full meaning is ‘since to do that (nau=s ... e)kpe/mpein) involves to them (1) absence from their lands’—(cf. the opposite e)pi\ tw=n i)di/wn ei)=nai Ath. Pol. c. 15), (2) paying the expenses out of their own money instead of getting it from the state, and (3) being chased off the seas by the Athenians.

16. ai( de\ periousi/ai—this sentence has direct reference to the finaneral condition of Athens. The policy of Pericles was to accumulate a reserve, so that the ei)sfora/—war-tax on property—was seldom levied; but the Pel. would depend on such a tax; see c. 121. 4. bi/aioi (like be/baios always of two
termins. in Thuc.) is a descriptive epithet to ei)sforai/ in general: they are not free gifts (e)pido/seis).
18. sw/masi—cf. c. 121. 3.

20. to\ me\n ktl .—to\ me\n ... to\ de/ apply to sw/masi ... xrh/masi, pisto/n and be/baion being pred.: lit. having in the one a possession they can rely on—viz. that it may come safe out of the dangers; but in the other a belonging for which they have no security that they will not spend it before the war ceases.
26. mh\ pro\s o(moi/an a). — ‘against a power differing in character’ from theirs. The mh/ under the influence of the infin.
o(/tan—so long as; cf. c. 142. 1.

17. th
 me
 ga ktl.—this is taken in two ways: (1) th
 me/n object of paraskeua/sasqai and po/lin a)nti/palon in apposition= w(/ste gene/sqai po/lin a)nti/palon (Krüger etc.); (2) th
 me/n accus. of respect, ‘as regards the one’ (Shilleto, Classen, etc.). The sense is clearly given by Arnold: ‘Pericles is distinguishing
between two different methods of e)pitei/xisis, the one by founding a city in the neighbourhood of Athens strong enough to interfere with her trade and be a check on her power, po/lin a)nti/palon: the other by merely raising one or two forts in Attica, as strongholds for plundering parties to keep the country in constant annoyance and alarm, frou/rion.’ The only difficulty is that e)pitei/xisis is nowhere found of a rival city founded in time of peace; hence (2) is probably the constn. intended.
18. h)= pou dh/—of course, then, sc xalepo/n e)sti.

19. e)kei/nois h(mw=n a)ntepiteteixisme/nwn—this seems to refer to the certainty that Athens would reply to an e)pitei/xisis by taking similar measures in Peloponnesian territory (Pylus, Cythera): hence we look for a future; and a)ntepiteixioume/nwn, a)ntepiteteixisome/nwn or the insertion of a)/n has been proposed. Another view is that Athens herself is meant; she is already standing as an e)pitei/xisis threatening any post that Sparta might establish in Attica. Since an e)pitei/xisis always occurs in an enemy's country, this could only be justified by supposing that Pericles uses the term loosely for the sake of the antithesis. But it certainly looks as if something to be done by Athens is meant.
22. au)tomoli/ais—by encouraging the slaves in Attica to desert to them. This actually happened in the case of Decelea in after years.

25. ple/on ga\r e)/xomen ktl .—e)mpeiri/as depends on ple/on e)/xomen, we have more experience of land operations through our naval experience than they have in naval operations from their service on land. Pericles alludes to the use of Athenian fleets on hostile coasts in connexion with descents on the land (a)poba/seis). The knowledge of the Pel. coast-line would enable them to choose the right point for an e)pitei/xisis.
28. to\ de/—the de/ answers the me/n of 142.3.

3. ou)k a)po\ tou= i)/sou mega/la—lit. other important things (mega/la) on a greater scale, i.e. ‘have the advantage of them in other important matters.’ This refers back to what has preceded, and is not further explained, for Thuc. does not here want to give a detailed account of the Athenian position: this is done in the second book. The ref., as Steup says, is especially to the fleet.
6. ou)ke/ti e)k tou= o(moi/ou—then it will turn out that it is much worse.
13. o(/ti e)ggu/tata tou/tou—i.e. putting ourselves in thought as nearly as possible in the position of islanders.

14. oi)ki/as—those outside Athens. During the invasions the population of Attica had to crowd into the city, as Athens could not bring into the field an army strong enough to oppose the Pel. invading force.

7. e)kei=na me/n—i.e. advice as to the conduct of the war, which is best given during the war itself. For the present (nu=n de/) our course is clear.

11. cenhlasi/as—these expulsions took place from time to time, no doubt by order of the ephors. Plato suggests ironically that the Spartans used them when they wanted privacy for the study of philosophy; Xenophon says they feared corruption of the traditional character by contact with ce/noi. poiw=si , of course, ‘enact’ in their laws.

12. ou)/te ga\r e)kei=no kwlu/ei —ou) kwlu/ei there is no hindrance to stands for ou)de\n kwlu/ei in Aristoph. Av. 463, and in two or three passages from later authors. Hence there is probably no need to insert ou)de/n here. e)kei=no ... to/de=the cenhlasi/ai and *megare/wn yh/fisma—there is as little to forbid the one as the other in the thirty years' truce.
16. sfi/sin e)pithdei/ws—see c. 19; alluding to the form of constitution. The Schol. says he thinks toi=s *l. is a gloss on sfi/si.
18. au)toi=s e(ka/stois—sc. e)pithdei/ws.
